content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs was originally going to be a direct sequel in the True Crime series many years before actually coming out. Thankfully, this never came to fruition. After a few changes, and a few publishers later, Sleeping Dogs came to be. Some will say it is the spiritual successor to the True Crime series. I'd like to think the connection never happened. Mainly because this game is just that good. Too good to be tied to a deservedly so dead series. Sleeping Dogs takes place in Hong Kong, and has you playing the role of an undercover cop with ties to a small group of triads, as you work your way up through the ranks, and work from both sides, as a straight up police officer, and an undercover officer playing a triad member who gets in too deep. It's a risky business, but for our main protagonist Wei Shen, it's all part of his life now. Sleeping Dogs is an open world action game modeled after games like Grand Theft Auto. You can run around freely, drive cars and ride motorcycles, and either take on main and side missions, or do other things as you progress through the game. Sadly, there is not much to do in terms of sandbox play. The world is very nicely detailed, and seems to be alive with the amount of people you will see moving about, but there just is not enough freedom to make this a real sandbox open world game. Most of the things you'll find yourself doing will be set up as part of the game instead. And anything you make up along the way will be few and far in between. Unlike open world games like San Andreas or Just Cause 2, where you can spend countless hours outside of any scripted events, making the game seem like your own little playground. This may be partially due to how constrained the world is. You can wander around streets, and inbetween buildings, and even inside of some, but the world is not as open as I would have liked it to be. Just don't be fooled by how big the map is, as lots of areas can not be accessed outside, due to barriers. Regardless, it is still a pretty big world. Just not ripe for exploration. Hopefully this gets remedied in the sequel. As for action gameplay, its nice. You won't find yourself using guns often, but when you do, the cover system is decent, and aiming is not too bad. You even get a few max payne style moves, like slo-mo diving thrown in the mix. The star of the combat however would be the hand to hand stuff, which is reminiscent of the Batman Arkham games. You will not be one on one most of the time, but rather one on many. Weaving in and out, doing parries, and a number of nicely animated kicks, punches, and grapples with ease. It's almost like poetry to see it in motion. When you are running from cops, or chasing down the enemy, you'll also find that Wei Shen is a good master of parkour. You don't have a jump button sadly to just jump whenever, but instead the parkour is tied to platforms and obstacles. So you run up to a wall, and Wei Shen will run up and grab a ledge when hit the proper button. He can jump over gaps, slide over obstacles like cars and tables, and more. Again, this is quite nice to see in action.As for the audio, it's fantastic. You have a nice selection of radio stations, featuring both HK Eastern and Western themed stations, full of commercials, and great music. You also have some amazingly done voice acting, helping to bring the story to life, with a cast of seasoned voice actors and tv and movie stars. The voice acting is also a mix of english and cantonese. Mostly english spoken, but a bit of cantonese here and there for authenticity. Some characters will also only speak in cantonese. While pedestrians will almost always speak in english. But the accents are just right even when spoken in english. Sleeping Dogs may not be the ticket for anyone wanting a true sandbox open world game, but for those starving for a good action game with an open world set piece, and a great story. Sleeping Dogs is the perfect fix.

												After 46 hours gameplay and 100% completed game achievement, i need to say this game is pure gold.Even though people says its like Grand Theft Auto so thats why this game is just "boring copy", they think.This game doesnt need to be "Grand Theft Auto killer" to be fun and exciting to play. Story of the game is wonderful and so exciting and intense to watch, so much story line tricks and turn-ups. Game focus on to chinese open world place called "Hongkong" as based to real-life city of China. Driving system of game is pretty contradictory. Cars, motorbikes & boats. Nothing special, but nothing to lame. What makes the game unique is it's fighting system. Easy to learn and fun to do. Story & game itself use's more fighting than guns and i think its good choice because its different way when comparing other games. And of course game uses melee & firing weapons, not very much of them (in my opinion) but its understandable because of the fighting system of the game.        Graphics are beautiful when you download free "High-Resolution graphics" from steam store. It makes game more beautiful.Game contains sidequests, collectibles and minigames. Vehicle stores, clothes stores, food markets, parkour tracks and even karaoke bars!+Story(line)+Chinese atmosphere+Cool and beautiful looking chinese Hongkong+Fighting system+Sidequests, collectibles and exploring adds more to do-Confusing Driving system-Scumbag AI-Most of storyline quests are too easy-"Side stuff" is in many places one-sided9/10 One of the best games ever what i have playedGreetings from finland, i have so bad english :D

Posted: November 25, 2013
												What was once shelved and left for dead by Activision is given new life and what would have been the third in the True Crime series is now Sleeping Dogs, exceeding expectations of just about everyone but Square Enix, the new publisher.Sleeping Dogs is an open world action-adventure(sandbox) game that takes place in China where you play as undercover cop Wei Shen, tasked with infiltrating the Triads. The game has been compared to other games in the genre, most notably, GTA. While similar in gameplay, Sleeping Dogs is no clone. It has an interesting story that should keep you enthralled, coming up in the underworld of a criminal organization, racing across the streets of Hong Kong, shooting it out with rival gang members all while undercover for the HKPD. The gameplay is what you would expect of a game of this scale and caliber. The game will give you plenty to do and will leave you wanting more. Unfortunately, the DLC doesn't quite fill that need.* You can play with either Keyboard and Mouse or plug in a controller. I tried both input methods and found both options to be enjoyable. Thankfully, that means the choice up to your preference. Pros: +Very fun+Good story+Solid gameplayCons: -Story is a bit short.-DLC is lacklusterOverall rating: 8/10

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)Game Name: Sleeping Dogs Original Release: 2012 Genre Tags: Sandbox; Action; Third-Person; Martial Arts; Open World; Adult My Overall Grade: A Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 25-55 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseursREVIEWWhy do you not have a pork bun in your hand?Seriously though, this game is amazing.  It brings nothing particularly innovative or special to the genre of open-world-mayhem sandbox gaming, but what it does offer is high-quality, exciting gameplay and a well-written narrative. Sleeping Dogs is a worthy pick-up for any fans of the genre looking for something new.You can’t fly jets, grapple-hook atop buildings, drive a tank down a city street, or do some of the other extreme actions that are becoming common in the genre. Sleeping Dogs is more grounded in reality and focuses more on having a believable narrative and atmosphere.  That said, the gameplay is still very enjoyable and there is plenty of extra stuff to do besides playing through the main story. Furthermore, the simple fact it takes place in Hong Kong goes a long way to add a little unique novelty  to the experience (like driving on the left side of the road, entering cars from the right, and just exploring a virtual city that isn't supposed to be in America for once).It has a well-written story that is quite engaging and is reinforced with decent voice acting.  Combined with the nice graphics and atmospheric gameworld, it results in an excellent overall presentation. It definitely is an experience that feels more authentic than some of the more ridiculous games in the genre.   I definitely recommend to any fan of the genre who is looking for some novelty that they check out this game.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

Posted: June 25, 2014
												---PLEASE READ BEFORE YOU BUY THE COMPLETE PACKAGE/ALL DLC---I enjoyed this game when I first bought it new, but never got a chance to finish it. I came back to it and recently bought it again because it was on steam sale. My only complaint is the DLC. PLEASE, be careful and read what the DLCs are and what they give you. Buying the complete DLC package is totally game-breaking. It really hurts my enjoyability of the game because it's way too easy to play now. Here's some things you should avoid the DLC because:Right out of the tutorial/first few starter missions, you become level 8/10 on triad and cop. Face is I believe 7. You gain more XP from everything.You are level 10 (max) in everything by the time you get to the mission that gives you the impounded car (Race Scene mission). Not to mention that the DLC gives you about a dozen cars already before then.You begin the game with $200,000 in your pocket. One of my best memories of this game is how hard it was to hustle to get money, and how rewarding it was to afford the things you want. Now, before I even get the first starter car, I can afford every car in the game practically.You receive a lot more money from everything. You will start receiving at least $5,000 from every short mission. $5,000 used to be a lot, now it's chump change with the DLC.You receive outfits with overpowered stat bonuses. One outfit gives you 60% reduction from all melee damage taken. That makes sense, right? Another outfit (Super Swat) reduces ALL incoming damage by  50%. That is rediculous, even for late game. Some outfits (like the deus ex outfit) even give you guns. Equip the deus ex, agent 47 or any of those outfits and it gives you the fitting weapons (flechette rifle for sarif armor, silenced pistol for agent 47 suit).You will already own all player homes. I didn't figure this one out until it was too late. I was freeroaming looking for drug busts when I came up on one of the best player homes you can get, the mansion. It was unlocked. I could use it. It was my home already, it even marked it on the map. There will be absolutely nothing to work for. You get all the free guns, clothes, houses, cars and even money you will need. I currently have about $600,000 and I haven't even gotten to the part where wei is kidnapped.There are more reasons to avoid some of the DLCs than this. Now, I'm not saying that ALL the dlc are bad. A lot are fun, actually. I enjoy a lot of the ones that add content to the game. However, a lot of them are WAY too game breaking.DLC YOU SHOULD AVOID:High Roller Pack (near infinite money, best car. It gives you a nice suit but that's not very important)The Red Envelope Pack (It adds 20 packages for $50,000 at each Parking Garage in the freeroam world, totalling one million dollars you can get in 10 minutes of driving)Top Dog Gold/Silver Pack (INSTANTLY gives you a ton of XP in all fields, makes you near max level at beginning of the game)Square Enix Characters Pack (I do enjoy this pack, but it is something I must warn you about. Gives you deus ex and agent 47 outfits, which come with overpowered outfit bonuses and free guns)Retro Triad Bundle (The outfit this pack gives you makes you do more damage, gain more triad and face XP, and gives you more melee damage resistence. Overpowered)Movie Masters Pack (Added this purely because of the Bronze Warrior outfit it gives you. It looks cool, but it's unlore friendly and gives you 60% resistence to melee damage which is overpowered)I hope this review helped you a bit. Now, I'd like to mention again, these DLCs are fun. They add more opportunities for replay and freeroaming. However, you should avoid getting these if it is your first time playing the game, it honestly ruined most of the fun for me since I was way overpowered at the beginning of the game. The fact that this (mostly) singleplayer game is basically Pay-to-Win makes it deserve my downvote. I hate that I can't love this game, it's one of my favorites, but I must warn you how game breaking the DLC is.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: Sleeping Dogs 

			Views: 1,625		

			Sleeping Dogs' development cycle had some bumps along the road, in spite of all the hardships was this old dog able to learn some new tricks?		

Fans of film directors like Johnnie To, Ringo Lam and John Woo will feel right at home in Sleeping Dogs. You take control of Wei Shen, a Hong Kong native who has just returned home after spending some time in the United States. He is working as an undercover cop under superintendent Thomas Pendrew and his handler Raymond Mak in an effort to take down a powerful Triad gang known as the Sun On Yee. Wei's assignment positions him as a lowly thug under the wing of a 'roided out hothead named Winston Chu and follows his ascension to a prominent figure within the Sun On Yee. Things become complicated however, as the line between undercover cop and criminal blurs. Wei becomes deeply entrenched in the criminal underworld, building friendships with his gang-mates while witnessing signs of corruption within the police force. The yarn spun by Sleeping Dogs is solid enough but it's telling stumbles. Pacing is all over the place, and many important elements seem undercooked. Sleeping dogs has issues integrating plot points into missions and providing build up. For example, Winston has a fiancee that is revealed when you have to run a few errands for her as part of a mission. She softens Winston's image and makes him a little more human but, unfortunately she exits the plot just as abruptly as she shows up making her little more than a tool to develop Winston. Thankfully the finale builds in a satisfying way and there are some sections that are really effective and engaging in the middle portion of the tale. Its just a shame that it couldn't be more consistent and better developed. Being an undercover cop Wei must straddle the line between right and wrong and missions reflect this. Good guy Wei finds time between running errands for the triad to assist a police inspector with some of her cases. Triad missions are strait forward affairs that usually involve collecting protection money, stealing stuff, beating the hell out of other gang members and maybe shooting a few people. Cop cases play out more like multi-stage quest chains commonly associated with RPGs. Wei also earns experience for both a cop skill tree and a triad skill tree. You earn both types of experience in both mission types but being a public menace and destroying public property or killing civilians will take away from the cop experience you can earn in a mission. Throughout the course of Sleeping Dogs Wei hacks cameras, races, sings karaoke, cracks combination locks, plants bugs, triangulates cellphone calls, bets on♥♥♥♥♥♥fights, plays mahjong poker and picks locks. The game does a great job of mixing these elements up and missions are generally interesting with only a few lame ducks.  All of the aforementioned elements are secondary to the driving, fighting and shooting you will be doing to make your way through the game. The fighting system in this game really shines. Wei relies on strikes, grapples and counters to dispatch his foes. Enemies come in varieties as well, some specialize in strikes and block many of your attacks, grapplers are burly chaps that you want to keep at bay with power strikes, some enemies wield knives and tire irons and later in the game you will find enemies that are really only susceptible to counters. If you want to live in Sleeping Dogs, you will have to prioritize your foes and time your attacks carefully. Your wushu can be supplemented by finding Jade statues that can be returned to the Kung Fu master in the game. These moves are valuable tools and you will find yourself utilizing most of them. They allow you to snap your opponents limbs, deliver powerful blows and disarm your foes. It's a great system and is evolves enough during the course of the game to remain engaging. Driving is similar to other open world games with cars that handle differently based on weight and size. The one unique addition to the driving mechanics is a button that allows you to throw the car sideways by pushing the appropriate button or key and moving in the direction you wish to go. This allows you to ram vehicles that are in hot pursuit of Wei. Motorcycles, scooters and boats are also among the vehicles you will pilot. Shooting is of the cover-based variety and Wei can vault from cover and enter slow motion as well as blind fire. It's solid but the mechanics are not as unique and engaging as the hand to hand combat. In light of this most of the game focuses on hand to hand confrontations.  Sleeping Dogs' interpretation of Hong Kong is an efficiently constructed playground. There is an unusual amount of verticality in this game despite the lack of air vehicles. Wei can climb the ledges and scaffolding around a number of the building and access rooftops. Pedestrian overpasses on the streets also provide access to high places in which numerous collectables are tucked away. Free running is also a part of Sleeping Dogs' bag of tricks. At certain points Wei will have to pursue targets on foot through a gauntlet of barriers and other impediments. These sections involve the player running after them and timing button presses to clear obstacles gracefully, poor timing results in fumbling over an obstacle and loosing ground. The animations for these sections don't flow together as smoothly as those in Assassin's Creed but the extra input required to complete them is a welcome addition that adds a small layer of interactivity in what is usually a passive experience in other games. It's just a shame that the camera is not exactly stellar. It seems to have a knack for being in the wrong place most of the time. Strangely absent is the ability to center the camera with a button press that's so common in third person action games.  On the PC, Sleeping Dogs is a really pleasing game to look at. Square Enix has also made a high resolution texture pack available for those with decent rigs and includes some DX11 features. Hong Kong is wonderfully detailed with neon signs glowing, power lines forming webs overhead, air conditioning fans spinning on the sides of buildings, and plenty of pedestrians and traffic to make the city feel alive. Also, the game wisely uses rain to give everything a nice sheen--as it rains the wet pavement reveals reflections of neon signs and characters appear wet. The handful of interiors are also detailed and pleasing to look at. NPCs are not too detailed and are a little more robotic as a result of a low poly count and the cars are not tremendously detailed but these are technical limitations that are to be expected. The main characters however are richly detailed, making the cutscenes a treat. Skin textures are very detailed and the tattoos that adorn the bodies of the gangsters add quite a bit of character to each of them. You can also customize the clothing that Wei wears and wearing certain combinations of clothing can provide stat benefits. Cloting options are rather varied accounting for both ridiculous looks and strictly business attire.  For a game that was almost canned, Sleeping Dogs is quite impressive. The story fumbles around before ending on a strong note and the camera can be irritating but these faults are offset by great mechanics and strong visuals on the PC. Sleeping Dogs isn't ready to dethrone Grand Theft Auto as the best open world crime game but it's robust mechanics and numerous diversions make it a strong addition to the genre. It appears that Square Enix stuck gold by reviving this dead dog.

Posted: May 18, 2015
												Have you ever imagine an open world game such as GTA IV,a game where you obtain the knowledge of Kung-fu and other eastern martial arts, and a game where you find yourself working as a undercover police simultaneously?If you did so, what are you waiting to buy this game?A main story line where you work as an under cover police man in the most dangerous gang organizations in the entire world, the Chinese triads...Sleeping dogs is a game that combines the power of freedom known in the GTA game series, the use of the environment and knowledge in martial arts to unleash powerful attacks and combos known in many fighting games and most importantly, the perfectly mixed in story line of an under cover police man who will get emotionally attached by his work and the people he interacts with.But, there are few firearms available...This is true, this isn't america where everything is solved by gunfights or explosions. This is Hong Kong, where strength and skill is valued and measured in epic, pleasant hand-to-hand combats. But even despite that, the use of firearms will depend on your type of game play, and the game will satisfy that lack of weaponry, in amazing breath-taking missions as you progress in the game.Isn't Hong Kong a bad choice for a game like this?Definitely not, Hong Kong is currently one of the most wealthiest places in the world; It has everything from a deep underground gang network, a gym to practice or learn new moves after completing each task, a club for you to interact with other people and to complete other side objectives, to random optional objectives and events that will appear in-game.How are the graphics and the environment design?To begin with, the game's designers performed extensive research in Hong Kong to create an accurate portrayal of the city. Art designers spent seven days in Hong Kong, where they studied the city's environment, and took more than 20,000 photos as references for the physical environment in the game. And the result was that many reviewers praised the authenticity and charm of the city in the game.You mentioned the importance of the story line at the beginning, will this mean that after the game story line is completed, there wont be anything else to do?No, almost all side quests and task will continue to be there, and the game wont change at all in order to preserve it's longevity.Should I buy this game? and why?This game is the perfect for anyone who either likes a good detective main story line, an open world sandbox like the GTA game series, and a similar fighting system seem in many fighting genre games.I would rate this game 81 out of 100, or 4,5 out of 5,0. A masterpiece in mixing both action and adventure gaming genres into one, simply brilliant and well-balanced without looking lame, but truly epic!

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs was a game I bought in Steam's 2013 Autumn Sales, after being curious about this game for a long time and being aware that looking up YouTube footage might have spoiled the story for me, this sale was a good opportunity for me to just gamble on this one.And it was jackpot for me. Having played Just Cause 2, GTA 1 to 4, Saints Row 3, L.A. Noire and countless other free roaming games, I was completely overwhelmed by how convincing Hong Kong was portrayed in Sleeping Dogs. Hong Kong, which in this review refers to the map in Sleeping Dogs, is a graphically pleasing platform that carries the player through a gritty storyline revolving around Chinese gangsters. Even though the city is small compared to most of the aforementioned free roaming city games, there is a healthy amount of detail put in every square foot of Hong Kong, making the city feel as big as it would have felt in real life. The city dynamics are downright convincing, you will encounter a large amount of variation among the residents, each with their own reason for being on the street. This, and the amounts of interaction provided for the player, is something that at the time of writing is not appreciated enough in the industry.Sleeping Dogs features oriental themed music to reinforce that atmosphere. The genre of the background music as well as the radio stations vary from hip-hop to classic, all with Chinese roots. Luckily, a great majority of the used vocabulary is English, although you may encounter a Chinese swearword here and there. This is translated in the subtitles and may seem a bit forced, if not out of place. Personally I find it understandable considering a full English or Chinese transcript would've alienated the player from the casting in this context, or otherwise not being able to follow the story at all.It's important that this appeals to the player as the emphasis of the game heavily lies on the implied Chinese gangster culture. This means that gunplay and car-craze is reduced to a minimum when compared to other games in this genre. Rather than mowing down your enemies it's more common to have to fight people barehanded, the use of several martial arts and enemies with different specialities makes this less linear than it may sound. I wouldn't go as far as calling this game less violent either, if anything, this game deserves its 18+ rating more than the others in its genre.Having that said, the mechanics of the game definitely require getting used to, luckily this is achieved through a clever tutorial that gradually increases the freedom you have while playing.To progress through the game there are countless of missions and events to participate in, and not all of these are fun to do. In fact, there's some dreadful shooter-on-rails included. Luckily this wasn't so common that it started to bother me more than I could take but these are things that make Sleeping Dogs far from perfect. It's a missed opportunity to go down in history as a classic, though looking back on what Sleeping Dogs did manage to achieve, it would be greedy to ask for much more. I already feel like a cheapskate having paid so little for what I got.I greatly enjoyed playing Sleeping Dogs and within the 25 hours I needed to finish the story it has managed to claim a place on my list of all-time favourite games.[IMPORTANT NOTE: I have played Sleeping Dogs on the highest settings and with HD textures (free DLC). This makes Hong Kong more crowded and makes everything look a lot better. I imagine this influences the experience quite a bit, so make sure to get the most out of your game.]

Posted: November 29, 2013
												Not a stretch of originality to be seen, but that's okay. It's fine if you blatantly skin your gameplay inspiration from some of the best games of the last three years, so long as you pull it off like Sleeping Dogs has. Combat is a simple, not-so-fluid, homage to Rocksteady's Arkham games. Free motion like a muscular dysfunctional Assassin's Creed and for transport/driving it rips a blank page out of Square Enix's own Just Cause's manual while the narrative is your average hard boiled vice story with an American protagonist. Individually they falter, but as one game they all succeed. I enjoyed it, and maybe you will too.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												Being a nerd precludes me from being a gangster, which is why Sleeping Dogs is so much fun. In pure escapist terms, the game lets me renounce my mild, introverted mannerisms and embrace the violent, yet honour-bound way of life as a member of a Chinese Triad organisation. In other words, I get to assume the unfamiliar role of a bad-a$$, and guess what? I love it.As a pensive nerd, I would quietly apologise and then flee from any threatening bullies. As a righteous member of the Sun-On-Yee however, I could--and frequently would--Dim Mak  anyone, and I mean anyone, that so much as coughed near me. The combat is a lot of fun, reminiscent of the Batman: Arkham series, although not quite as fluid.The reckless abandon is invigorating when you've spent your life adhering to laws and rules. It helps that the characters and story, whilst clichéd, are likeable and intriguing. Hong Kong as a setting is also quite refreshing.Be warned, though. The game has issues starting half the time, and I was constantly verifying the game cache to play it.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs is an open world action-adventure video game developed by United Front Games and Square Enix London. The game has you infiltrating the ranks of the Triads as undercover cop Wei Shen on an island off the mainland of Hong Kong.Sleeping Dogs places a strong emphasis on hand to hand combat giving you the opportunity to unlock a wide range of different combos to be used while fighting. The combat very closely resembles that of Batman: Arkham City however doesn't feel as smooth, regardless anyone who enjoyed that series will probably enjoy this.Every now and then you will be required to use a gun, personally I think they should have just focused on Melee combat either way the guns add some extra "action" to the game. A cover system is also included to allow you to avoid being shot and an interesting bullet-time mechanic allows you to vault over cover and take out enemies in slow-mo.For those who like collecting stuff there is a large amount of collectable items in game to find while playing, you can also obtain several houses and dozens of clothing items, vehicles and furniture to customize your character. Sleeping Dogs also features achievements which cover all aspects of the game including DLC content so I suggest, if you care for the achievements, you also pick up the DLC so you can 100% the game. I took roughly 35-40 hours to 100% the game and should a Steam sale come up I think you should play it too!Pros+ Fantastic graphics+ Interesting story+ Plenty of content+ Enjoyable fightingCons- Controls could be better- Map could be bigger- Achievements require DLCVerdict: 8/10

number of helpful: 38 of 44 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												Note: To see this review in its "true" form (Text formating,in-game pictures and such) go to http://wildwoodgeek2.blogspot.com/2014/04/game-sleeping-dogs.htmlSleeping Dogs is a Open World combat game. it takes pages from Grand Theft Auto and Batman Arkham Asylum. While guns are a big part of Grand Theft Auto in Sleeping Dogs hand-to-hand combat is the most used weapon, with Knifes/bars coming in second. you can get guns, but not by buying them. you have to take them from the police or the elite thugs. this is the first thing about Sleeping Dogs i dislike. i would have liked to been able to buy guns at a store or something, but i understand that the games core focus is the hand-to-hand fighting.Gameplay in Sleeping Dogs is like i said very hand-to-hand combat focused but there are elements of hacking, and just like Grand Theft auto, following missions. but just because the game is focused on the hand-to-hand combat does't mean its not fun. in fact its a lot like playing Batman Arkham Asylum, but with added mechanics. you can smash people into environmental objects and watch a little animation of you beating the heck out of the poor guy. you can throw them into giant speakers, drown them in a public toilet, beat them with a public phone, and more.  Sleeping Dogs also has a strange mechanic called "face". Face is a lot like reputation or renown in other games. you get face for completing missions and doing other activities. the Face mechanic is at most a hamper in your quest for freedom and at least an annoyance. without the proprer level of "Face" you can't do certain things like buy the really cool cars. so even if you have the money you have to have the Face to get it. Cars in Sleeping Dogs are great looking and fun to drive. they are a lot better than the cars in Grand Theft Auto. and they look better than Grand Theft Auto cars. once you buy a car you can get it from any parking area in the city. the amount of cars you can have are unlimited. if you have the money and face you can have the car. unfortunately Sleeping Dogs has no car editing or customization whatsoever, other than changing the car color. the cars are everywhere on the streets and you can grab any car you want, but you can not save that car to use like in Grand Theft Auto. Sleeping Dogs is also riddled with annoying quick time events. if you get hand-cuffed QTE! if you get grabbed QTE! if you get knocked over QTE! they are everywhere in this game, and they are really a quick time event, fail to do it on time and you will pay for it. even with the QTEs sleeping dogs is fun. i just wish there weren't so many of the dang things. Sleeping dogs also has skill trees and perks. you can get upgrade yourself to get more health, easy access to weapons, or new fighting moves.The story in Sleeping Dogs is that your character Ricky Wong a would be drug dealer, is forced to become a undercover cop when he is threaten with lock up time in prison. he then must dive into a dangerous world of drug lords and turf wars. all the while working for the police to catch them. it is of course not easy. the story of Sleeping Dogs is great, while its not the best story ever it is a good story, it feels nice to be on the good side, and yet still be a kinda of "bad guy". and that is another great thing about the game, you can be a rouge/ends justice the means kind of guy or a good/nice cop. playing by the rules will give you more perks in the Police skill tree while being a rule breaker will give you more perks in the Criminal skill tree. one more thing that Sleeping Dogs does better is that the game runs good. remember how Grand Theft Auto crashes and lags up so often? Sleeping Dogs rarely has any of that. granted Grand Theft Auto's world is bigger that Sleeping Dog's, but at least Sleeping Dogs runs like it was made for PC. in the end i would recommend Sleeping Dogs for anyone who likes games like Grand Theft Auto,Saints Row, or Just Cause 2.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												I love this game. This was my "Game of the Year" for 2012. I genuinely believe that if this were just a tiny bit better, it could have been considered a masterpiece. Sleeping Dogs is a genuinely fun game. Controls are solid, responsive, and the game has plenty to do. Whether it's chasing down dudes from another triad with your sports car - SMG's and pistols spitting hot lead in all directions, or it's smashing a thug's head into a car door, or even slapping a hobo with a fish, this game does not stop being entertaining. There are tons of challenges for one to do - including ones such as races, illegal fighting rings, and even chicken fights.Sleeping Dogs is beautiful. The city of Hong Kong has never looked so good. At night, the neon lights glow bright, and are complimented by the game's graphical abilities. I'm not very "tech-savvy" (sorry to use that term), but Sleeping Dogs looks stunning, and runs well even on my somewhat old and under-powered setup.Sleeping Dogs's story is compelling. There are very few games that have made me both laugh, and become visibly upset. This is one of them. I don't usually care this much for somebody who doesn't exist. This may sound stupid, but Sleeping Dogs hits true to heart when it needs to, and it will hit hard.Go buy this game (technically, go buy the Definitive Edition, since the original version isn't available on Steam anymore).97 out of 100. Some people may think that's pretty high, but this game was a saving grace for videogames, in my opinion. So many videogames at the time were just not that great, and then this game blew my mind.Buy this game. Love this game. Review this game. Recommend this game.Welcome to Hong Kong.

number of helpful: 31 of 37 people (84%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												NOTE: I did not play 400+ hours of this game, it's a Steam bug that multiplied my playtime. I inquired about it but got not response from support.INTRODUCTION:Wei Shen a police officer trained in the USA, now working with the Hong Kong Police Department has been sent on a dangerous mission. To infiltrate and gather information on one of the largest and most dangerous Triad Organization in Hong Kong. Will he break under pressure or will he do his duty as one of Hong Kong's finest?PROS:+ Nice Graphics: -I like the visuals but you can clearly tell it was developed with consoles in mind. The only redeeming factor on this area is that a free high-texture DLC pack is available for download. The world is adequately populated by NPCs though at times some parts of the City does look empty. It has a day and night system as well as a weather system which adds to the game's atmosphere.+ Expansive Map: -Though not geographically accurate to the real Hong Kong, the game still provides a massive Island to explore, populated by a number of NPC citizens as well as a number of drivable vehicles. Driving and exploration on this fictional representation of Hong Kong is very fun and oddly calming.+ Interesting Combat: -The combat focuses primarily on punching people using street style Kung Fu martial arts, taking inspiration on the Batman Arkham games. Extremely violent and extremely satisfying in my opinion. This is further amplified by the fact that wearing different combination of clothing has benefits to your over all performance in hand-to-hand combat.CONS:- Very POOR Optimization: -As I said, this game was developed clearly with consoles in mind. Unexplained crashes, errors and FPS drops occur more than I would like. Not game breaking but It can be annoying and disruptive of the otherwise fluid gameplay.- Story: -Though I found it interesting and fun, it's still rather predictable and rather cliche. Even going so far as to have one (or several), "The Godfather" moments. My primary complaint is that there is only one ending to this game and your choices never really affects the ending which makes both "Triad & Police points" a bit useless outside of the combat skill tree.- Side Quest: -The game has a very good concept of side quest, offering both Police and Triad missions but they clearly weren't either finished or polished. I personally would have liked the "Drug Bust" missions to include proper detective work rather than have the game spoon feed who I should arrest.CONCLUSION:PRETTY GOOD. Notwithstanding the fact it's "like GTA", Sleeping Dogs is unique in it's own sense. The story has just the right feel to keep you interested and the gameplay offers enough action to keep you satisfied. Though it's current full price is good, I'd wait for a sale.If you want a break from the fun and mindless violence of GTA, Sleeping Dogs can provide a fresh story based alternative.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

												I very highly recommend this game, particularly when it's on sale.It's one of the few games I've played in the past few years that I've had trouble putting down. It's essentially an Asian GTA, although feels a lot more arcade-y, in that it's somewhat less realistic (cars in particular control very well compared to GTA) but is arguably more straight-up fun. I don't remember too many segments where you'll have to travel long distances without anything to do, or many particularly tedious tasks.I think one criticism that some people had was that it got a bit too repetitive. I can see where they're coming from, as many of the missions are more or less "kill this bunch of guys". With that said, I found the combat incredibly satisfying, if not a little bit easy on the default difficulty.Have bought but haven't actually tried the DLC yet. Will probably edit this review once that's done.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This is one of those games that's look like a generic clone of some other series, but that's a huge disservice to Sleeping Dogs.In a lot of ways, yes, it is GTA with chinese people, but everything about the world set up in this game is fantastic.Sleeping Dogs has one of the most spectacular open worlds ever made. The graphics are amazing, even by PC standards. Everything feels alive and real, like it's a world that would continue to exist after you close the game. The main story in the game is executed surprisingly well, with characters you will actually care about and a story that makes sense, and is most importantly, interesting.Instead of generic gunfights, the majority of the game uses a brawling system very similair to the Batman Arkham games, and it's much more satisfying taking down enemies this way than the standard "shoot the bad guys" approach. Gunplay does pop up occasionally and while it's not anything special, it works and feels decent enough.If you want to be immersed in a game's world, and want to experience more than just a run of the mill story that's an excuse to shoot people, give Sleeping Dogs a try.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												First of all I'd like to point out that I finished the game 3 times. (Twice on my console.)Anyway, Sleeping Dogs is what people nowadays call a "GTA clone" when in fact it's more than what GTA can normally give in terms of a: Amazing and tense lore, the morale of a cop in Gangster's job, the act of having two separate story lines from either the Triad missions between the Police Case solving missions. Sleeping Dogs as a game was amazingly enjoyable for me. The open world was fantastic, the humor was really satisfying here and there, Wei Shen as a main character is really likeable and the game really does make you feel emotion when a character dies at certein events. The combat in Sleeping Dogs really does set itself to be the main glory point of it. Simillar to the Batman Arkham franchise, the combat consists of Melee attacks and counters between attacks, the controls are only somewhat unusual from the standart open world experience but it takes not too long to get used to it. The enviroment kills like shoving someone's face into a lobster rock or a ceeling fan or destroying their face with a car door or just for simplicity shove them into a public toilet till they suffocate. The combat is not very challenging however in Sleeping Dogs, though for new players it will take time to get used to the timing of the counters and of such but with little training they can take on rival Triads with no sweat. Gun combat in Sleeping Dogs appears a bit later on in the game and eventually turns into something you often get used to. Wether it's a firefigth against rival Triads or a armed high speed chase around Hong Kong, the feel of the gun mechanics feel really satisfying, even when ammo tends to be something you'd scavange for since you can't buy weapons though you can stuff a pistol in your back pocket.. Again not really challenging but really satisfying. The story of Sleeping Dogs really sets itself as an Undercover Cop which tries to cripple a gang from the inside while also having the gang be his childhood friends...and enemies. Destined to revenge his sister's death he accepts this mission to cripple and weaken the Sun On Ye Triads while also being one himself as part of one of the gangs. The story has dramatic moments and amazing plot twists that are always rememberable. Graphichs are simply gorgeous on the PC. Having said that I can really only tell that I almost never had enough of looking at the amazing road textures and the neon signs on the streets at nigth! Game has alot of side activities like Poker Majong, street races,♥♥♥♥♥♥figths to bet on (Yes♥♥♥♥♥♥figths..) and also a battle fight club and much more! All due these amazing stuff said about this game, it does suffer from some glitches that can be frustrating at times, some of which just look really odd that to be honest I never experienced on a console. They're not horrible but they can bug you at times.All in all, Sleeping Dogs is an amazing game! By far one of my faveorites of all time! I recommend this game to anyone that enjoys the standart Open World genre and also to those that are looking for a change from your typical GTA/Saints Row.I give this game a 9.7/10

number of helpful: 20 of 23 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												Attention Steam Library Dwellers, it's time to wake up that dog that has curled up deep within your game collection. Not only does it have Steam Cards, it's also one of the surprisingly good games I've played recently. Yes, you could almost say this was a... sleeper hit. OK, so that's hopefully got the terrible puns out of the way, now we can get to the crux of the matter. Sleeping Dogs is a game that deserves your attention; while it might be a new IP name wise, it has a storied history as 'True Crime'. However, due to rising costs Activision sold the rights to Square Enix who rebranded the game as 'Sleeping Dogs'. So yes it's 'new', but it comes with the benefits and years of experience built up from the previous True Crime games - perfect!The game is an Open-World Sandbox game - think Grand Theft Auto x Saints Row. Sleeping Dogs takes what I liked about GTA and what I liked about Saints Row and manages to meld them together into a game that has it's own unique qualities too. This perfect blend comes together to form a really unique and fun sandbox experience. The story is dark, based around an undercover police officer who is trying to destablise and expose the Triad groups in Hong Kong (think Infernal Affairs); the action is fast and frantic, like a John Woo movie; while there is a very refreshing melee element thrown in. It's the melee/Martial Arts element of the game that really allows Sleeping Dogs to stand tall on it's own merits, and not avoids being labeled as 'just another GTA clone'.In fact the combat not allows this game to stand on it's own feet, but manages to propel it above GTA and Saints Row. The gunplay has refreshing, as it's not thrown down your throat at every turn and mission. Your mean weapons are fists and your fury, and melee weapons - yes melee weapons! Meat Cleavers, Swords, Batons, etc are all at your disposal, but it's the environment that will be your biggest weapon. Sure you can kick and punch through the Triad Forces like a young Bruce Lee, but it's when you turn your attentions to the walls, the fuse boxes and other nasty everyday objects that are in the world that you become a bad♥♥♥♥♥Jackie Chan. Grab the enemy and run towards the wall? Ram the guy's head into the wall. Run towards a dumpster? Throw that guy into the dumbster!! Run towards meat hooks... well I'll let you find out...I was honestly surprised at how fun the combat was, it wasn't as mindless as some GTA games where you seemingly have an arsenal of weapons to use at any given time. It wasn't as endless as Saints Row where mobs just keep coming. It had the ideal balance between mobs and user abilities. Sometimes frustratingly you notice that it's always 1v1 in melee combat, despite several other bad guys standing around waiting for you to stop being attacked by their fellow goon - yet this seemed strangely fitting for the Kung Fu/Martial Arts tribute Sleeping Dogs manages to deliver on so many levels. However, if there is a sequal it would be nice to see Square Enix throw in multi-mob counters and combat ala The Batman: Arkham series.Yet, you shouldn't dismiss the gun battles entirely either, as they're intense and just as fun. There's a nice nod to 'John Woo' with the addition of 'Slow Motion' gunplay when you vault out of cover, which can create some fantastic 'holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ moments within the game as you clear a room with headshots and 'reactions'. There are a few minor complaints I had about Sleeping Dogs, but none of them are gamebreaking and once you adapt to the game mechanics seem almost trivial. The driving can take some getting used to, and is perhaps the one area of the game that could do with a lot of TLC in any possible sequel. It's not terrible, just at times it feels as if your cars can't turn correctly, and it doesn't distract from some exciting highway chases and car chase/gun fights.Besides the Radio Stations are immense and contain some fantastic tracks to listen to and select for your driving madness.Visually the game is immense (if you download the free HD Textures map) and makes you wonder (at time of writing) why Watchdogs can't hit the same heights on PC (hopefully it will). When the rain falls and the city lights reflect on the wet film spread across the road, as you drive through the streets of Hong Kong you realise you're inside a wonderful looking gameworld. This game looks better than any GTA has managed to achieve to date on retail release. There are times when the shadows look a little goofy, and the blood splatters can almost become Splatterhouse-esque, but it doesn't distract too much from what is a wonderful looking game and world.Overall Sleeping Dogs manages to put together a great Sandbox game that pulls together infleunces from a range of sources - GTA, Saints Row, Asian Cinema. Yet, it seems to have went largely unnoticed, even 2 years after it's release I'm talking to people who haven't played the game or even heard of it. Those who have played seem to love it, and I can't blame them now that I've joined them.Sleeping Dogs will provide you with ~15 hours of gameplay, with a rich story driven experience that has a very strong combat base to carry the action along. If you're a fan of Asian Cinema then you'll be in fanboy heaven as the nods and tributes appear throughout the game. If you're not a fan of Asian Cinema then I'd like to suggest you watch the following movies either before or after playing the game: Infernal Affairs, Police Story, The Raid. Sleeping Dogs - A surprisingly good game.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												OverviewBack in the days Sleeping Dogs should have been the counterpart to Grand Theft Auto.Well Grand theft Auto is and will always remain a highlight. Especially in case of graphics, open world etc… but Sleeping Dogs confidents in his very own and special way. You play an undercover police officer in Hong Kong, who tried to infiltrate the local triad. There you expect to collect tasks such as collect money, to fight other gangs, kidnap some important people, to steal cars etc. Soon you will experience that the Triad seek internal changes in the balance of their leadership.  At the same time you are giving important information to your boss police). You take out some enemies before you can hack some surveillance cameras. With these cams you can watch drugs handovers, viewing the dealer and call the police to arrest him. You can also do some special missions, following some member of the triade, make hidden photos and listen to some discussions about money transfers.   In my opinion, the story is very captivating and exciting. The voice acting is good and look very authentic. Dont forget, ist not america, ist hong kong, different driving sides, freakier cars and everything is like really densely built. All quest are categorized in three different areas : - Police Area (after completing a quest you earn xp and can level up) - Triade Area (after completing a quest you earn xp and can level up) - Social Area (after completing a quest you earn xp and can level up) Many contents are comparable to Grand Theft Auto . There is a huge open world , lots of traffic , own cars (stealing, buying) , special clothing for your hero, weapons , several apartments and ancillary tasks. You can find hidden chests with money or clothing. To increase your energy, there are several shrines. To learn new fighting techniques, there are also hidden statues. These statues you can bring to your former teacher of martial arts. Afterwards he teaches you a new technique. You can train it in his fighting school. Focus of the game is the martial arts melee. Several kinds of enemies waiting for you : - Light opponents - Serious opponents - Wrestler - Enemies with weapons - Covered Opponents etc.   In addition to the main tasks that you can solve, there will be also little Quests to raise your Social Status. For example helping a woman to sink her car in the river. With those points you can buy better clothes. The clothes also allow you to earn some extra attributes (for example 5 % more damage on enemies in fights). After some time you will have enough money to buy anything, it just matters how is your current level in each area (police, triade, social). Some things you can only buy if you have a minimum level in one of the areas.  GraphicsI dont want to talk much about the graphics. Check out some screenshots, even if you dont play this game on ultra settings, it looks great. It can not exceed GTA, but it still looks good enough in my opinion.  ControlsYou can play it with both controller or keyboard. I prefer Keyboard, somehow I play most of those kind of games with mouse and keyboard. At least its much easier for me to hit targets with weapons instead of using the controller.  My conclusionIf you like GTA, then you will like this for sure. You can feel the intensity of the main character. I really like his way he speaks, the way he acts. He fits totally for this job.  If you love martial arts fightings with a mix of grand theft auto flavour, an open world, undercover action, a great story, then go and get it. I can only recommend the game. Enjoy it   Greetz     MajorKing PS: this was my first review of a game, who finds spelling errors in the text, can keep them xD

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												7.5/10I love that game. I love to be in it, like it's Matrix of sort. It has a beat, that goes on and on. It's full of life, really! For some points, it's bested Euphoria engine, if you know where to look. It's fighting mechanics feels even better than in Batman games! So I really can beat thugs for eternity there, it's always fresh and nice feeling.But, looking at some other points, this game tastes messed up. Story based on Hong Kong movies... just not give a hook for the most part of game progress. Some attached achievements feels very weird, like killing 50 cops for some "rogue cop gold". If you remember Karma from original True Crime, it's even weirder. Shooting mechanics and freerunning stuff almost always appear quite clumsy and far from natural. Driving mechs and some other game aspects just ripped from the "Wheelman".Then, you realise, that all in the game plot was made not quite right, probably because of some stupid focus group, playing every game like it's Carmageddon or Postal.Nonetheless, it's quite a good game. It's GTA-clon, alright, and maybe not the best of them, but smooth, good-looking (with up-to-date-graphics), and have some personal charisma. For once, you play for a good guy, and not for a blood-thirsty deadbeat. If you're up to some gta-like openworld of good quality, it's well worth a shot.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs, What more can i say, 10/10 this open world, crime driven drama is an amazing experience I have not come across before. You play as Wei-shen, an undercover cop whom has the role of bringing down the infamous and well know Sun On Yee Triad affiliates. Through glorious and violent car-chases to all out blazing gunfights, and even lockpicking, hacking and the more suttle of detective work you experience the breadth and height of Hong Kong's underworld. You even approach romantic interest with an underlying premise of information that'll help you bring down the infamous Triads of HK. From martial arts moves reminescent of movie scenes to chasing down petty theives taking advantage of your goodnatured friendliness to help the denizens of HK this is a great game with hours of fun, missions, side quests, exploring and just being an in game cop or criminal. Outfits are varied and great, such as the ong bak themed preset, to the natural born genius Bruce Lee outfit from  "Enter the Dragon" this game has it all. Characters are well presented, plot is fairly limited but linear, development of the protaganist is good, with solid foundations of his motive and even his background affecting his candidacy to be an informer within the Triads. Overall 10/10 game, visuals are stunning, soundtrack is just plain breathtaking, my favourite station is "softly" has amongst the coolest eastern hits like "from Xikou with love" and "love is heavy". Thumbs up, and hope to see a sequel to this True Crime renamed franchise :)Rob, pleased player.

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
Teal DeerDevelopers: United Front Games Publishers: Square Enix Initial release: Aug 2012Genre: Open World, Crime#Worth/NotWorth: #Worth Exposition, Concurrence and SummationWei Shen is a cool ♥♥♥♥in catSleeping Dogs is an open world crime game based in Hong Kong. With a bit of a twist on the traditional main character; You actually play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop attempting to infiltrate the Sun on Yee, one of the leading Triads in China. Each mission is either for getting deeper undercover or for getting better leads and investigating for the police. As you can imagine, many issues arise with this situation and the story telling and voice acting is very good. Quite an enjoyable narrative indeed. Now, some people say that the combat is rather simplistic in that you are able to basically spam one move the entire game and prosper. While this is technically true, that sentiment can be extended to ALL games. The game has a rather robust combat system in that you use quick hits, heavy hits with holding combos, counters, grabs and environmental attacks. Once the combos are unlocked for example you can use X, X, X, Hold X for a 3 hit punch and roundhouse to X, Hold X to punch and low leg sweep making a real life combo that involves timing despite it's one button nature. All this is happening while countering and avoiding grapples. You can even sprint, dragon kick and stun enemies that could lead into other combos. You get out of the combat what you put in, you CAN spam but if that's all you end up doing you probably aren't that interesting of a person to talk to. The animations are fluid and visceral; the sound design and camera shakes are appropriately graphic. The combat while fluid efficiently breaks animations to give a responsive feedback to the player. There is gunplay but I don't really enjoy it to be honest, it's fine and quite functional. It certainly isn't out of place I just feel as though I could have done without it. It's also rampant with slow-mo sequences highly reminiscent of John Woo's Stanglehold.The driving is very arcade-y, very slide-y. This is also quite rampant with slow-mo sequences. It's a lot like a little known game called “Pursuit Force” on the PSP; in which you can jump off or out of vehicles and actively hijack moving cars. The mini-games whether it be, picking a lock, hacking a camera, calibrating a bug, triangulating and tracing a phone call all feel intricate, meaningful and not just sort of tacked on as one button affairs. The game also has some pretty decent DLC, the “Zodiac Tournament” being the best. Appropriately campy, some approximation of a 80's kung fu movie and what feels like a Mortal Kombat vibe. THE GIST A great open world game and decent enough alternative to GTA to make it feel new. I found an immense amount of pleasure beating thugs up which are in no short supply wearing a get up reminiscent of Marshall Law from Tekken or Fei Long from Street Fighter. Follow my curation for morePOST REVIEW RANTI actually played through this game twice now. The first I played it was years ago back when I was in tech school where I lived on a military base with no internet connection. The reason I bring this up is I actually probably have about 60 hours in this game, maybe more but none of that was documented because I was in offline mode. I used to take my laptop with a 630M in it and walk to the library on base to authenticate my credentials and head back to my dorm and get back to gaming. However, none of the achievements or time spent was documented. It would have been great to at least have some way of properly have that info retained. I realize that storing that type of info in say a text document could lead to a lot of, lets call it fraud for want of a better term but it's just a little annoying that none of that time ”exists” Anyways, just thought I'd put that bit of hopefully constructive criticism/frustration out there. I have fond memories of the rigmarole I used to go through when I didn't have proper internet.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game. It's a little on the short side, but the characters were likeable, the world is immersive, and the gameplay and combat were smooth as silk. Special props to the unarmed fight scenes where you could bust out the kung-fu combos, and the gunplay that rings of a cross between John Woo-esque cover vaulting and Max Payne Bullet-time. The vehicles seemed a little tacked on, but there are racing mini-games to satisfy your inner speed freak. Speaking of mini-games, there's also a "karaoke" type game a la Rock Band, which while silly, was still very enjoyable.I was very much reminded of Mafia II, delving into the gritty criminal underworlds; instead of the Italian Mafia Stateside, you're working your way up the Triads ladder in Hong Kong. The story was engrossing and you're stuck in the middle of being an undercover officer while trying your damnedest to not get attached to these lovable gangsters. If you're looking for an immersive crime drama with lots of action in an open-world that hasn't really been visited, go ahead and pick up this game. It's one of my favourites and I'd have it still installed on my SSD if'n I had the space!

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This is easily one of the best open world crme game i've played. Cruising through the streets of HK with some hip hop, techno and soothing pop on the radio is truly a pleasure. There isn't a ton of gunplay but the melee combat is where it shines the brightest. It feels a bit like combat in Assassin's Creed but somehow, better. You can use objects in your surrounding to perform 'environmental kills', throw a girl in your trunk and drive them around and even take a human shield! You can also learn combo attacks that are easy to master. Oh there's also the parkouring, jumping over objects, free running, climbing short walls, definetely on of the best delight. There's also the food and drinks that give you temporary boost in different stats. And also lots of collectibles which isn't easy nor hard to find. On vehicles, you can ram enemy vehicles, go into slow motion while shooting enemies, perform action hi-jack. The story is really great but i honestly think that it ended a little too quickly. In the midst of the game, you actually came to care about several characters, for example Jackie for me. To summarise you should really get this game if you don't mind the extensive use of swearing.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2013
												What an amazing game!  United Front did not pull any stops in creating a fantastic open world sandbox that incorporates all of the best features from similar games.  The game's portrayal of Hong Kong is very vibrant and believable and the NPCs are fun to interact with.  The game world looks amazing on the PC at full resolution (make sure to install the FREE HD texture pack DLC).The combat system focuses primarily on melee with some gunplay mixed in at times.  The combat system plays similar in nature to the Arkham series of games and allows for cool environmental finishers in addition to some time-slowing "bullet-time" when leaping from cover.  Vehicle combat is also fun with action hijacking and time-slowing effects when firing your sidearm from your vehicle.The main campaign story is very good and gripping, but also very predictable at some points.  As an undercover cop trying to infiltrate the Triad organization the game keeps making you think about your duties as a cop versus your loyalty to your "family".  The skill system reflects this conflict in rewarding experience as both a cop and a Triad gang member with experience being portioned based on your actions.  A very nice design feature in linking the advancement of the character to the moral implications of the story and how the player decides to play it out.And any game that uses voice acting from the legendary James Hong is great in my book!Overall if you enjoy similar games like Saints Row or the GTA series then you should love this game.  It is a very big open city with lots of activities to keep the player busy.  A very well thought out and designed game that made me feel that I was actually playing in a classic Hong Kong action film!  Sleeping Dogs is definitely among the top games I have ever played and I highly recommend.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												Amazing game, absolutely worth both your time and money, and the only thing I regret is not buying the full DLC pack right away.I started out with some missions and had some conversations with a pig mask on my head that made me laugh more than it should. Then I discovered the game isn't just for laughs, although it has that in spades - the story is excellent too. I also had the pleasure of experiencing the awesome Batman: Arkham Asylum style combat in the game, including putting a guy through aquarium glass in a night club, breaking legs and arms, and just generally being a wrecking machine of a fighter. Good times, really good times. But there is more.Because there are times in the game that are not only good, they're almost transcendental.One evening, I woke up after a hard day/night before. I had some texts waiting on my phone, from both police investigators and thugs, and said to myself it was going to be alright, even though I was playing both sides. I got out of my apartment, picked up a car and started driving to my next mission. And then...I found myself just keeping on driving around the city.Time had stopped.I no longer sensed the room where my sorry gamer butt was actually sitting because I was no longer there.I'm in Hong Kong - for real. I can't stop driving. It's raining and the reflection from the neon lights in my car, the fan-♥♥♥♥ing-tastic music from the radio, the streets and back alleys, the people, the crowds - I'm completely immersed.And like throwing game money on pimped up outfits (that actually gives you bonuses sometimes, so they're more worth than just for "show"), and awesome, fun, expensive cars, I'm looking forward to throw a little bit of real money on United Front again - this time to buy the whole DLC pack to continue my stay in Hong Kong. It's been a journey like nothing else and it has been the best digital vacation ever.Recommended with all my heart - it rivals some of the best games I have ever played in my life.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												A truly fantastic open world action game set in the refreshingly colorful city of Hong Kong. You play the role of an undercover cop trying to take down a notorious group of Triads. The story is something to take note as there is no simple good cop / bad criminal side to it. The game does a fantastic job of showing you the side of what it means to be part of a Triad family and that the police isn't necessarily the enemy here, nor are the Triads. Doing missions and assignments for both sides will test your moral standings and alignment. The story is good enough and has enough twists and turns to make you stay interested in finding out what happens at the end.Gameplay wise, you will primarily be falcon punching your enemies or killing them with your horrible karaoke singing skills. The game does include guns but is primarily fighting focused. As per open world style, you can drive around the city looking for stuff to do. Options include but not limited to: driving for fun,♥♥♥♥♥♥fighting, dating, looking for shrines of health, delivering vehicles, participating in street races, learning fighting moves, hacking street cameras, karaoke, beating down groups of gangs, eating pork meat, drinking herbal tea, getting an erotic massage, buying clothes, yachting and I've probably missed half of the others.So if you're in it for fighting, the drama of becoming a Triad gang member, the colorful Hong Kong city lights or just want to listen to some fantastic Chinese radio stations - be sure to pick up Sleeping Dogs, you will not be sorry.

Posted: December 13, 2013
												I finally finished Sleeping Dogs yesterday and I have to say I really like the game. Nice story mode (watch Hong-Kong movie Infernal Affairs for more in-depth look on Triad) which was pretty intense, interesting side missions (still didn't finish them all), amazing graphics (especially on rainy nights), excellent sound and soundtrack. United Front Games and Square Enix didn't dissapoint.Combat system is interesting and takes some time to used to, but when you master all kung-fu moves you'll be unstoppable (gather Jade statues as soon as you can cause it will greatly boost your performance in combat). Well, throughout the game, no matter how good you are, patience will be your biggest friend when fighting a group of mobs. :)Don't forget to download High Resolution Texture Pack (free DLC) which will really bring the game to higher level. Also, if you're lazy, you can purchase Top Dog Silver Pack (1,49€) and Top Dog Gold Pack (2,49€) for a quick XP boost, which will instantly give you many skillpoints to enhance your abilities and access to many wardrobe options.Do I recommend this game? Yes, I do. It's a fun open world third person action game in the asian setting which does have some weaknesses (missions are sometimes repetative; chase enemy - kill enemy) but, all in all, it a fun game and I don't think you'll regret it. It should be available on Steam sales for a nice price (I got it for cca 6€ a few months ago) so keep it on radar. Graphics:  ★★★★☆ Sound:  ★★★★☆ Gameplay:  ★★★★★ Music:  ★★★★☆   Overall:  ★★★★☆

												Sleeping Dogs has you play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop with a dark past, trying to crack the Sun On Yee, a powerful triad force controlling the underground of Hong Kong.Sleeping Dogs is beautiful and awesome. The story is superb and entertaining, with hugely comedic elements, but drawing brilliantly on dramatic storytelling where appropriate. The journey of Wei Shen is a tumultuous one, and it's awesome to be there at every step.Along with completing missions for the Triads, you have the Police case sub-missions, carjacking missions, extortion missions, drug busts, hacking and tonnes of random world events to keep you entertained.It took me 31 hours to 100% the game (Cheif Inspector achievement, including all other achievements (except 30/30 Silver/Gold stats)) and I enjoyed every minute of it.Keep in mind: play with the HD texture pack if you can (check DLC, it's free), makes the game look so much better. And, play with a controller. So nice. Brilliant game.-Nilesy

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs isn't a game that does one thing perfect, but it's a game that does a lot of things incredibly well. The amount of effort that United Front Games put into development is shown from start to finish and the overall charm outshines that of any other sandbox game currently on the market. To help explain, the team spent weeks in Hong Kong taking pictures (20,000+) and recording audio to help their efforts in recreating the city. The world feels realistic and everything you encounter has personality. There was also extra work put into making it fully optimized for PC, fluid keyboard and mouse controls, specialized hardware support, and a day one high resolution texture pack to accommodate players with better machines are some of the few.The game offers a nice mix of cop and Triad missions that help the pace of the overarching story, but there are plenty of things to keep you busy for the collector and completionist mind. Featuring a surprisingly well-driven narrative (... for a video game) centered around melee combat and parkour, there are also racing events, random jobs, fighting rings, hidden lockboxes, car deliveries, cockfights, gambling dens, dates (lol), and enough cars and clothes to collect to feel satisfied. Every character is fleshed out and feels real, the city is beautiful, and the soundtrack complements the themes and overall immersion very well.After having owned the game since launch, it remains of one of the few that I still like to revisit every now and again. It's fun, it's cheap, and it deserves a spot in everyone's Steam library. Give it a shot if it's still sitting there with zero hours played and get hyped for Triad Wars.Word of caution: You might be better off without the DLC for the first playthrough, as it gives you in-game experience that will unlock upgrades early on. It takes away most progression and is something to be wary of.

												Don't know exactly why, but I fell in love in this game. It's certainly underrated, due to its graphical glitches, but it sucked me in for long like no other "guns'n'races" sandbox ever managed to. It's probably the sum of many elements contributing to the ultimate Hong Kong mood: smart mafia/triads plot, merged with three-way development system, Cantonese inserts in dialogues, local soundtrack, martial arts, karaoke, sport bikes, and of course creepy chinese snacks from tiny food booths. Diving into it may get dangerous, since you'll inevitably get into the habit of left-hand driving.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												That's what worries me, Wei. You're one of them.......Sleeping Dogs was supposed to be part of the "True Crime" franchise but instead went solo after Square Enix bought the publishing rights. In my opinion, this game deserves way more recognition.You play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop whose mission is to take down the Triads residing in Hong Kong. You'll uncover the power, corruption, secrets behind the gangs and know what it means to be Sun On Yee.Story is a bit cliched in my opinion but is still very well executed. The character development is a bit weak, since I didn't actually feel any real, deep connections with the characters but the voice acting is honestly one of the best I've ever heard.The visuals of this game is just wow, plus with the Hi-res texture pack, everything looks much clearer. Hong Kong is a bright vibrant place full of things to explore and people to kill. I live in a place where the environment is pretty much similar to Hong Kong so that's a plus xD I didn't really enjoy the music that much as you'll be focusing more on the action/driving/shooting.The gameplay mechanics is the strongest point in Sleeping Dogs. It's like the Arkham series..... in an open-world-sandbox-type of game. Enemies are tough in the beginning, but you'll earn upgrades and moves that'll eventually make you untouchable ^_^ Guns are a rarity, since melee combat is its focus. Driving will take some time getting used to, it's very weird when you're driving slow and the camera angles don't really help, but when you're going fast, it's smooth and responsive.Overall Experience: I love this game, but it could've been better. I've experienced lots of flaws in the game such as cutscenes  not loading, game crashing on startup, GPS keeps on redirecting me, cars launching to space etc. Despite all of these errors, the game is very well-made and is pretty solid for most of the time. Plus there are cameras to hack, hidden loots to find, altars to upgrade health, gangs to eliminate, statues to recover, songs to sing, toilets to♥♥♥♥♥♥in, people to kidnap and loads of other stuff to do in this game.... It'll keep you busy for hours xD I very much recommend this game especially if you love the open-world genre.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
"YOU'RE A COP. I'M AN UNDERCOVER COP."Sleeping Dogs nominated GOTY for 2012, didn't win, but still deserved at least nomination.Big plus goes for the story. It's actually more gripping for me than any of GTA series so far for example. It's like a good movie - full of great moments, action, and few emotion scenes. Basically great Yakuza story. It took me about 18 hours to finish whole game which's really long time, and additional 20 hours for completing it to 100% (And still ain't got all achievements :( A lot of times I thought it's just end of the story, but good for me, it wasn't, and long way forward awaited.  And here comes the question what's better - fists or weapons.. Of course fists and by this, I gotta mind that fighting system is really awesome. Camera in fights never flew away or something like that. Doing enviromental kills is great fun, I'd say also very important part of the game. Covering is not so good at all, but as I said, primary, players should use fists more than weapons (Gold Deagle :3You can buy furniture to your houses if you find seller at secret locations. You can buy cars to your garage. You can even bet money on cockfights. Some advanced GTA sh*t right?DLC -Besides the game rating, it's important to mind DLC's. There's 25 DLC's, those which give you some in-game bonuses such as money, clothes, cars and stuff like that I won't mention. I'll mention only 3 - Nightmare in North Point, Year of the Snake and Wheels of Fury.First two are story filled but without previous story connection. They provides 10 achievements (5 and 5). Story of in NiNP is so stupid, that it ain't even worth to talk about. 3 types of some "magic" enemies, empty town and one magic sword. My godness what kind of bshit is that.Year of the Snake is pretty much better than NiNP. My personal feeling is, that it was prequel of police career of Wei Shen. More packed action than in main story, but defeat of cultist ? Oh come on.Wheels of Fury contains less than 10 missions which point was to build hyper-car. I mentioned this because of fast look of it, enjoyment of the car, and additional rampage with it. Connected with main story means another rampage against Triads.Bonus Point: Wei ShenRating: 8/10------------------------------------------------------Sleeping Dogs - 8/10Nightmare in North Point - 1/10Year of the Snake - 6/10Wheels of Fury - 5/10
