content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												Wonderful game. Looks like GTA and Yakuza had a child and it’s turned out to be awesome.Sleeping dogs owns GTA4 in every way. I was forcing myself to finish GTA4 and enjoyed Sleeping dogs twice (on PS3 and after couple of years on Steam) and even collected all the achievements.Firstly the graphics are much better, GTA4 looks like crap and sleeping dogs looks great and when it’s start to rain it looks amazing. Sleeping dogs runs much MUCH better too while GTA4 is barely playable and bad looking even on high end machines.The gameplay is much more fun than broken GTA4, where controls are pathetic, shooting is frustrating, cars are bouncing, etc. This is not existent in Sleeping dogs. Controls are really good except for some rare camera issues. Driving is fun, especially shooting while driving and hijacking. And shooting mechanics is great, it’s easy to target the enemy, shoot him in the head, hide behind cover or disarm the enemy.The fighting system, is something like Yakuza. There are some combos which you learn by levelling up, you can use environment and knives, cleavers or even umbrellas, purses and my favourite – a fish to kill people. Side missions are not boring unlike in some other games, most of them are different every time. Catching the thieves, throwing out the drunks from the shop, collecting debts, stealing cars or find the lady in a car’s trunk and free her only to find out that it’s some sexual game and she was waiting for her husband to find her, not you.The story is good too. As undercover cop you must infiltrate the triad and bring them down. So you play as a cop and as a gangster depending on the mission. Sometimes it’s just driving, sometimes fighting or some bloody shootout.Oh and the game have radio with a different genre of music. My favourite is roadrunner records station. It has such bands like Machine head, Dream theatre, Soulfly and Trivium. It’s really fun to kick some teeth while Fear factory’s edgecrusher is playing :) The only downside of this game for me is that it lacks activities. After playing Yakuza games which has a bunch of activities I want more of them in other games too. The only activities are♥♥♥♥♥♥fights, races and mah-jong. Because of this I’m giving this game 9/10 :)

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												I never bought this game on release because I don't like action/fighting titles - or any game that requires gamepad gymnastics, but having read about the game's Hong Kong open-world, I picked it up in the summer sales, and wow, what a game!Combat is mostly martial arts and is fairly easy going for controllerphobes like me.  The Hong Kong world is fantastic, very atmospheric and way too vast to explore!  There are many optional side missions and two story strands to play (a gangland member and an under-cover cop) that are played side by side.  Some of the minor NPCs are a bit cliched and stereo-typed (to the point I cringe) but stronger characters are developed well.A very enjoyable game for anyone who enjoys mission-based antics in a highly detailed and atmospheric world, with a good story to go with it.  The only negative is that all the accompanying DLC levels you up almost to max so there's nothing to work up towards (I learnt this too late), but otherwise it's a fantastic experience.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
Gameplay:Similar to the styles of Grand Theft Auto and the Saints Row series, this game is a visual impact of what gang life would be like on the streets if there was an exaggeration on the realism. Allegedly being trained in a kung-fu training school at your home town of Old Prosperity in Hong Kong, you’re equipped with martial arts and the ability to smoothly defeat any enemy you come across with ease. As much as this fighting style is fun and easily playable, it does leave little challenge and it would be better if enemies were faster or even if more bunched on you at the same time – similar to that of the Batman: Arkham series. The whole customization scheme is great for your player, buying clothes and the DLC packs that allow more custom outfits. However, I would love it if Square Enix put emphasis on the customization on the character himself (Wei Shen) and allow you to maybe change his looks a little bit e.g. his hairstyle. In addition, a positive feature would to allow vehicle customization, not to the extent of Saints Row where it almost seems tacky, but maybe the addition of NOS or bulletproof windows etc (seeing as you are an undercover cop). The map is easily explorable but can feel a bit repetitive or leave you with the feeling that more could be added.Graphics:I actually love the graphics on this game, even though some improvement could be made. The graphics do seem quite decent in my opinion; although the problem I seem to find with them is that everything seems to be a little too reflective or edgy. Although this seems really picky, these factors are highly noticeable and can become a little bit of a nuisance – especially to those struck with OCD! I think for a sequel the graphics should definitely be improved to the quality of more recent games to make it seem like a more scrutinised game: if that’s even the correct term for it.Controls & Movement:As previously mentioned, the combat style is really playable with this game with the only problem being that the techniques – although look rather good  - are really simple to complete; this leaves the game drought of challenge at times. Staying positive however, this game’s combat is definitely more advanced than games such as Grand Theft Auto, Saints Row and the most similar game style is the Batman: Arkham series however that has a little more complexity: with combos at a more developed stage. If the next Sleeping Dogs (or True Crime) took a shining to this then they could make the game a percentage better than it already is. The main fixture they should improve though is the gun system, as much as I love the slow-motion action scheme sometimes, I would like it if you could store guns and/or aim with a bit more ease.Storyline:The storyline to this game is actually very, very good. I find that it’s more intellectual than most games these days and has had a lot of thought built into it. The game makes your character experience a series of feelings and emotions and different thoughts such as revenge or anger. Although you’re an undercover cop cooped into the life of a gang called the Sun-on-Yee, you actually become sucked into their life more than your police life; you’d consider yourself as one of them before calling yourself a cop. You rise through the ranks and earn your place through hard work and unthinkable tasks to have your mind played and traumatic experiences – for the character, not us. With side stories and missions you are able to take a break from all the action and lay low as a racer or simply as a civilian hanging out with some girls *cough* the girlfriend experience needs improving *cough*.Conclusion:To conclude, this game is brilliant in most aspects, not too much thought put into anything but not too little. Even if more thought could be put into some factors of the game such as combat and miscellaneous additions for example vehicle and character customization, it still seems to be intuitive with its ideas. Although being similar to other games of its genre, it manages to remain original for a sandbox game because of its great storyline and renewed gameplay style. Moreover, the game is really playable – especially with a controller – which makes it quick to learn, leaving the rest of your time to enjoy the aesthetics and unique style of play.Rating:Gameplay: [9/10]Graphics: [9/10]Controls & Movement: [9/10]Storyline: [10/10]Overall: [9/10]

												Really wanted to like this, the setting is interesting, it has good famous voice actors and I love HK cinema. But this game is just a collection of bad game design issues, the driving is the worst in any sandbox game I have tried to date, the fighting is always a dull exercise in waiting for counters and trying to pull of convoluted inputs, you seem to always get points deducted, and the missions forces you to endure these issues at length. It's a shame, like I said, I really wanted to like this.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												A genre that isn't really thought of as a genre but is still one of the most immensely popular genres out there is what I call the 'open world crime game'. Saints Row 4 and GTA 5 were some of 2013s most anticipated games which shows how popular the genre is. Another classic genre is the old school fighting game. As in, fighting with fists not guns. Sleeping Dogs combines these two to form an absolutely amazing game. The story is fantastic, the combat is far more interesting than in games such as GTA or Saints Row, the city (Hong Kong) is really nicely detailed, and the driving is at least as good as that of those two games.In my opinion this is the best game of the 'open world crime' genre and is among my favourite games of all time.

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
												This game is an intense thrill ride following Wei Shen an undercover cop in Hong Kong who is inflitrating the Sun On Yee a Triad member gang. You must choose between the honor of your gang and your duty to the badge. A great plot with many shocks indeed. It is a very gruesome story that has some cringing moments.This is not like a GTA game you focus less on shoot everyone and drive away fast. You mainly use your martial arts skills to defeat foes while attempting to not put innocents in harms way. Driving recklessly will negatively affect your police skills and take away points. The game utilizes parkour in many ways such as combat, running missions, and exploration.The only real downside is that if you fail a check point your buffs just vanish and you must go through the city and get them again later. Also there were several instances of NPC clipping errors. In which during a cutscene an enemy would get stuck behind a door or circle their vechile endlessly meaning the cutscene would not end and I would have to restart from the checkpoint. Another instance is when you enter a shop and the keeper will randomly not be active for interaction, though when you walk away they are ready until you approach them again. The only way to cure that is to go around the block then try again.Overall it is a great game an open world that is not a shoot up everyone game.Also if you want to have some fun try leaving your car 1/2 in the garage then talk to the attendie your car will be damaged.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 14
												It all started with the Winter Sale of 2016.I bought Sleeping Dogs for 5 euros and did not expect too much because in other reviews it was called the chinese GTA. Instead of being a copy of GTA Sleeping Dogs can easily keep up with GTA 4 or even GTA 5.So, I want to give all of you a short overview of what I liked and disliked about this game.Positive:- The story was awesome. I just finished it with some of the sidequests and it took almost 30 hours. You play Wei Shen an undercover cop who moved from America to his hometown Hongkong. It is his job to infiltrate the Sun On Yee, a local gang, where he meets old friends and becomes part of their gang. Soon,he has inner conflicts whether being a good cop or being a gangster is the right decision.-  Being cop and gangster at the same time means to do jobs for both sides. So you have a huge variety of tasks. Chasing murderers, street races,drug deals and so on.- In the huge amount of sidequests you help friends, get to know girls and do delivery jobs for the gangster next door. Searching for collectible items, health upgrades and money can also give you an advantage in the main story.- The upgrade system gives you a lot of benefits. The better you do the missions, the faster you can upgrade your skills. This skills can help you in future missions.- Fighting in Sleeping Dogs is awesome but also challenging. Throughout the story it is possible to improve your move-set  which helps you fight stronger enemies and more enemies at the same time. - Sleeping Dogs has an awesome atmosphere. This may sound silly but Sleeping Dogs really creates an authentic atmosphere via graphics and music. Furthermore it has the perfect music for every taste. On the way to the missions via car, motorcycle or boat there are 7 or 8 different radio stations who make you enjoy the game even between the missions. (Chinese Instrumental, Chinese Rap Music, American Hiphop, Jazz, Rock and Metal, Classical Music and Pop Music; more than 100 songs)Negative:- There is no Multiplayer or DLCs for additional content. After finishing the story you feel kind of lost in this game.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs in many ways is just your average GTA clone. It does nothing much groundbreaking or new but manages to provide a decent open world experience that will entertain for as long as it should.You start of as Wei, an undercover police detective that's working his way into the power structure of a local triad. Of course he has a number of personal connections and vendettas that he is secretly trying to solve however the lack of choice often means you won't really get to care about his developing identity crisis.Unlike most games in this genre guns are fairly rare and you will only really use them in the missions that require it, the rest of the time you will be depending on your martial arts skills.Although the developers did quite a lot of talking up the fighting system in this game, even going as far as comparing it to the Arkham games, it doesn't quite meet that standard, you got your heavy attack and your light attack as well as a grapple and can use those in a variety of combos. Unfortunately Sleeping Dogs also takes a page from the first Assassins Creed game and gives you an end all counter button. You can win almost any fight by just standing still and countering the enemy attacks without much effort.The driving feels pretty good, not quite the cartoon style of Saints Row but not the annoying wannabe realistic style of later GTAIV either it manages to strike a nice balance where cars are still fun but it doesn't get too silly. For some bizarre reason though motorcycles have much greater road grip than even the best of cars.Instead of multi-player Sleeping Dogs have a social hub feature wherein you can compete with your friends for high scores on missions and races as well as a number of challenges but it is a feature easily forgotten or ignored.What separates Sleeping Dogs from the pack is the location. Instead of being situation in yet another differently named version of New York City the game takes place in Hong Kong and everything about the game, from the mini games to the radio stations and the street vendors create a different feel than we're used to in this sort of game. When was the last time you bet on cockfighting in a video game?Although the Hong Kong vibe manages to make Sleeping Dogs rise somewhat above the pack it is still a fairly unimpressive game underneath, not much new and not much improved over the many other games in the same genre out there now. Also it is much lighter on content than is normal for a game in this genre and 100% the game, achievements and DLC shouldn't take much more than 25-30 hours of game time.Still, it's a game I had quite a bit of fun with and the Hong Kong vibe was interesting to play around with, it's a pretty game despite originating on the consoles and although I would probably feel a little cheated if I had gotten it at it's original 50$ price tag with the current sales and discounts it's an enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												GTA Hong Kong. I believe this is the easiest way to sum up Sleeping Dogs. But it would also be incorrect as it gives you the impression that the game you are going to play will be exactly a GTA game but its setting will be a different city. That is why you should try Sleeping Dogs as it is so much more!Gameplay-wise it is exactly what the newer GTA games are: you have an open world game where you go wherever you want and you can do whatever you want. Of course, doing some hit-and-runs will only anger local police so they'll be after you pretty quickly. You can approach icons scattered throughout the game that launch missions - those that are essential to the main story progress are indicated by a different icon than those who serve to be side missions only.There are TONS of things to do in Hong Kong: you can participate in racing games, sing at karaoke parties, date girls, bet on cockfights, join a fight club. You also have hundreds of collectable items. It's worth participating in all these activities as the game rewards you with experience points that let you level up only to learn new abilities.In GTA you you had an assortment of firearms available for you to use. Here, emphasis is on hand-to-hand combat. Learning new abilities makes martials arts even better. Carjacking is also available but can happen much faster than in GTA - you can jump into vehicles and there are also car chase sequences in the game.Story-wise you play Wei Shen, an undercover cop, who climbs the criminal corporate ladder only to get closer to the bad guys he needs to expose. There are some nice surprises here and there and just like GTA this game can also steal around 40 to 50 hours from your life.A highly recommended game if you liked GTA IV or any of its third-person shooter predecessors.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												This is one of my favorite games for sure.  I love asian culture, so thats what got me interested.  This is an open-world game with racing, clothing stores, kareoke bars, fight clubs, apartments, and much more.  The music choice in the game is interesting.  There is a selection of cantonese and mandarin songs, but there are also songs from Killswitch Engage, Queen, Pat Benatar, Blood Red Shoes, Machine Head, Mozart, and plenty more.  Hand to hand combat just feels right.  Shooting an enemy may make you feel good about yourself, but there is nothing like a flying dragon kick to the face!  As you progress through the game you will learn more moves to use.  Fight clubs are a great place to try out all the moves you know, while taking on 1, 5, or even 10 enemies at once.  If that isn't enough, the story just makes it that much sweeter.  It is very easy to feel connected to characters in the game.  This is just a portion of what this game has to offer.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												If you're looking for something reminiscent of Grand Theft Auto but unique in its own right, look no further than Sleeping Dogs.  I was extremely pleased with this game.  I had expected a good time but what I ended up getting was far more bang for my buck than I had initially expected.Sleeping Dogs has gameplay similar to Grand Theft Auto in that it takes place in an open world city where you acquire missions from contacts to progress the story but you can generally do whatever your heart desires.  However, whereas Grand Theft Auto is very gunplay oriented, the majority of Sleeping Dogs' combat is melee in a way that reminds me of a kung fu action movie.  The combat is much deeper and more complex than I had anticipated (similar in a sense to the Arkham games) and the parkour movement was a nice surprise as well.  The story, I must say, is absolutely incredible.  It has its twists and turns as you play the role of an undercover police officer navigating both the criminal underworld and the police hierarchy of Hong Kong.  If I had to choose one of the aspects of that game that was the absolute best and most standout, I would go with the story.  I highly recommend this game to all fans of modern open world games, action games, and especially to anyone who's looking to scratch that Bruce Lee itch.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												From the developers who brought you ModNation Racers, a kart racing game that makes Mario Kart seem unsuitably violent for children, comes Sleeping Dogs; the brutal, ultraviolent action game you've always anticipated would rise up gallantly, to try to compete with the popular GTA franchise, only to fall short by an unsurprising stretch. Not to say it's not an entertaining game, Sleeping Dogs reaches certain standards, most of all when it comes to innovating the field of satisfying your homicidal urges. After all, its progressive skill system is based on 'Face points’ that are awarded accordingly by how creative you are on your quest: to reduce the bodies of your enemies to the least identifiable shape possible (the important thing to know about evidence is that it’s best if there is none). You get the option to use the vibrant urban environment to your advantage, being given difficult choices like whether to crush all the bones in your opponents’ bodies with easily accessible car engines, or the equally effective maneuver of putting them gently down in a trash container.The story is set in the metropolitan jungle of Hong Kong, and you have the privilege of following Wei Shen: the spiritual successor to every character Jackie Chan has ever played in films. He is an undercover cop and a master of martial arts before he even enrolls in the in-game martial arts class, and an unrelenting champion of doing the right thing. Like spending blood money on fancy clothes. Throughout Wei Shen’s journey, you will face difficult moral choices, encountering moments where you’ll have to decide whether a character or scene is merely stereotypical, inappropriately prejudice or straight up racist (for example: why it seems like every fighting individual seem to possess knowledge of, and skillfully demonstrates, advanced martial arts just because it’s set in Hong Kong).You will be taken on an adventure where, as a servant of the law, you will rise in the ranks of organized crime through vicious acts, lie to near everyone you come across, and enthusiastically murder almost every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ person that stands in your way, be it suspects, gang members or policemen, and still getting to keep your job as a cop. Oh, and you also get the option of using ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s posing as masseurs for in-game bonuses, tasteful! An excellent social commentary on how the modern execution of justice is flawed and better handled by a single, unstoppable psychopath, who also enjoys karaoke.Your toughest enemy throughout the game will be the agony of a typical, nightmarish PC port. You will be combating mortal enemies like painfully stiff controls and a swarm of bugs, along with strategically consistent game crashes to ultimately break your resolve. In addition, Square Enix’ support center seems to have lost all the passwords to all of their e-mails. A suitable challenge for only the most hardcore gamers, those who don’t really want to play at all. Final verdict: “it’s alright” out of 10.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Whoever came up with the title “Sleeping Dogs” must’ve had the biggest grin on their face when the name was approved. The game was originally pitched as a completely new IP, then rebranded as a reboot of the True Crime series, then pulled back into the series as True Crime: Hong Kong, and then canceled, only to be picked up by a different publisher for another rebranding and an actual release – the sleeping dog that nobody would let lie. Given that its initial announcement was in 2009, not to mention its ties to a less-than-revered franchise (does the True Crime name really move units?), it’s easy to understand why Sleeping Dogs simply isn’t showing up on many radars – we’re practically at a micro-Duke-Nukem-Forever at this stage. However, Sleeping Dogs shouldn’t be ignored. In fact, taking its rocky road to release into account, it’s an awesome surprise.Open-world crime games aping movies are nothing new, but Sleeping Dogs nails it better than practically any other. As undercover cop Wei Shen, players will dive deep into Hong Kong’s criminal underworld, assuming the role of a Sun On Yee soldier with the intent of climbing the gang’s hierarchy and crippling it from the inside. Wei Shen has a personal vendetta against the gang, but it’s not long until his hands are as dirty as the rest of them. His loyalties to both the police and the Sun On Yee will be tried and tried again over the course of the increasingly violent story.Does it sound corny? It is, and it’s frankly the game’s most interesting aspect. Plenty of video games attempt to place a conflicted main character at their core, criminals with hearts of gold who are just doing what they have to, waxing poetic about life and death in a maudlin cutscene before the actual gameplay starts, in which the player is far more likely to see how long they can drive on the sidewalk before getting shot than they are to sit and ponder deep questions about killing, honor and redemption. Sleeping Dogs does all of that, but it’s dressed up in the wonderful melodramatic styling of a classic Hong Kong crime film. Wei Shen is angry and unhinged, the Sun On Yee are violent and feudalistic, and the police are cold-hearted and shifty. The game’s script embraces cheese and contradiction, lampshading the disconnect between story and gameplay far better than most crime games with a serious tone. Sleeping Dogs isn’t a comedy or a satire, but it knows that it’s pulpy.The action movie influence seeps into the gameplay itself, too. Sleeping Dogs focuses mainly on hand-to-hand brawling, employing a combat system that feels like a less refined version of Arkham Asylum or The Warriors. There isn’t a prominent combo counter, but there are counter moves that can be triggered as soon as an enemy flashes red – a slightly jarring visual – and some truly brutal punch-kick strings activated by tapping or holding the attack button in certain orders. It’s slightly jerky and robotic feeling, mostly due to a lack of transition animations, but it can be very satisfying. More interesting are the throws and grabs that make use of environmental hazards, which usually involve Wei Shen shoving a goon’s head into something sharp or spinning (or both). All of these attacks are straight out of Hong Kong crime films, and they are all awesome. Heck, even when there aren’t any interesting objects around to push people into, Wei Shen can still sprint full-tilt towards the nearest wall and smash the person he’s holding into the hard surface head-first.Then there’s the driving, which feels very tight and arcade-y. Cars and bikes go incredibly fast and are almost all very nimble, save for a few trucks and mopeds. The streets of Hong Kong are lots of fun to speed through when you can turn on a dime, and car chases are pretty thrilling because of it. There are a few control issues once action-hijacking and shooting are introduced, though – even though the pace slows down time a tad to help you keep track of everything, it’s often very easy to jump onto the wrong car, or pile straight into a wall while trying to shoot something behind you. However, the fact that these are all things you can do is undeniably cool, and actually jumping onto the right car, clambering across the roof, and kicking the driver out of their seat is immensely satisfying.The third major section of the action is shooting, which mostly plays out like you’d expect. There are guns, there are chest-high-walls, dudes pop out and you shoot them. It’s definitely the least remarkable pillar of the game, although there are a couple of interesting mechanics that save it from being too dull – namely, the way the game encourages you to vault over cover at enemies, rather than sticking around in one spot shooting people as they peek over their hiding spot. Sleeping Dogs employs a heavy dose of slow-mo when you complete certain actions – leaping over cover, disarming a foe – which makes clearing large groups of enemies really easy. Thankfully, on-foot shooting missions are in the minority, although there are some straightforward run-and-gun sections towards the end of the game that can get pretty dull.If only the PC version let you assign separate keys for some actions, rather than using the obviously console-oriented “press-then-release-then-press-again-really-fast” setup – I imagine a lot of the control issues would be nonexistent. With a mouse and keyboard, some of Sleeping Dogs can be a bit of a headache. Sprinting and jumping over objects requires timed presses of the same sprint key – likewise, getting ready to jump out of your car and actually jumping out of your car are two actions tied to the same key, which just feels odd with all of the options available on a keyboard. Moving Wei around can feel a little stiff, as well – thankfully, the game supports controllers without a hitch. I’d strongly recommend a gamepad.The overall package of Sleeping Dogs is helped immensely by its presentation and atmosphere. While the character models and animation aren’t great, the Hong Kong they inhabit is gorgeous. There are moments where the game practically bleeds cool – rain-soaked streets, gaudy neon lights and the bright metropolitan skyline. The voice acting is appropriately over-the-top, and the character designs get more and more sleazy-looking as Wei makes his way up the Sun On Yee. There are some great missions, too, one-offs that feel like they belong in cult crime films. One sees you sneaking into a superstitious man’s house and messing with his furniture to screw up his feng shui. There are some truly horrifying revenge killings. You can also date Emma Stone.I wonder how Sleeping Dogs would have been if it had been released in 2010 as True Crime, or 2011 as True Crime: Hong Kong. The game is a tad unpolished as it is in 2012, so clearly there were reasons to push it back. However, if the game was as charming and interesting as it is now, I have no idea why anyone would cancel the project. Sleeping Dogs is a great action game with a compellingly melodramatic story and an atmosphere thick enough to cut with a knife. Control issues aside, it’s a great PC port, too – on a beefy gaming PC, Sleeping Dogs looks far better than its console counterparts. For fans of Hong Kong cinema and/or open-world games, it’s a must.My Rating: 8.7/10

content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
												This was the game that was to be True Crime Hong Kong.  As sandbox entertainment it's all over the map.  Many of the employed systems leave a lot to be desired.  As a story based brawler it's among the best I've played.  High production values.  Spectacular graphics, professional voice acting and fighting system that is somewhat simplistic yet makes you feel like Bruce Lee without having to memorize a multitude of button combinations.  The story can be summed up by the quotation; "Shoot for the moon. Even if you miss it you will land among the stars.".   It's not perfect but the entertainment value is high.  The setting is Hong Kong and the city is gloriously realized.  The story is solid with plenty of "moments" whose characters and writing couldn't of been done much better by Hollywood.   Play Sleeping Dogs.  You may not look at Chinese restaurants the same thereafter.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												If you were wondering if this was a GTA V knockoff like I was, it's not. It does follow the open world genre, but with a twist. Sleeping Dogs puts you in the role of an undercover police agent attempting to infiltrate the triad organization. The role involves taking missions involving from either the side of the police or the triads.Wei Shen is the main character in the story in which the player will control. Wei was born and raised in China but moved to America with his family. He has now returned to China as an undercover police agent infiltrating gangs. His role starts out quite easy getting initiated into the gang, but quickly heats up as a lot of his undercover work requires a lot of unethical decisions. Whether you are taking a police or triad mission, you will be docked points for causing any crimes or damages to anyone not involved. Meaning, if you cause damage to the environment (wreck-less driving or stealing cars), it will be noted into Wei's reputation. Speaking of reputation, Wei also has side missions available to increase his "face". Increasing the "face" stat will allow Wei to have more access to specialized cars. Face challenges require the player to fight gang's that can be found around the map.The overall gameplay of the game is between alright and good. The unique feature of this game certainly has to be the fighting that is involved. The game reminds me of the True Crimes series with it's fighting genre. Fighting can seem basic at first and upgrades can be added to Wei's Arsenal. There are a few types of upgrade trees to worry about : cop skill, triad skill, melee skill and face skill. You will not be given general upgrade points. Rather, the points will be given depending on which missions you take. It is important to note that if you would like to unlock certain fighting features that you will have to focus on specific areas. The fighting itself is not too bad. It is a nice addition as it makes it different from other open world games, but failed to optimize on the opportunity. There are grabbing capabilities on top of unlock-able combo's, but the player will find themselves mashing X then pressing Y quickly to counter another opponent. The flow of hitting enemies while doing counters is pretty cool to watch. That's sort of the issue though; it's more of a watching/button mashing gimmick for me than it is being creative with my fighting approach. I should highlight that the player can interact with the scenery while fighting and really do some serious damage to opponents by throwing them off railings, into vents or even into garbage cans. While the fighting is fun, it could have been a lot better.The exploring component of the game is pretty good. The environment (Hong Kong) in which the game takes place feels very nice. The conversations, radio stations, ambience and scenery really tie everything beautifully together. There are a lot of side missions to do be it fighting gangs to drug busts. Wei can hack security devices (such as cameras) and watch the city over his computer at home. These cameras are only accessible when Wei hacks into them (as they are not available by default). Small gimmicks like these do try to differentiate the game from other big open world brands. Other side missions include races, statue collection (to unlock new moves or points), and (not limited to) hit and runs. The driving itself is not the greatest but does have it's own unique system to itself. Not that it's entirely bad, but it will take some getting used to. Wei is able to stunt jump onto other cars as he is driving. Alternatively, the player may use the "X" button to initiate a ram maneuver. These actions definitely add depth to the game and  absolutely make it more dynamic. Paired with QTE (quick time events), it will keep you engaged.The visuals/graphics are quite stunning and can demand quite a bit from the PC. Besides the streets not being super crowded as I would imagine Hong-Kong, the map creators do a good job of creating an immersive atmosphere. The sounds are definitely remarkable as there will be conversations going on in Chinese and in English. The radio stations are very good and gives the player a new cultural insight into music. The cut-scenes are relevant and are well-received thanks to the passionate acting.Overall, the game is decent. It can definitely be a fan favorite for a few but speaking as a neutral reviewer, it is an average game. For the price it's been selling at, I would say it's certainly worth a buy on sale. The game has it's fair share of action, drama and story. I feel the actions could have been complimented with a little more to distinguish the game. For that reason I will be giving the game an average score.RATING : 7.0Gameplay B- Story / Campaign B- Visuals / User Interface B+ Sounds / Music B Replay-ability C+ Overall  B-ScreenShots :

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Probably one of the most underrated games of 2012, Sleeping Dogs brings to the table an unique experience. From the interesting story, to the refreshing Kung Fu combat, every single bit of it is really enjoyable, but as every other games, it has it shortcomings.Story & SettingSleeping Dogs is a third-person, open world, action game set in modern Hong Kong. The story revolves around Wei Shen, an undercover cop from San Francisco that left Hong Kong with his family when he was young, and his journey to infiltrate in Sun On Yee , a criminal organization who is both feared and respected. The main plot line is focused on Wei`s struggle between the two worlds, between what is right and what is wrong, between law or emotions. The second plot line is focused solely on his    work in Sun On Yee, where family and respect are the most important thigs, leading to some really intense moments. GameplayThe Gameplay is the best part of the game, and what you are gonna by doing most of the time. Inspired from Batman Arkham Asylum ,but with a twist of Kung Fu, the combat is one of the most enjoyable when it comes to Open World Action Games.The mechanics are simple : You have an attack button, a counter button, a run button and a grapple button. The basic combo consist in pressing the attack button a certain amount of times, and sometimes you have to hold it to increase the power of the attack. Also, you can combine the attack with either run or grapple in order to performa even more combos. But beware, most of those will have to be bought with statues that you find in missions from the dojo.You main defence will be the counter button. Just as in Batman, when an enemy is about to attack he will flash red. If you hit the button at the right time, you will stop the attack and initiate a counterattack. Of course this does not work on all enemies, some will have to be disarmed in order to be able to counterattackOf course, as in every action game, there are gonna be guns but they are very rare, and only certain missions will have it. The gunplay is cover-based, from which you can also blind fire or jump over in slow-motion. Some of the cover is destructible, but most of it is not. Be careful though, because the enemy will come after you if you don't kill them. When in a car chase, the gunplay consists either in shooting the bad guys or in shooting their tires, resulting in an awesome slowmo scene.The biggest flaw that the combat has is that it can become a little repetitive after a while.Graphics & SoundSleeping Dogs has THE best rainy scenes and the most detailed city I have ever seen in a game. The models are very nicely detailed and textured, the city is full of things hanging or flying. The detail put in this game is absolutely amazing. Even if you can't run it maxed out, you will be able to experience the beauty that this game has.As for the sound I have to say that it is very immersive. From Traditional Chinese music, to modern club music, to some metal the game provides something for everybody. The voice acting for every single character is top notch and very authentic.ConclusionSleeping Dogs is not a perfect game, not by any stretch of the imagination, but it IS a really good game which offers a great story and characters, but also a really good combat system that is very enjoyable to watch. It is an underrated game that deserve much more than it got.

												Sleeping Dogs is definitely one of the best gems on my steam account. The story is very cinematic and gripping. You follow Wei Shen who returns to Hong Kong as undercover cop to take out the triads. A bit of a cliche story line, but the animation, the characters' development and the output of the story are done really well. The only bits that were a bit weird were the scenes where Wei flirts with girls. He doesn't seem as smooth as Square Enix would have liked him to be, and instead comes across awkward and cheesy.Gameplay wise, it's a treat. Combat system is like Batman Arkham Asylum (which is always a good thing), nice shooting controls and free roaming world would definitely put many GTA games to second best. Yes, this game is a lot better than most GTA games, as it's not overly long or has many unnecessary missions as I've felt with some GTA games.Graphics are amazing, I put it on low because of my laptop power and I was still impressed.The DLC isn't a highlight, but if you can get it for cheap you might as well. But the main story is the gem. Get this game!8.75/10, would have been 9 or 10 if it wasn't for some bugs e.g. the radio playing the same song no matter which car you stole. Also the DLCs aren't amazing

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is easily one of the best open world crime sandboxes I've played in a long time. It is a nice blend of the later GTA's grittiness and realism, showing the deep dark underbelly of corruption and crime, while maintaining a slight sense of humor about it, a la Saint's Row.The gameplay isn't exactly that different from any other games of this genere, save for the combat. The melee combat (which you use a lot) is very fluid, making stringing together combos a very rewarding challenge. The somewhat limited gunplay (lampshaded in-game by saying that guns are rare in Hong Kong) is nothing to write home about, yet I still found myself enjoying the occasional gun battle.There are two things which got to me in this game: The story and the graphics. For a game two years old, the graphics blow me away, even on a medium-high setting. The story is the thing that had me hooked on the game the most. As a sufferer of gaming ADD, I found myself unable to pull away from the game!I highly recommend Sleeping Dogs, regardless of the price.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												I rather enjoyed my playthrough of Sleeping Dogs, a Hong Kong set entry into the open-world crime genre.  The story follows Wei Shen, an undercover cop, as he attempts to infiltrate and undermine the local Triads.  I found the story engaging and the various characters memorable, and while the plot doesn’t offer too much in the way of surprises for those familiar with organized crime and undercover police stories, it does tell its tale with panache and style.The undercover angle to the story also makes its way into the gameplay, encouraging you to balance violence and brutality to please the Triads with an adherence to law and order and minimized collateral damage to appease Wei’s police handlers.  It’s a great idea, but it really only comes into play during story missions.  Personally, I would have liked to see it expanded into other aspects of gameplay, especially the game’s side missions.Further differentiating Sleeping Dogs from its neighbors is a focus on brawling over gunplay, which given the setting and story seems quite appropriate.  The fighting mechanics are accessible and I enjoyed opportunities to thrash hordes of thugs with little more than fists and whatever was around at the time.Sleeping Dogs gets my thumbs up.  According to my Steam clock, I put about 25 hours into the game.  Time well spent, in my opinion.  My only caveat is that I found the game to play much better with a controller instead of mouse and keyboard, though that may be a matter of taste more than anything else.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												You play as Rover, the friendly and intelligent family dog. You are the biggest corgi the world has ever seen, and you must eat all the sausages in the kitchen, until you can fight no longer, and you become the Sleeping Dog. Really now, you play as a Jackie Chan double who is actually a sleeper agent (hence the name, hurr durr) and you want no trabble. You fight your way through several ladder factories while holding several different babies, in your fight against slightly bigger asian people that look like they're straight out of Fast and Furious. You go through several losses, in this trainless society, and sleep with many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, although it is wisely disguised as if you are getting a massage from a massage parlour. You go through several girlfriends, and lose none of the perks that came with them after you pump and dump through all of them, essentially leaving the world with several Jackie Chan babies. You also learn many secret hidden techniques by picking up some sort of Chinese takeout food, or something along those lines, I don't really recall because it was unmemorable, but that's besides the point. The game has you fighting in a very enticing combat system that allows you to have fun while you steamroll everybody as if you were a train. What this game lacks in trains, it makes up for in witty dialog, enticing story, and fun gameplay. The main character is likeable, and most of the game is played through his eyes where he's constantly at odds of being caught by the criminals he associates with. Overall, if you want a fun, and mindless beat 'em up game, with a karaoke minigame in it that frankly deserves its own review, you should get Sleeping Dogs, because who doesn't want to be an oversized corgi, fighting sausages in the kitchen?

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs was a great surprise! Yes, it is a GTA clone indeed, but it only takes the best aspects from Rockstar's games and then tries to add something new to it, like a good hand to hand combat system, a big selling point for this title. You play as an undercover cop with a dark past who infiltrates the dangerous Honk Kong triads, trying in the meantime to solve some intricate cases for the local police department.This dualism between the good and the bad sides of the main character is well used by the developers, missions are always interesting and fun to play, you want to go ahead and discover what happens next. Secondary missions are not bad either, even buying vechicles and clothes in order to obtain different bonuses is well implemented and not a mere filler.Sleeping Dogs is also very easy to play, a bit arcadey if you want, and with some small control glitches, but immediate to master. Technically I really liked the graphics (download the highres textures!) and the voices of the characters, very well interpreted. Honk Kong is a big city with its different districts, not so diversified as any other GTA, but interesting to explore nonetheless. The story is well narrated, nothing breathtaking but good enough to keep you playing for at least 20-30 hours. In the end I think I can suggest this game to any other GTA fan who wants something a bit different and fresh, while maintaining a well know gameplay infrastructure. If you don't already have Sleeping Dogs maybe this is the right moment to buy it, the Definitive Edition just went live with better graphics and all DLCs included!

to spoil anything but you should play the game to uncover all of the mysteries in the city.In GTA IV when you earnt money you couldn't really spend it on anything other than $1 hot dogs and paying the camera system, you can then go home and access that camera and after a while a new group of gang members will appear and you can then pick which one is making the drug deal and have them arrested.There arent that many flaws that I could pin-point, but i was a little disappointed that once you finish all of the main missions and side-missions there werent that many things to do, for example the races are tied into the side-missions so once you finish them they are gone and I thought if you could mabye use your phone to arrange a race that would have been a nice feature that would have made me play it even more.I would definately reccomend this game, the story is well done, the driving is good, combat is bloody amazing and it will keep you entertained for hours, lots to do content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Looking for a great story driven, immersive open world action RPG?  Look no further.Sleeping Dogs originally came out to little fanfare. It just sort of was THERE suddenly. I took a chance on it when I originally saw it, and it payed off. This is a good game.The game itself follows the exploits of Wei Shen, an undercover cop sent in to infiltrate and bring down the Triads in Hong Kong. And exploits indeed! You'll find yourself doing everything from making deliveries, to burning down rival gang warehouses, carting around women planning their weddings, singing karaoke, racing, and much, much more.The gameplay itself is great, everything flows smooth, and looks good. If you're familiar with Grand Theft Auto, you'll probably feel right at home here, with a few exceptions.One of those exceptions is the combat system. In most open world games there's very little melee. Usually a punch or a kick and that's about it. In SD, there's a fully features fighting system that's like a cross between Soul Calibre and Die Hard Arcade. It's fun, though it can be challenging. I found myself rather enjoying when fights came my way.There's also a shooting aspect, which isn't particularly impressive, though quite functional.There's also more parkour bits than in games like GTA. You'll find yourself running after suspects (or running away from them) at several points in the game, over rooftops and through back alley markets.The graphics, as I mentioned, are quite good. The game is a few years old now and even without the high-res textures, Hong Kong has rarely looked more immersive. Tall buildings, bright lights, weather effects, you name it. It's all very convincing.There are a few things to be cautioned about though. The game is VERY bloody, and there's a TON of language. It's not really surprising, given the subject matter, but the squeemish may want to hold off. Just in fights alone you can slash people with knives and cleavers, break arms and legs, slam faces into ventilations fans, and use a number of other environmental objects to deliver what are very clearly death-blows to your enemies. The majority of which are shown. There's also some even more grisly things which are more implied than shown.The language would be a definite R rating as well. The characters in the Triad drop F bombs like they're going out of style.The game lacks multiplayer, though it does allow you to compare scores and records with your friends. Silly things like longest wheelie, highest number of hit and runs in a row, largest amount of money collected from parking meters, etc are all counted, and the game will show you who of your friends has the highest record for you to beat, while you're doing it; so you have a reference.The story itself is more or less linear, but solid. You do develop attachments to the characters and what happens around them. I would say it stands up a bit better than the GTAV story. The ending though did feel a little bit rushed. (I'll avoid any spoilers) Most all the writing and dialogue is pretty good, though the romance parts of the game fell pretty flat.(I got yelled at by a girl for "cheating on her" with a girl I met all of one time, and I didn't even know I was supposedly dating the first girl.)TLDR/All in all, Sleeping Dogs is a fantastic game. It has some flaws but most of them are small and easy to ignore. It's definitely in my list of all-time great games. I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs provides players with an engrossing narrative set to the atmospheric and richly-detailed backdrop of Hong Kong. An extensive array of additional missions and activities ensure there are always opportunities for further adventure and action to discover while roaming the streets. Along with an impressive presentation for both the visuals and music, Sleeping Dogs is without doubt the sleeper hit of 2012 for open world action games.Square Enix and United Front Games pulled Sleeping Dogs from the brink of death, and what surprised me is just how good it turned out to be.Unlike the previous ‘True Crime’ games, where there was a strict depiction of the city maps, Sleeping Dogs does not portray Hong Kong, inch by inch. United Front Games has implemented GTA’s novelties in way that winks slyly at Rockstar. In essence, what the GTA series has accomplished, Sleeping Dogs has carried out better and more elegantly.This game is a very pleasant surprise that's throwing down the gauntlet to GTA V with its Cantonese oral insult. The game's story along with plenty of gaming mechanics' innovation make Sleeping Dogs a truly remarkable and never-ending joyride with no intention to imitate the original at all costs.Sleeping Dogs is now the example developers should strive to beat when they want to create a game in this genre, because Square Enix's title is now the new leader of the pack.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is a great game and has a lot going for it. First of is the graphics. The game looks amazing on pc if you download the free HD texture pack. All the settings you would expect to bee in a pc game is there, and im glad to see a publisher that actually give us the full experience thats possible with a pc. The gameplay is no less then amazing. With the focus being on hand to hand combat, and using the environment to your advantage in spectacularly violent finishing moves, makes the fighting exciting and action packed. The guns are nothing special, the fun is found in the martial art style moves you can pull off. The combos aren't hard to pull off, but still give you that satisfying feeling when you do them. you learn more advanced and damaging moves as you progress through the game, and the pacing feels right. The story of this game is actually really solid. When i bought this game I expected a mediocre story at best, but when I got when i started playing, i found my self sucked in. I played the whole main story doing every mission back to back, which is really rare for me. The characters are well developed and the missions where really varied, and there was no feeling of doing repetitive tasks. The world it self looks gorgeous. I love the setting, and the city feels vibrant and alive. You can pretty much go anywhere you like, and there is a lot of little minigames, like participate in illegal fighting tournaments to win cash, collecting the jade-statues for new combos, hacking securety cameras and much more.The only downside to this game is that the best experience requires a controller. If you have one, this game is a no-brainer.The overall experience is great. I would reccomend this game at full price to pople who enjoy openworld ''GTA-Like'' games, and at a discount this is a must have for pretty much anyone.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Looking for a great story driven, immersive open world action RPG?  Look no further.Sleeping Dogs originally came out to little fanfare. It just sort of was THERE suddenly. I took a chance on it when I originally saw it, and it payed off. This is a good game.The game itself follows the exploits of Wei Shen, an undercover cop sent in to infiltrate and bring down the Triads in Hong Kong. And exploits indeed! You'll find yourself doing everything from making deliveries, to burning down rival gang warehouses, carting around women planning their weddings, singing karaoke, racing, and much, much more.The gameplay itself is great, everything flows smooth, and looks good. If you're familiar with Grand Theft Auto, you'll probably feel right at home here, with a few exceptions.One of those exceptions is the combat system. In most open world games there's very little melee. Usually a punch or a kick and that's about it. In SD, there's a fully features fighting system that's like a cross between Soul Calibre and Die Hard Arcade. It's fun, though it can be challenging. I found myself rather enjoying when fights came my way.There's also a shooting aspect, which isn't particularly impressive, though quite functional.There's also more parkour bits than in games like GTA. You'll find yourself running after suspects (or running away from them) at several points in the game, over rooftops and through back alley markets.The graphics, as I mentioned, are quite good. The game is a few years old now and even without the high-res textures, Hong Kong has rarely looked more immersive. Tall buildings, bright lights, weather effects, you name it. It's all very convincing.There are a few things to be cautioned about though. The game is VERY bloody, and there's a TON of language. It's not really surprising, given the subject matter, but the squeemish may want to hold off. Just in fights alone you can slash people with knives and cleavers, break arms and legs, slam faces into ventilations fans, and use a number of other environmental objects to deliver what are very clearly death-blows to your enemies. The majority of which are shown. There's also some even more grisly things which are more implied than shown.The language would be a definite R rating as well. The characters in the Triad drop F bombs like they're going out of style.The game lacks multiplayer, though it does allow you to compare scores and records with your friends. Silly things like longest wheelie, highest number of hit and runs in a row, largest amount of money collected from parking meters, etc are all counted, and the game will show you who of your friends has the highest record for you to beat, while you're doing it; so you have a reference.The story itself is more or less linear, but solid. You do develop attachments to the characters and what happens around them. I would say it stands up a bit better than the GTAV story. The ending though did feel a little bit rushed. (I'll avoid any spoilers) Most all the writing and dialogue is pretty good, though the romance parts of the game fell pretty flat.(I got yelled at by a girl for "cheating on her" with a girl I met all of one time, and I didn't even know I was supposedly dating the first girl.)TLDR/All in all, Sleeping Dogs is a fantastic game. It has some flaws but most of them are small and easy to ignore. It's definitely in my list of all-time great games. I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is a great game and has a lot going for it. First of is the graphics. The game looks amazing on pc if you download the free HD texture pack. All the settings you would expect to bee in a pc game is there, and im glad to see a publisher that actually give us the full experience thats possible with a pc. The gameplay is no less then amazing. With the focus being on hand to hand combat, and using the environment to your advantage in spectacularly violent finishing moves, makes the fighting exciting and action packed. The guns are nothing special, the fun is found in the martial art style moves you can pull off. The combos aren't hard to pull off, but still give you that satisfying feeling when you do them. you learn more advanced and damaging moves as you progress through the game, and the pacing feels right. The story of this game is actually really solid. When i bought this game I expected a mediocre story at best, but when I got when i started playing, i found my self sucked in. I played the whole main story doing every mission back to back, which is really rare for me. The characters are well developed and the missions where really varied, and there was no feeling of doing repetitive tasks. The world it self looks gorgeous. I love the setting, and the city feels vibrant and alive. You can pretty much go anywhere you like, and there is a lot of little minigames, like participate in illegal fighting tournaments to win cash, collecting the jade-statues for new combos, hacking securety cameras and much more.The only downside to this game is that the best experience requires a controller. If you have one, this game is a no-brainer.The overall experience is great. I would reccomend this game at full price to pople who enjoy openworld ''GTA-Like'' games, and at a discount this is a must have for pretty much anyone.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs provides players with an engrossing narrative set to the atmospheric and richly-detailed backdrop of Hong Kong. An extensive array of additional missions and activities ensure there are always opportunities for further adventure and action to discover while roaming the streets. Along with an impressive presentation for both the visuals and music, Sleeping Dogs is without doubt the sleeper hit of 2012 for open world action games.Square Enix and United Front Games pulled Sleeping Dogs from the brink of death, and what surprised me is just how good it turned out to be.Unlike the previous ‘True Crime’ games, where there was a strict depiction of the city maps, Sleeping Dogs does not portray Hong Kong, inch by inch. United Front Games has implemented GTA’s novelties in way that winks slyly at Rockstar. In essence, what the GTA series has accomplished, Sleeping Dogs has carried out better and more elegantly.This game is a very pleasant surprise that's throwing down the gauntlet to GTA V with its Cantonese oral insult. The game's story along with plenty of gaming mechanics' innovation make Sleeping Dogs a truly remarkable and never-ending joyride with no intention to imitate the original at all costs.Sleeping Dogs is now the example developers should strive to beat when they want to create a game in this genre, because Square Enix's title is now the new leader of the pack.

												Sleeping Dogs is a really good game. It was hyped a lot for me by many people and I have only recently decided to play it. I honestly felt a little underwhelmed at first (after playing a lot of GTA V before this game), but after I got stuck in I had a lot of fun. The game made me smile so many times, from it's action movie combat to it's clever humor and dialogue. The story is amazing and really stands out compared to other games of a similar style. The game focuses primarily on melee combat and using the environment, but when guns are used they are great fun too especially with slow mo. I thought the voice acting was fantastic and the characters were generally really well done.Id highly recommend giving Sleeping Dogs a go if you enjoy open world games with a good story.

Posted: January 13
												Trust me when I say to get this version over the Definitive Edition (you can still get this version from GMG and other places).The reason? This version runs so much better than the DE. Everything is really smooth and there are no framerate drops. If you get the DE, you'll get weird and random framerate drops even if you have a great rig! Now, you might say that the DE has better graphics. Not necessarily so. If you buy this version and install the free HD texture pack that's included, I PROMISE you won't notice any graphical differences between this and the DE.As far as the game itself goes, it's fantastic and you'll have a hell of a lot of fun. Yeah, GTA V is what the cool kids are playing nowadays but you'll be sorely missing out on a great experience if you overlook this game. Personally, I like this MORE than GTA V. They're both great games but I had more fun with this one.So whether you buy this version or the DE (though I advise against not getting the DE), you're in for a ton of fun!Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2012
												This game right here may be the game of the year for me. Sleeping Dogs takes the best of the openworld undercover genre and shakes it up with its own style. Instead of run and gunning like GTA or DEM SAINTS you'll be focusing on hand to hand combat throughout much of the game. Alot more guns do eventually come into play when things get a bit crazier and serious and I'm glad that they worked it out that way as it really adds to the feel that triad war is heating up. The story is actually really well done, cutscenes are pretty and the voiceacting is fantastic. Most importantly though they build up characters just right so that you can empathize with them (with the exception of one VERY forced character that you spend the day driving around). You never feel overwhelmed with stuff like in GTA and the story tension keeps you going for completion of main missions. There are a ton of clothes to collect, so you can look stylin' while you do your thing. The game killed someone I liked so 9.9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Hmm... where do I start with this game? Well for starters, this overlooked title is frequently compared to the GTA franchise. So what does this game have to offer?What I like about this game:- The setting of Hong Kong, loosely based off of the real Hong Kong that is...- The hand-to-hand combat with interactivity of the environment to even the odds a bit (and because it looks fancy).- The story following an undercover police officer.- The protagonist Wei Shen and the characters he interacts with.- The colorful environment making Hong Kong feel active (especially the night market)Stuff that gave me mixed feelings or have no opinion on:- The AI: sometimes their behavior get pretty wonky at times, but nothing majorly broken with them- The side activities: they're okay if not a little underwhelming since there isn't a lot of stuff to do aside from side quests. For me, the two gambling activities are kind of a waste of your time unless you want a method to toss your money away more quickly.- Environmental glitches: I encountered about one or two bugs, with one of them involving a wire attached to a security camera floating in the middle of a parking lot, but nothing major.- The protagonist Wei Shen never speaking a single word in Cantonese (he said one word in Cantonese in the wheels of fury dlc, much to my suprise). Honestly it confuses me a little bit, but that's just a minor complaint. I'm just going to assume he just has a preference to strictly speaking english anyway.- Guns: yes, yes, nothing's fun without gunplay, but obtaining guns is a little different than what you would expect from GTA. While gunplay is pretty fun, there is no way of purchasing firearms or ammunition so the only way you can get them outside of story missions (and occasionally DLC) is to do it the hard way: steal them from the HKPD. Completing the story will get you a golden Desert Eagle for you to use.- The map size: a bit small for an open world game, but it's tolerable.- The mini map: most of the time, directions for way points work, but there was one area that partially breaks the GPS and tells you to go around in circles until you disobey it.What I didn't like:- The ending: It didn't bother me too much, but I kinda wish you could become a member of the Triads full-time or stay loyal to the Hong Kong Police Department.- The DLC: personally I think most of them don't really offer much, but I think a few of them are probably worth purchasing, especially if they're on sale.- The second to last story mission: specifically it is the quick-time event on the scaffolding where button mashing is required. The reason why I hate that sequence is because there is a programing error that if you rapidly button mash, you will fail regardless of how fast you press the spacebar. How to get past it is to find a steady rhythm and keep the rhythm for about 20 - 30 seconds. (Note that it took me 10 minutes to figure out what was going on and go to the forums to look for help. I know, it's really sad to admit that it took me that long for me to figure it out)- Animation quality: they didn't put a lot of effort into animation outside of the official cutscenes. They put effort into lip-syncing and movement in the cutscenes, but didn't even try to put any effort outside of that, althought when it comes to movement like walking and running, they are just fine. (I should note that they "semi-locked" the camera to make sure you don't see Wei's face, and when you do see it, it's very obvious they didn't even bother)- Camera angles: my main pet peev comes from driving when you want to go reverse, the camera automatically rotates around the car and I'd rather do it manually because it feels really disorienting to have the game do it for me.What will kick most people in the teeth:- The lack of a multiplayer: the game has a social hub for you to compare scores with your friends, but some people like me will not care about numbers and might be upset that there is no physical multiplayer to play with your friends.Despite my complaints, this game has plenty to offer and is definitely worth the current price tag and deserves more attention that it currently has.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Sleeping Dogs is an outstanding game that takes the open world elements from Grand Theft Auto and combine it with the melee combat system from the Batman Arkham games and you have a game that has a gorgeous world and satisfying combat. The game takes place in Hong Kong and the world is full of realistic details; just walking around you hear everyone speaking in Cantonese and the radio is filled with Cantonese songs. The streets are littered with stores and vendors trying to get you to purchase something; the world is full of these little details which makes the game feel alive. The combat and open world driving is very satisfying and fun. The real highlight of the game is the story, where you are an undercover cop moving up the ranks in the Triad. The story missions are all varied and are full of twists and turns. Overall, the game takes about 40 hours to completely 100% the main game and to finish the 3 large DLCs and the various small DLCs which add some additional missions/content. There are tons of collectibles to find and lots of areas to explore, so if you're a fan of open world games this is a must play with an awesome story and amazing martial arts combat. By the way, check out who voices the characters in the game, you will be surprised to see how many famous actors/actresses are in this game!

												This game is awesome. The storyline is incredibly gripping and causes the player to really feel some feelz. I also want to make a comment on the quality of the AIs: I could predict who was going to do what in the fights because they behaved like actual humans. Anyways, thanks for reading this exteremely long review (assuming that any of you have :/) and to the developer I say keep up the great work! :D

Posted: April 26, 2014
												Open world grand theft auto kung fu madness - The only way I can explain this game in some simple words that all would understand.Okay.The graphics are fairly decent with not amazing but certainly not bad but really good to look at.The controls are really easy to get used too, even hoping from car to car is so easy you cannot complain.The sound seems like a silly cheap movie rip off I found which is amusing but becomes boring after a while, and I went around playing with no sound listening to music.The game itself is good fun with a small world but you learn to push past that when you notice you do a few decent stuff in the world, and the DLC in the game is really nice too.The story I did not play and complete because I was not impressed that much.  It was go here beat this person, go here catch this person, go chase this person, repeat, repeat, repeat and I was bored after only 11hours in this game.  I am sure the story contains some amazing moments but it did not grab me quick enough to keep me entertained.I did pay £29.99 for this game as a preorder and now the game is £14.99 (Now on sale as we speak for £2.99 which is a STEAL) and the £14.99 is really cheap as it is because of what the game offers.If you like open world, stealing cars, beating people, kung fu fighting, just cause leaping from cars, then this game will keep you going for way longer than myself.You really nice feature in the game was the car control.  The sounds on the cars, and the way it dips and dives when turning, specially the bikes was sooooo nice.  Anyway, this game is worth the time and money you want to put into it.Shame there was no multiplayer and only singleplayer but still. Good fun.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												It's not everyone's type of game. There's no multiplayer and to be honest you'd be better off playing it with an xbox 360 controller or similar controller with the emulator mod (ask if you need the link). I've met and have heard from others in the forums that using keyboard and mouse, you eventually get used to it and the only difficulty is in the driving. I actually used both, shooting with keyboard/mouse and fighting and driving the xbox controller. Regardless of price (I did buy it discounted through some key re-seller friends, but it wasn't at this price nor were the dlc I got with it) I totally enjoyed this great game. It's like every John Woo film and a lot of Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan films put into story mode. There's even a dlc called Zodiac Tornament that is pretty much the movie Enter the Dragon where you go to an island tournament with all the different stlyed fighters and of course have to beat the evil organiser of the tournament, classic Hong Kong movie stuff to be had all round.Story wise, you are an ex Triad gang member gone to the States and returns to Hong Kong assigned the task of getting into a gang that you have ties to from your youth and a score to settle with one of the leaders of another faction of the Triad gang Sun On Yee. You have to deal with all the politics and oblivious Police dept. issues as well as the gut wrenching ethical dilemas of being a cop posing as gangster to people you eventually end up respecting and caring for as almost family.If you are time poor and just want to experience the story and action unabated you can get this game complete with all the upgrades and rip through the game almost too quickly but have all the bling and weapons at the game start. Remember though a lot of the unlocks are earnt through the game progress, not all but a lot are and it's usually stated on the dlc page itself if that's the case so have a look before you buy and save some cash if you need to.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2013
												Coming into this game, I expected a mediocre GTA clone set in Hong Kong. Now, having played about 12 hours or 30% of the whole game, I feel that I like this more than I liked Dishonored.The story is the best I've seen for any open-world action/crime game. Wei Shen is an undercover cop who is tasked with taking down the Triads of Hong Kong from within, attempting to balance loyalty to the law and playing the part of a gang member. As the story progresses, you get to know more about certain characters that would be considered the "bad guys" and morality in this game is no longer black and white. Having not finished it yet, it will be interesting to see whether Wei forsakes his duty as a cop or brings down the house on the criminals.The game has an immense focus on melee combat and it plays almost identical to Arkham Asylum, but it doesn't straight out copy it. You level up your combos and abilities which was soemthing Arkham didn't really focus on. You can also grapple enemies and unleash "environmental kills" and use an air conditioner as a blender for some guy's head. You can use butcher knives, tire irons, and a few other melee weapons to kill, but after 10 strikes the weapons "break", so when you actually find one, you know that you'll need to still rely on your fists. As for guns, they are rare and powerful. VERY rare. I had to wait maybe 3 hours to get my hands on a pistol. However, though they are few and far between, the gunfights are most enjoyable. Cars play a big role in the game, and the driving is superb, though not perfect. The ramming mechanic is unrealistic but fun and certain vehicles (any truck) feels clunky. Also, there is no inventory system. You can not sheathe weapons or carry multiple guns. Typically, you can never take a weapon into free-roam from a mission, which reminds me: The game never gets tedious. The missions are plentiful and enjoyable, though some (like the Drug Busts) have the exact same structure (though a different environment) and tend to get a little repetetive, but not boring.The graphics are amazing and I never thought I'd say it, but China is beautiful. The high-resolution texture pack is not that better than the base game, but it's better nonetheless. One thing I don't like, is that on Extreme Anti-Aliasing, the game hovers at about 30 frames per second, but on Ultra AA, the game hovers at 90. LOL WUT?All in all, this game is fabulous. I don't understand why it wasn't hyped up or ranked up with games like Dishonored, Borderlands, and Far Cry 3. This truly was the most underrated title of 2012, and it closely ties with Dishonored for my game of the year.9.5 out of 10

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												An excellent entry by Square Enix into the third-person crime genre, alongside more celebrated titles such as Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row. The game revolves around a well-written plot involving the player as an undercover Hong Kong police officer returned from America who has been tasked with infiltrating the local triads to shut them down. An fantastic cast featuring some very distinctive and memorable characters who you grow to sympathise with and love or hate regardless of their faction complements a twisting, turning, and storyline, with an explosive conclusion.While many games which do not focus on driving have driving issues, the driving in Sleeping Dogs is quite smooth, regardless of the vehicle you may be driving, whether it be a car, van, or motorcycle. This is complemented by the damage you can do in vehicles, and also by the incredibly fun ability to enter moving enemy vehicles... provided you don't fall off, of course!An incredibly fun open world experience based on the city of Hong Kong, the lack of air vehicles does not actually limit the game, with the ability to get to various places, even some quite high, on foot. The map and city is well-designed, and the game's ability to mix things up with extra side material such as catching criminals, hacking cameras, cracking locks, and singing karaoke only increases the game's allure.And then, finally. The combat. Despite the ability to slow time, and move over, to and around cover while shooting is quite nice, it is in close quarters hand-to-hand combat that the game shines. With the ability to pick up various items and wield them as weapons, from cleavers to handbags to fish, you can be sure that a fistfight will turn bloody and conclude quite brutally. The visceral nature of hand-to-hand combat is furthered by the implementation of "environmental hazards" - objects or locations in the world which you can use to finish off your enemies. Incredibly enjoyable and interesting, if very violent, the close combat in this game is truly a standout feature.
