content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs is a really good game if you enjoy titles similar to Grand Theft Auto or Saints Row.  The game is very nice to look at especially after you install the high resolution texture pack.  The setting is also very interesting.  The only thing that keeps it from being a definite "must buy" are its numerous inexplainable glitches.  Sometimes things have just "stopped working right".  For instance, at one point I was using my cell phone in-game and was unable to dismiss it from my hand.  I had to exit to the main menu and reload the game.  When I did this the phone was still in my hand, but I was able to put it away.  Just oddball stuff like this happens from time to time.  The driving in the game is not very interesting and makes the races more of a pain than actual fun.  Other than that it is very entertaining.  The fighting in the game is a blast.  It is nice to see a game going more for martial arts than blasting everything around you with a gun or tank.  It is a good game but, as I said, the glitches and driving mechanics keep it from being a classic.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												TL;DR- 8/10, fun game despite a few flaws.I've heard this game reffered to as "a poor man's Grand Theft Auto". And while the moniker may come across as derogatory, I can't disagree. Certain aspects of Sleeping Dogs draw from open world titans like GTA, but it still manages to stand tall of its own merits, rather than on the coattails of GTA.The pros are that it is a legitimately fun game to play. The story was interesting enough to keep me engaged and wanting to dig deeper, combat handled pretty well and was easy to learn, and a lot of the special actions you can perform, such as mid-driving carjacking, are pretty fun to pull off. The dual experience system is implemented fairly well, rewarding you for wreaking as much havok as you can upon your enemies, while punishing you for hurting, killing or destroying anything not related to your mission. Environmental hazards give combat a little more pep, allowing you to seriously injure, if not outright slaughter (sometimes quite brutally) anyone standing in your way.The cons are that there isn't a terrible lot to do outside of the story quests, and what little there is to do becomes repetative and tedious with no meaningful reward. Some of the dialogue and situations/resolutions you come across can be pretty tongue-in-cheek if not outright absurd and cheesy, and felt detractive towards the overall tone and feel of the game. Combat, while easy to learn and diverse in what movesets you can punish your enemies with, ultimately boils down only attacking, grabbing or counters, and doesn't encourage making use of the many skills you can learn except for the sake of doing something flashy. NPCs will sometimes get stuck on terrain or on corners, making some missions impossible to complete without a restart.But the two biggest offenders in this game for me, are the vehicle camera controls, and the option to purchase a number of game breaking features from the start through DLC content. The vehicle camera controls can be frustrating at best and damning at worst. It tends to lock itself in whatever position you move it to relative to your vehicle, and doesn't transition back to the forward position when you begin driving unless you move it back yourself, making multi-point turns and complex driving maneuvers aggrivating.The DLC content almost broke the game for me at the start. I'll admit I grabbed the whole shabang without reading about it all when it was on sale, and I wish I had. After the first couple missions, I suddenly found myself awash in an inordinate amount of Cop and Triad XP, Face XP, money, vehicles and items.. enough so that what was supposed to be earned throughout the course of the game was instantly given to me at the start, making personal progression almost non-existant. If that's your sort of thing, then by all means. Otherwise be wary of what DLC you purchase.Despite the cons and my own complaints about the game however, I'm left feeling quite positive about the overall experience. It's no GTA for sure, but I do think it's worth a look and a playthrough.8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I felt compelled to write a review for Sleeping Dogs, as it is a game that gave me more bang for my buck than most ever have.  I'm a huge fan of open-world games with driving (GTA, Saints Row, Far Cry).  With that said, I 100%'d Sleeping Dogs at about 30 hours in, and my current playtime is now nearing the 118 mark.  I can count the number of games I've 100%'d on less than two hands.  So, I think the important question is, why do I still keep playing?  What caused me to learn this game inside and out, to the point where I know all the mechanics, glitches, and how to mess with every piece of AI?The answer lies in that to me, Sleeping Dogs is just pure fun.  The melee combat is something that almost no other game has done as well, and really the only one that comes to mind is the Arkham series.  Even with Arkham, I find the combat takes too long, whereas in Sleeping Dogs it gets things just right.  It's visceral while remaining simple.  Enemies react in momentary fear to bone-crushing martial arts moves, and the protagonist Wei Shen can masterfully counter and take out hordes of gangsters.  Wei also moves around Hong Kong with basic parkour moves, as he can survive falls of impressive heights and slide over all manner of objects smoothly, if timed right.The other aspect is driving.  Let me preface this section with two things: one, that I vastly prefer arcade style driving (if I want real driving, I'll go take my real car out), and two, the weapon-based DLC car singlehandedly has given me hours upon hours of extra time with the game.  I'll put this bluntly; if you want realistic driving, go play another game.  Ramming cars at high speeds, tearing through the Financial District with a nearly indestructible bus, and blowing out the tires that sends cars flying like a Hollywood movie... all of its is insanely fun.  Add in the DLC car that pretty much breaks the game, and it just gets hilarious how awesomely you can dominate Hong Kong.Sleeping Dogs is far from perfect, however.  Some of the things the game does are laughably bad, like how the police are handled.  I'm not going to mince words here, the police are just terrible.  They're so bad that they're funny, like with how awful horror movies work.  The biggest issue I have is that they literally pop into an area.  You could be in a desolate alley and shoot someone, or beat up a bunch of people in a quiet street with no police anywhere nearby.. and they will literally pop in like they used a portal gun or stepped through a dimensional rift.  If they weren't so easy to shake off and mess with, this would have ruined any sense of immersion the game had.While I thoroughly enjoyed the story with a satisfying ending, which took me about 15-20 hours with exploration and side missions, you could tell that in some sections, the developers did not have the time to implement other features they wanted.  It's pretty obvious that they wanted to include deeper connections to Hong Kong with Wei with how much exploration and collection there were, along with Wei's serial hit-it-and-quit-it attitude with women.  Wei's struggle with his identity and corruption, both in the Triads and the police force, was a compelling reason for me to finish the story, however.Finally, don't let the DLC scare you.  The DLC mostly adds things in to make the game a little more fun, and none of it is necessary whatsoever.  I know some people who wouldn't sneeze at Sleeping Dogs for the amount of DLC it has, but I doubt they ever actually took a look at what it does.  I really believe that Sleeping Dogs is a game that every fan of this genre should play.  Hong Kong's a relatively fresh setting from similar games, and Sleeping Dogs finds its identity in mechanics that are just fun.  Not crazy whacked up purple♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bat fun like Saints Row, and not maniacal, realistic Trevor fun as in GTA, but just super tight, simple, attractive combat with good pacing and a pretty beautiful world.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												This one is in a similar category to Spec Ops for me. It's a game with AAA production values but a lower level of marketing and sales, which is unfortunate. To me this is pretty clearly a better open world game than GTA4, though the sandbox seems smaller and therefore the game shorter. It's been quite a while since I've played GTA4, so that may not be correct. With that exception, Sleeping Dogs does everything better than GTA4. The graphics are better, the driving is better, the combat is better (though my personal preference would be to have more gunfights and less fist fights), the hidden objects are handled better, etc. I enjoyed the story as well, though it was somewhat predictable. However, had it not been, it wouldn't have been as satisfying as there weren't a lot of ways the loose ends could have been wrapped up. Hopefully Rockstar "borrows" some of the gameplay elements for GTAV, though that would have had to be in development before this game was released. Square-Enix should do all PC ports, because they get them right, down to the high resolution texture pack, Steamworks, video options, etc. Thank goodness they saved this game from cancellation.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Rating: 10/10Story review: Realistic, breath-taking view of Hong Kong mirrored into the game creates an excellent open-world experience that is yet to be chalenged by the likes of GTA.The choreographed fighting, acting, driving and cut scenes are above average, showcasing what is possible when developers take game mechanics seriously and invest in it. The game has a short learning path, even for new comers. You'll get thrown right into action from the first scene, and the nostalgic storyline will keep begging you for a repeat of the story once you're done. Visuals and system requirements: The visuals are stellar, and you will not need to break a bank to build a rig that can play this game. Simply put, if you can play Tomb Raider on Medium settings with DirectX11 features turned on, you'll blaze through this game without breaking a sweat.Stereoscopic 3D via AMD HD3D works out of the box if you have an AMD HD 5000+ GPU connected to a 3D capable monitor via HDMI 1.4a. Depending on your setup, you may need a 3D driver such as Tridef 3D to play it in 3D mode.Personally, I had a blast playing the game and would recommend it highly.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												In Sleeping Dogs you're playing as Wei Shen, an undercover police whose job is to infiltrate the rank of triads and at the same time operate as informant to police in Hong Kong. Through the game you will find a lot of missions and side missions to hone your skill as martial artist and gunslinger. Some people said sleeping dogs are just imitation to GTA and True Crime. Well, i disagree with them. In my opinion sleeping dogs have something that surpasses them.A lot of features in sleeping dogs compelled me to said so.. for example :Combat AspectGTA and True Crime doesn't have martial arts to confront their enemies, in Sleeping Dogs you have martial arts as your friend. As Wei Shen, you can learn to do complex moves at dojo. Learn to fight against various enemies, countering attacks from them. You even have a environment to support you while in combat! You can impale enemies to meat hook, dump them in trash bin, smash them to aquarium, and many more.Car HijackWei Shen have ability to hijack car while driving a car without a need to stop first. In a world where you need to be fast to chase down enemies on the road, this would come handy. GTA should adopt this mechanism for their future release.ParkourIn sleeping dogs, chasing criminals is one of the most interesting features of the game. Hongkong are well known as crowded city with a lot of market and cramped building, with parkour you will be able to jump over obstacles and climb over the wall easily while chasing targets.Basically these features are only a few of many best thing in the game. If you like playing GTA or True Crime, this game will easily hook you up with a lot of charming and fresh features. But if you're in for stories you might be a bit disappointed, as the game only tell a common feud between triads and police, nothing new.That leave you one final question, Are you in for the gameplay or are you in for the stories ? This review might help you answer that.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												When I heard about this game, I was hesitant to get it due to the fact that it wasn't as hyped as a GTA or a Saints Row and I didn't want to be disappointed. However, I knew I liked these types of games so I took a chance on it while it was on sale. I gotta say, I wasn't disappointed.Story:You assume the role of Wei Shen, an undercover police officer sent to infiltrate and take down the Sun On Yee, a traid organization based in Hong Kong. Wei deals with the inner conflict of being a cop, while proving himself to the Triads in order to gain their trust and complete his mission. Unfortunately, in order to gain the trust of the Triads, Wei must go against his moral code. It's only a matter of time before Wei gets in too deep.Gameplay:Sleeping Dogs isn't just a GTA or Saints Row clone. It brings something different to the genre. It doesn't feel like a generic recreation of the previously mentioned, more established frachises. This game stands out on it's own with the addition of kung-fu melee fighting, parkour, chase sequences and a conflicting story. Other than the main story, there's side missions, races, drug busts, fight clubs and more. There's also an abundance of collectibles to find throughout the map. On top of that, there's four different skill trees that allow you to upgrade your abilities as you complete missions and activities. The melee fighting is really fun. You're not just blocking, reversing and throwing punches. You can use your environment to your advantage. Some of the environmental kills are brutal. Throw your opponents off a roof, or into an eel tank or impale them onto some meat hooks. There's also several types of melee weapons to use such as crowbars, machetes, tire irons, etc. If the use of guns in these types of games are a necessity to you, this game may not be for you. There are certain missions that will require firearms, but the majority of combat is melee fighting. I would estimate the melee-to-gun combat ratio is about 70/30. Guns are somewhat uncommon. This is even mentioned in the story. However, that's something I actually liked about the game. You had to play differently than you would in a GTA or a Saints Row.The Negatives:I only have two complaints with this game. Firstly, the main story is a bit short. There's only about 30 main story missions. Once I beat the game and watched the ending cutscenes, I thought they could have milked out two or three more missions. Instead, they seemed to rush the end of the story and summarize it in cutscenes. The other complaint I have is the driving. It feels very stiff. I remember when I played the first Saints Row after playing nothing but GTA games and the driving felt so stiff in comparison. Well, I felt that way again with Sleeping Dogs. It feels even more stiff than Saints Row does. This isn't that much of a deterrence since the game offers so many other things, but it is something I think they could improve on for a sequel.Conclusion:Overall, this game was worth every penny. If you enjoy games like GTA or Saints Row, I think there's a good chance you'll enjoy this as well. The graphics, the gameplay and the story are all excellent. There's a lot of things that will keep you busy. If you're hesitant, I would still wait for a good sale like I did. It's definitely worth a try.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2013
												An Asian Kung Fu Version of Grand Theft Auto. Although most will disagree that there are no stripper bars in this game, there are clubs and such. In comparison and contrast, GTA has "whacked out♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;. Not as much as Saints Row. But still whacked out mini games. Sleeping Dogs invites you to a story of Wei Shen, an American-Chinese undercover cop who goes under the disguise of his childhood friend Jackie. His mission is to exploit the traids and ruin their operations (Drugs, etc.). During this story, the player will feel conflicted emotions from the events that happen to Wei. The combat system is a second recommendation from me after Batman Arkham City. There are multiple ways to take down enemies and there are tournaments for those who are thirsty for a beatdown. This game is brutal and is recommended for those who enjoyed GTA and Batman Arkham City. I have enjoyed the game incredibly and played through multiple times. (More on X-box). There are many dlcs for this game which I also bought and have not regretted. Buy this game when it is on sale. Since the dlc collection is huge. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												If you have ever wished you were a fast talking Chinese-American cop who is less "undercover" and more "dangerously unhinged" United Front Games (and about a dozen other studios and publishers over the course of a decade) have finally enabled your fantasy. Walk the streets of Hong Kong and grievously injure innocent pedestrians with your kung-fu while they recite authentic Chinese dialog such as "You like pork-bun, yes?" and "...Please help!". Watch protagonist Wei Shen rail against the Triads to his police superiors and then run over 40 fellow officers on the way to his date with real American actress Emma Stone. It is not all fun and games though; your buddies in uniform(who don't have the everyday stress of having to randomly murder civilians for no reason) will kind of try and put a stop to your rampages. But no matter how many of them you kill no one turns you into Human Resources for creating a hostile work enviroment.Seriously though it is a great game.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Definetelly the best open-world game in my opinion !The idea of Sleeping Dogs is very excited and well executed.You are playing as an undercover cop and your mission is to infiltrate Triad and make some friends among their leaders.In the same time you can not forget that you're a cop and you have to arrange secret meetings with your police fellows ,make some phonecalls or send text message when you need to.The graphics is amazing ,and so is the game phisique ,especially seen during a street fights which occur very often.I have never seen well executed fight scenes as here in Sleeping Dogs .It's not about blind clicking your mouse .(of course you need to use it ) .To become a supreme street brawler you will need need to use counter strikes ,blocks ,throws ,and a lot of combinations to tackle your opponent down ,brake his legs or arm ,or crack hes jaw:) eventually throwing him in to a phone booth :)But it is not all about street fights...you will need to track and eliminate other gangs that are a treating Triadyou're in .Pursue competition by car,motorbike ,bus ,or just by using your legs ,go to kung fu school to improve your fighting skills ,eliminating in the same time Triad members silently and without any suspicions.I forgot to mention that while playing Sleeping Dogs you're gaining experience which is converted to skill points.Basicly what you got here is: 2 skill trees :one for doing work for Triad ,and another skill tree for co operarting with cops.Amazing isn't it???:) You can use almost anything to steal the car ,or boat ,hack the CCTV cameras ,harrass Triad competition and even do petty jobs such as destroying sports car or collecting money from shops for so called "protection"The game is deep ,and has a lot of dimentions.You don't need to follow quests or mission as if  the fun part would depend on those .Take your time ,explore the city ,find hiden suitcases ,try beat your friends record by riding longer on one wheel of your motor bike ,or make the longest car jump in a history of Sleeping Dogs ,and many more fun stuff awaits on you in this awesome game.When you start playing you will not know when to stop!!!:)Love it !!!Dan.

Simply put, if you can play Tomb Raider on Medium settings with DirectX11 features turned on, you'll blaze through this game without breaking a sweat.Stereoscopic 3D via AMD HD3D works out of the box if you have an AMD HD 5000+ GPU connected to a 3D capable monitor via HDMI 1.4a. Depending on your setup, you may need a 3D driver such as Tridef 3D to play it in 3D mode.Personally, I had a blast playing the game and would recommend it highly.

In this game you simply drive behind the car, when the green arrow pops up, press a button, jump on the moving car, steal the car as its moving and drive away!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												I just finished the game, so all of this is kind of a recent pile of thoughts.The story:Wei Shen, an undercover cop has to get into the Sun On Yee, one of the triads in Hong Kong. Old friends, new friends, lovers, enemies, and bitterness is what follows his mission to the very end, which is one of the greates cliamxes in any games I've ever played so far. It's like a really awesome TV series coming to a satisfying end. The base of the story is a dolig one, which we could see a hundred, maybe a thousand times. But man...they did a wonderful job for making it work better than anything else that follows the same path. You'll feel the friends in the game are truly your friends - and their betrayal will hurt you even more. You'll find yourself cheering when something turns out great, and feel anger you never thought you could ever feel. While you don't have much choices storylinewise, the one you get will be usually the best. You'll kill when you need, but feel guilty for it, when you did not. And what makes it all possible?The characters. Wei Shen is a really great protagonist for a game like this. A cop, who has lots of friends from his childhood in the triads, but his supervisor gives him the orders. You'll feel the weight of the things he has to go through, and you'll even feel sorry for him some times. And thus, the payoff will be the better because all of this. Then you have people who knew Wei from his childhood. Jackie, who appears to be the comedic sidekick, but he is indeed much more. A loyal friend, a brother in arms who'll be by your side every time. Then there's Winston, the Red Pole (triad rank), who was first a bit skeptical about you, but he'll become a good friend too. You'll understand him, and you'll ultimately feel sorry for him. And that was just two of the many great and memorable characters from the game.The writing is really good. It's logical, the interactions between the characters are genuine, you know that it was written by someone who can create good characters, and instead of making them do what needs to be done, he or she just creates them, puts them into Hong Kong, and watch what do they do. There are fillers in the discussions between the characters, but they feel anything but forced. They are chatting, enjoying themselves, nothing serious. Just what you'd do if you were roaming the city with your best friend riding shotgun.Overall the story, characters, game concept, and writing gets a 10/10 - really enjoyable, and I'm sure even folks who are not into the moral dilemmas of being an undercover cop will find the game interesting.Gameplay:It follows the road GTA has set up (or at least as far as I know, but it could happen that it wasn't the first game like this), third person view, open world, sandbox feeling, etc. If you played any GTA games, from III to V, you are familiar with the concept. But instead of guns, the emphasis is more on the fistfights. Wei can learn tons of new moves, each associated with a "reputation tree", one for the Triads, one for the Police, and the third for your old martial arts master, Sifu. You get experience in each mission for both factions, depending on your accomplishments - if you didn't break anything, and didn't kill or hurt any civilians, you get more Police XP, while killing more enemies, especially with enviromental kills will reward you more Triad xp. For Sifu, you need to find his jade statues, and he'll teach you a new move for every one of them. The melee system is not too complicated. You have a bunch of combos, and about four buttons to use. It's like the melee system of Batman, but without the gadgets, and with more brutal fightning moves. Roundkicks, breaking arms and legs, throwing them off a building, you get everything you need. I mentioned enviromental kills, which need some explaining, I'm afraid. When you grab an enemy, you can see some items with blinking red lights. You can perform enviromental kills on them, like throwing the poor guy on a bunch of swordfish heads, or roasting his head on an oven. Even tho there aren't as much emphasis on the guns, they are still present. They aren't too many of them, but they are a great deal of fun. You can use covers, and go all John Woo on your enemies' asses. Slow down time, jump through tables, and earn more time slowing for shooting them in the head. Firefights will play like an action movie, such a shame there aren't a bit more of them in the game. Most of the big turning points of the game involve a lot of guns and enemies, which will make the blood run faster in your veins. The open world is wonderful. I've never been to Hong Kong, and haven't seen too much pictures of it, but if it looks like this, then hot damn, what an awesome city. It looks really good. And with all the people going aroudn, doing their daily routine, it becomes even better. In the daytime the streets are crowded, while the night is relatively quiet, and only a few people are running around. And most of them belong to one or another gang, so be careful.There are lots of hidden, or not so hidden altars around the city. Pray at them, and for every 5th you visit, your health will increase a bit. A great fun, and they feel the part of the city.Also, there are a lot of minigames, which I haven't discovered in their entirety. You can race with cars, bet on chicken fights, play mahjonng poker, etcetera etcetera. They are worth checking out, and maybe you'll find them as engaging as the main game and storyline itself.Overall, for gameplay, I'd give a 9/10 - only because I'm sure there are mistakes here and there, but it's so recent i'm still under the effect of the game.Graphics:I don't want to talk about this as much as the other parts, as I don't really watch the graphics of the game. It's in harmony with the other parts of the game, and this is awesome. The characters' animations are great, you can spot really lifelike impressions on them.Let's say non-rated/10, I haven't got the hardware to see it's full potential.Sounds:Various radio stations in the cars, and great enviromental sounds when you are not in a vehicle. Both of them are good, and I'm sure everybody will find a radio station he likes. From techno, to J-pop, from classical to death metal. They got your taste covered. 10/10Multiplayer/co-op:Non-existent, you can only see if in specific areas you did better than your friends or not. Longest time driven without accidents, and so forth. I don't think that's necessary, but could have been a welcomed addition to the game.Overall? I'd give this game a 9 out of 10. A joy to play, and I didn't get frustrated at any part on normal. It was a fluid game, that really worth my money. I got it on a sale, but if you don't want to wait to try it, get it for the full price - you won't regret it. Many hours of fun, with minigames, side missions, or just plain exploring.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												This game was brilliant. Much better than other titles that Square Enix has made that are not Final Fantasy such as Just Cause which has serious audio syncing problems. Combat system closely related to that of Batman Arkham Asylum and Arkam City. graphics are quite impressive. But besides the great fighting mechanics, the endless amount of things that you can do in Hong Kong, the customisation with clothes and the many many cars there are to purchase and show off. What is most impressive about this has to definitely be the storyline. Unlike typical games of this genre such as Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row, the main protagnanist of the game,  Wei Shen, is not just a character that comes off as just the average, out to get money and destroy stuff for the sake of it. Wei Shen is the heart of the game. He is a well respected polie offica with the San Fransico police department that heads back to his home city, Hong Kong, to try and assist the local PD with taking down the Traids in the citty. It is immediatly obvious that your character has history with a fair amount of the people in the Traids, seeing as they use one of your oldest friends, Jackie to get Wei into the Triads to begin his undercover operation. Though as Shen gets pulled further in to the seedy underground workings of Hong Kong. It becomes more apparent that his motives of ether helping the police take down the Traids, or working with the Triads become extremely blurred. In conclusion, as I have seen with other reviews of this game, we are all confused as to why people are not paying enough attention to this brilliant title. Yes there are a few bugs in the game, but what game doesn't. Even if you do not like the look of the game, I absolutely recommend this game just for it;s in depth and "keep you on the edge of your seat" storyline.

												I've done pretty much everything there is to do in this game, and I can conclusively say it's my favorite crime sandbox I've ever played. The story is well-crafted, the characters are awesome, the gameplay — especially combat — is outstanding, and it has its equal measures of laughter and powerful dramatic moments. content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Definetelly the best open-world game in my opinion !The idea of Sleeping Dogs is very excited and well executed.You are playing as an undercover cop and your mission is to infiltrate Triad and make some friends among their leaders.In the same time you can not forget that you're a cop and you have to arrange secret meetings with your police fellows ,make some phonecalls or send text message when you need to.The graphics is amazing ,and so is the game phisique ,especially seen during a street fights which occur very often.I have never seen well executed fight scenes as here in Sleeping Dogs .It's not about blind clicking your mouse .(of course you need to use it ) .To become a supreme street brawler you will need need to use counter strikes ,blocks ,throws ,and a lot of combinations to tackle your opponent down ,brake his legs or arm ,or crack hes jaw:) eventually throwing him in to a phone booth :)But it is not all about street fights...you will need to track and eliminate other gangs that are a treating Triadyou're in .Pursue competition by car,motorbike ,bus ,or just by using your legs ,go to kung fu school to improve your fighting skills ,eliminating in the same time Triad members silently and without any suspicions.I forgot to mention that while playing Sleeping Dogs you're gaining experience which is converted to skill points.Basicly what you got here is: 2 skill trees :one for doing work for Triad ,and another skill tree for co operarting with cops.Amazing isn't it???:) You can use almost anything to steal the car ,or boat ,hack the CCTV cameras ,harrass Triad competition and even do petty jobs such as destroying sports car or collecting money from shops for so called "protection"The game is deep ,and has a lot of dimentions.You don't need to follow quests or mission as if  the fun part would depend on those .Take your time ,explore the city ,find hiden suitcases ,try beat your friends record by riding longer on one wheel of your motor bike ,or make the longest car jump in a history of Sleeping Dogs ,and many more fun stuff awaits on you in this awesome game.When you start playing you will not know when to stop!!!:)Love it !!!Dan.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												With the success of open-world titles such as Grand Theft Auto, Saints Row and Just Cause, developer United Front Games had big hopes for True Crime: Hong Kong, set to be published by Activision. Wait – True Crime? Yes. You could say the development story around this game might be more interesting than the in-game story.Hoping to reinvigorate the True Crime series, Activision had plans to merge United Front Games’ newest title into it – even going as far as announcing it and releasing a trailer (and eventually changing the naming to just “True Crime“). As time went on, and delays plagued the release, Activision gave up on the project. Some rumors state that the game was almost finished, and could even be completed by players in its current state.To the angst of gamers everywhere, with thoughts of what could have been, this happens often in game development. What also happens on occasion is that another publisher will spot the diamond in the rough, inherit the project, and ultimately publish it. That’s what happened here; when Square Enix first laid its eyes on the game, it’s been said that it was a done deal right from the get-go. There have even been quotes from Square Enix calling Activision “crazy” for abandoning not only a game so far in its development cycle, but a game with such potential.Those who enjoy open-world games such as the titles mentioned above will be pleased with Square Enix’s decision on this one, because Sleeping Dogs is a great game, offering just enough uniqueness to set itself apart from the games it’s going to inevitably be compared to time and time again.What’s not so unique is its story, but it involves a not-so-unique mechanic that makes it unique (get that?). You’re Wei Shen, a Hong Kong-born undercover cop that lived in America for so long that his accent is almost non-existent. Back in Hong Kong, Shen’s job is to get in good with the Triad gang Sun On Yee (based on the real-life gang Sun Yee On) and ultimately take it down.Throughout the game, Shen will have to perform duties for both his gang and the police department, and as missions are completed, XP will be earned for the respective skill tree (Triad or Police). Each of these are split into two sections, and as each level is earned, you’ll be able to unlock the next available skill in either section.Where the unique comes in is that ultimately, you may sway more to one side than the other, depending on your playstyle. When on a police mission, if you run into people or damage the environment, XP is taken away from that tree. This doesn’t matter much, as Police XP comes easier than Triad XP. In addition to these there’s also a “Face” tree, which is leveled up based on various actions throughout the game; when a new level is earned here, it adds a new self-benefiting ability, such as having buffs last longer.Buffs, you ask? Yes, Sleeping Dogs is more RPG-like than most other open-world games, with the game coming close to the mechanics Saints Row 3. By either eating or partaking in some activity, Shen can earn buffs that increase his damage, helps him regenerate health or boost other abilities. Each buff disappears after a certain amount of time; faster if it’s more beneficial. While it’d be nice given the difficulty of some fights, there are no healing items that Shen can keep on him.One thing that sets this game apart is that it takes place in Hong Kong, while most open-world games, such as Grand Theft Auto, Mafia II and Saints Row, take place in more Americanized locations. If you’re indifferent to Asia, this might not matter, but if you do happen to love the cities of any Asian metropolis, you’re going to be pleased with the world here. I’d argue that this is the most detailed open-world game ever, as the cities feel genuine with their layouts and design, and rarely did I stumble on anything that I knew was a direct copy / paste (things like advertisements aside).Adding to the realism, most of the NPCs in the game speak Cantonese with no subtitles, while all important characters speak in clear English with occasional Cantonese thrown in. This is appreciated, and to me, required. It’d feel a bit odd to traverse through Hong Kong and never hear the official language.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												I just finished the game, so all of this is kind of a recent pile of thoughts.The story:Wei Shen, an undercover cop has to get into the Sun On Yee, one of the triads in Hong Kong. Old friends, new friends, lovers, enemies, and bitterness is what follows his mission to the very end, which is one of the greates cliamxes in any games I've ever played so far. It's like a really awesome TV series coming to a satisfying end. The base of the story is a dolig one, which we could see a hundred, maybe a thousand times. But man...they did a wonderful job for making it work better than anything else that follows the same path. You'll feel the friends in the game are truly your friends - and their betrayal will hurt you even more. You'll find yourself cheering when something turns out great, and feel anger you never thought you could ever feel. While you don't have much choices storylinewise, the one you get will be usually the best. You'll kill when you need, but feel guilty for it, when you did not. And what makes it all possible?The characters. Wei Shen is a really great protagonist for a game like this. A cop, who has lots of friends from his childhood in the triads, but his supervisor gives him the orders. You'll feel the weight of the things he has to go through, and you'll even feel sorry for him some times. And thus, the payoff will be the better because all of this. Then you have people who knew Wei from his childhood. Jackie, who appears to be the comedic sidekick, but he is indeed much more. A loyal friend, a brother in arms who'll be by your side every time. Then there's Winston, the Red Pole (triad rank), who was first a bit skeptical about you, but he'll become a good friend too. You'll understand him, and you'll ultimately feel sorry for him. And that was just two of the many great and memorable characters from the game.The writing is really good. It's logical, the interactions between the characters are genuine, you know that it was written by someone who can create good characters, and instead of making them do what needs to be done, he or she just creates them, puts them into Hong Kong, and watch what do they do. There are fillers in the discussions between the characters, but they feel anything but forced. They are chatting, enjoying themselves, nothing serious. Just what you'd do if you were roaming the city with your best friend riding shotgun.Overall the story, characters, game concept, and writing gets a 10/10 - really enjoyable, and I'm sure even folks who are not into the moral dilemmas of being an undercover cop will find the game interesting.Gameplay:It follows the road GTA has set up (or at least as far as I know, but it could happen that it wasn't the first game like this), third person view, open world, sandbox feeling, etc. If you played any GTA games, from III to V, you are familiar with the concept. But instead of guns, the emphasis is more on the fistfights. Wei can learn tons of new moves, each associated with a "reputation tree", one for the Triads, one for the Police, and the third for your old martial arts master, Sifu. You get experience in each mission for both factions, depending on your accomplishments - if you didn't break anything, and didn't kill or hurt any civilians, you get more Police XP, while killing more enemies, especially with enviromental kills will reward you more Triad xp. For Sifu, you need to find his jade statues, and he'll teach you a new move for every one of them. The melee system is not too complicated. You have a bunch of combos, and about four buttons to use. It's like the melee system of Batman, but without the gadgets, and with more brutal fightning moves. Roundkicks, breaking arms and legs, throwing them off a building, you get everything you need. I mentioned enviromental kills, which need some explaining, I'm afraid. When you grab an enemy, you can see some items with blinking red lights. You can perform enviromental kills on them, like throwing the poor guy on a bunch of swordfish heads, or roasting his head on an oven. Even tho there aren't as much emphasis on the guns, they are still present. They aren't too many of them, but they are a great deal of fun. You can use covers, and go all John Woo on your enemies' asses. Slow down time, jump through tables, and earn more time slowing for shooting them in the head. Firefights will play like an action movie, such a shame there aren't a bit more of them in the game. Most of the big turning points of the game involve a lot of guns and enemies, which will make the blood run faster in your veins. The open world is wonderful. I've never been to Hong Kong, and haven't seen too much pictures of it, but if it looks like this, then hot damn, what an awesome city. It looks really good. And with all the people going aroudn, doing their daily routine, it becomes even better. In the daytime the streets are crowded, while the night is relatively quiet, and only a few people are running around. And most of them belong to one or another gang, so be careful.There are lots of hidden, or not so hidden altars around the city. Pray at them, and for every 5th you visit, your health will increase a bit. A great fun, and they feel the part of the city.Also, there are a lot of minigames, which I haven't discovered in their entirety. You can race with cars, bet on chicken fights, play mahjonng poker, etcetera etcetera. They are worth checking out, and maybe you'll find them as engaging as the main game and storyline itself.Overall, for gameplay, I'd give a 9/10 - only because I'm sure there are mistakes here and there, but it's so recent i'm still under the effect of the game.Graphics:I don't want to talk about this as much as the other parts, as I don't really watch the graphics of the game. It's in harmony with the other parts of the game, and this is awesome. The characters' animations are great, you can spot really lifelike impressions on them.Let's say non-rated/10, I haven't got the hardware to see it's full potential.Sounds:Various radio stations in the cars, and great enviromental sounds when you are not in a vehicle. Both of them are good, and I'm sure everybody will find a radio station he likes. From techno, to J-pop, from classical to death metal. They got your taste covered. 10/10Multiplayer/co-op:Non-existent, you can only see if in specific areas you did better than your friends or not. Longest time driven without accidents, and so forth. I don't think that's necessary, but could have been a welcomed addition to the game.Overall? I'd give this game a 9 out of 10. A joy to play, and I didn't get frustrated at any part on normal. It was a fluid game, that really worth my money. I got it on a sale, but if you don't want to wait to try it, get it for the full price - you won't regret it. Many hours of fun, with minigames, side missions, or just plain exploring.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												This game was brilliant. Much better than other titles that Square Enix has made that are not Final Fantasy such as Just Cause which has serious audio syncing problems. Combat system closely related to that of Batman Arkham Asylum and Arkam City. graphics are quite impressive. But besides the great fighting mechanics, the endless amount of things that you can do in Hong Kong, the customisation with clothes and the many many cars there are to purchase and show off. What is most impressive about this has to definitely be the storyline. Unlike typical games of this genre such as Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row, the main protagnanist of the game,  Wei Shen, is not just a character that comes off as just the average, out to get money and destroy stuff for the sake of it. Wei Shen is the heart of the game. He is a well respected polie offica with the San Fransico police department that heads back to his home city, Hong Kong, to try and assist the local PD with taking down the Traids in the citty. It is immediatly obvious that your character has history with a fair amount of the people in the Traids, seeing as they use one of your oldest friends, Jackie to get Wei into the Triads to begin his undercover operation. Though as Shen gets pulled further in to the seedy underground workings of Hong Kong. It becomes more apparent that his motives of ether helping the police take down the Traids, or working with the Triads become extremely blurred. In conclusion, as I have seen with other reviews of this game, we are all confused as to why people are not paying enough attention to this brilliant title. Yes there are a few bugs in the game, but what game doesn't. Even if you do not like the look of the game, I absolutely recommend this game just for it;s in depth and "keep you on the edge of your seat" storyline.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												After 60 hours in this games world.. I can safely say that this game is definitely for me.Sleeping Dogs is the story of Wei Shen a cop deep within Hong Kong's crime syndicate, so deep he doesn't know who's side he is on any more. All he knows is honour and respect are the most important things and he will keep to those values.Sleeping Dogs is a fantastic open world sandbox game, its gameplay mechanics and mesmerizing world combined make an experience that is overall rewarding and entertaining from the beginning to when you are finished with it, Whether it be a 20 hour playthrough of only the story or if you're like me and enjoyed the game enough and had the time to collect and unlock everything in the game in a 60+ hour playthrough. No matter what you are going to enjoy Sleeping Dogs if you are a fan of the open world genre.The game looks and sounds fantastic the best looking the game will get is at night with rain, its one of the most visually appealing sandbox games out there. A lot of people will probably have problems with the amount of limitations the game has... you can't fly planes or helicopters the driving is almost arcade (which I kind of respect in a world where every open world game is trying to be realistic with its driving ) and there isn't a jump button.. but when you play Sleeping Dogs you will see how those problems don't even matter instead of jumping the game will give you moments while running to jump to another rooftop or vault over and parkour the environment. I didn't really feel like flying a plane or helicopter would benefit the game at all.The combat is a nice remix of the Batman: Arkham Franchise's free flow combat and its a nice new take on that style of combat. You feel like you are in a Hong Kong action movie, with various environmental and up close takedown moves.A small but decent range of melee weapons and firearms the combat in Sleeping Dogs is very well done. That being said you will be doing more punching and kicking then shooting.. but that's in the games favour as I feel the melee combat towers of the shooting mechanics which are still pretty fun.The collectables in this game never really feel like chores because each one gets you closer and closer to unlocking more items or maxing out your health bar so even players who don't normally enjoy collecting will find themselves doing it anyway.. So I thought that was a pretty nice way to do the collecting side of things.I'm not a fan of DLC I hate the idea of it but I can find my self enjoying DLC whenever I somehow find my self playing it.Sleeping Dogs has three DLC missions and all three are great, one has Wei Shen return to being a beat cop and in full uniform to take down a cult that has made its way to Hong Kong and bomb certain areas. Another has Wei make his way to a fighting tournament on an island off the coast of Hong Kong.. and if you didn't think it could get anymore ridiculous there is a full on Halloween themed mission involving Wei rescuing his girlfriend from demon's and ghosts in the Northpoint of Kong Kong.The game looks, plays and sounds fantastically. If you are a fan of the sandbox genre then you would be a fool to miss this gem.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												When I heard about this game, I was hesitant to get it due to the fact that it wasn't as hyped as a GTA or a Saints Row and I didn't want to be disappointed. However, I knew I liked these types of games so I took a chance on it while it was on sale. I gotta say, I wasn't disappointed.Story:You assume the role of Wei Shen, an undercover police officer sent to infiltrate and take down the Sun On Yee, a traid organization based in Hong Kong. Wei deals with the inner conflict of being a cop, while proving himself to the Triads in order to gain their trust and complete his mission. Unfortunately, in order to gain the trust of the Triads, Wei must go against his moral code. It's only a matter of time before Wei gets in too deep.Gameplay:Sleeping Dogs isn't just a GTA or Saints Row clone. It brings something different to the genre. It doesn't feel like a generic recreation of the previously mentioned, more established frachises. This game stands out on it's own with the addition of kung-fu melee fighting, parkour, chase sequences and a conflicting story. Other than the main story, there's side missions, races, drug busts, fight clubs and more. There's also an abundance of collectibles to find throughout the map. On top of that, there's four different skill trees that allow you to upgrade your abilities as you complete missions and activities. The melee fighting is really fun. You're not just blocking, reversing and throwing punches. You can use your environment to your advantage. Some of the environmental kills are brutal. Throw your opponents off a roof, or into an eel tank or impale them onto some meat hooks. There's also several types of melee weapons to use such as crowbars, machetes, tire irons, etc. If the use of guns in these types of games are a necessity to you, this game may not be for you. There are certain missions that will require firearms, but the majority of combat is melee fighting. I would estimate the melee-to-gun combat ratio is about 70/30. Guns are somewhat uncommon. This is even mentioned in the story. However, that's something I actually liked about the game. You had to play differently than you would in a GTA or a Saints Row.The Negatives:I only have two complaints with this game. Firstly, the main story is a bit short. There's only about 30 main story missions. Once I beat the game and watched the ending cutscenes, I thought they could have milked out two or three more missions. Instead, they seemed to rush the end of the story and summarize it in cutscenes. The other complaint I have is the driving. It feels very stiff. I remember when I played the first Saints Row after playing nothing but GTA games and the driving felt so stiff in comparison. Well, I felt that way again with Sleeping Dogs. It feels even more stiff than Saints Row does. This isn't that much of a deterrence since the game offers so many other things, but it is something I think they could improve on for a sequel.Conclusion:Overall, this game was worth every penny. If you enjoy games like GTA or Saints Row, I think there's a good chance you'll enjoy this as well. The graphics, the gameplay and the story are all excellent. There's a lot of things that will keep you busy. If you're hesitant, I would still wait for a good sale like I did. It's definitely worth a try.

												Wow, what a game! If you love open world games with excellent storytelling, amazing melee combat, great gun-play, and white knuckled driving sequences...look no further. I was a fan of the True Crime series, but this is the evolution I wanted to see in these games. Taking the best parts of other similar games, United Front has really made it their own and an absolutely polished gem. The graphics (full out) on PC are breathtaking and the amount of detail in the world, and the speed at which this detail can go rushing by, is a sight to behold.I was addicted from the moment it started and spent every spare moment playing the game until the intense and satisfying conclusion. A graphical feast with truly lifelike audio, excellent acting, and a strong storyline made me care about the characters in the game like few others.

												I've done pretty much everything there is to do in this game, and I can conclusively say it's my favorite crime sandbox I've ever played. The story is well-crafted, the characters are awesome, the gameplay — especially combat — is outstanding, and it has its equal measures of laughter and powerful dramatic moments. content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Definetelly the best open-world game in my opinion !The idea of Sleeping Dogs is very excited and well executed.You are playing as an undercover cop and your mission is to infiltrate Triad and make some friends among their leaders.In the same time you can not forget that you're a cop and you have to arrange secret meetings with your police fellows ,make some phonecalls or send text message when you need to.The graphics is amazing ,and so is the game phisique ,especially seen during a street fights which occur very often.I have never seen well executed fight scenes as here in Sleeping Dogs .It's not about blind clicking your mouse .(of course you need to use it ) .To become a supreme street brawler you will need need to use counter strikes ,blocks ,throws ,and a lot of combinations to tackle your opponent down ,brake his legs or arm ,or crack hes jaw:) eventually throwing him in to a phone booth :)But it is not all about street fights...you will need to track and eliminate other gangs that are a treating Triadyou're in .Pursue competition by car,motorbike ,bus ,or just by using your legs ,go to kung fu school to improve your fighting skills ,eliminating in the same time Triad members silently and without any suspicions.I forgot to mention that while playing Sleeping Dogs you're gaining experience which is converted to skill points.Basicly what you got here is: 2 skill trees :one for doing work for Triad ,and another skill tree for co operarting with cops.Amazing isn't it???:) You can use almost anything to steal the car ,or boat ,hack the CCTV cameras ,harrass Triad competition and even do petty jobs such as destroying sports car or collecting money from shops for so called "protection"The game is deep ,and has a lot of dimentions.You don't need to follow quests or mission as if  the fun part would depend on those .Take your time ,explore the city ,find hiden suitcases ,try beat your friends record by riding longer on one wheel of your motor bike ,or make the longest car jump in a history of Sleeping Dogs ,and many more fun stuff awaits on you in this awesome game.When you start playing you will not know when to stop!!!:)Love it !!!Dan.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2013
												GTA: China, or so I Imagined Sleeping Dogs like that when i first heard about it but it's so much more than that. Of course it is like GTA in china in a way, but it doesn't fail in a storytelling like GTA 4 did. The game takes major influence from movies The Departed and Infernal Affairs where the line between friend and foe gets blurred and character loyalties and movies are questioned. The protagonist, Wei Shen is an undercover cop in Hong Kong who sworn uphold the law and bring criminals to justice but by virtue of being undercover which is also a gangster comiting very real acts of of crime. He has a personal vendetta against drug pushing triads for what they did to his sister and he sworn to take them down. It's a game about dealing with conflicting aspects of self. And what is interesting you don't have to chose between those aspects. It's a game about living with and reconsiling the fact that you have theese identities. The best straightforward example of this is you get 2 different EXP bars after each mission, the triad and cop. Triad exp fills with every kill you make, the more brutal the better, headshots, explosions fill up that bar while cop exp punish you for being clumsy or killing hostage etc. it implies that Wei is a good cop at the begining of the mission and going down morally doing his job. It's a game where protagonist doing the triad and cop things and he has to live up with consequences and it's show in game every time Wei goes to sleep. I think it's a good game and worth your attention 8/10.

It doesn't feel like a generic recreation of the previously mentioned, more established frachises. This game stands out on it's own with the addition of kung-fu melee fighting, parkour, chase sequences and a conflicting story. Other than the main story, there's side missions, races, drug busts, fight clubs and more. There's also an abundance of collectibles to find throughout the map. On top of that, there's four different skill trees that allow you to upgrade your abilities as you complete missions and activities. The melee fighting is really fun. You're not just blocking, reversing and throwing punches. You can use your environment to your advantage. Some of the environmental kills are brutal. Throw your opponents off a roof, or into an eel tank or impale them onto some meat hooks. There's also several types of melee weapons to use such as crowbars, machetes, tire irons, etc. If the use of guns in these types of games are a necessity to you, this game may not be for you. There are certain missions that will require firearms, but the majority of combat is melee fighting. I would estimate the melee-to-gun combat ratio is about 70/30. Guns are somewhat uncommon. This is even mentioned in the story. However, that's something I actually liked about the game. You had to play differently than you would in a GTA or a Saints Row.The Negatives:I only have two complaints with this game. Firstly, the main story is a bit short. There's only about 30 main story missions. Once I beat the game and watched the ending cutscenes, I thought they could have milked out two or three more missions. Instead, they seemed to rush the end of the story and summarize it in cutscenes. The other complaint I have is the driving. It feels very stiff. I remember when I played the first Saints Row after playing nothing but GTA games and the driving felt so stiff in comparison. Well, I felt that way again with Sleeping Dogs. It feels even more stiff than Saints Row does. This isn't that much of a deterrence since the game offers so many other things, but it is something I think they could improve on for a sequel.Conclusion:Overall, this game was worth every penny. If you enjoy games like GTA or Saints Row, I think there's a good chance you'll enjoy this as well. The graphics, the gameplay and the story are all excellent. There's a lot of things that will keep you busy. If you're hesitant, I would still wait for a good sale like I did. It's definitely worth a try.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												TL;DR- 8/10, fun game despite a few flaws.I've heard this game reffered to as "a poor man's Grand Theft Auto". And while the moniker may come across as derogatory, I can't disagree. Certain aspects of Sleeping Dogs draw from open world titans like GTA, but it still manages to stand tall of its own merits, rather than on the coattails of GTA.The pros are that it is a legitimately fun game to play. The story was interesting enough to keep me engaged and wanting to dig deeper, combat handled pretty well and was easy to learn, and a lot of the special actions you can perform, such as mid-driving carjacking, are pretty fun to pull off. The dual experience system is implemented fairly well, rewarding you for wreaking as much havok as you can upon your enemies, while punishing you for hurting, killing or destroying anything not related to your mission. Environmental hazards give combat a little more pep, allowing you to seriously injure, if not outright slaughter (sometimes quite brutally) anyone standing in your way.The cons are that there isn't a terrible lot to do outside of the story quests, and what little there is to do becomes repetative and tedious with no meaningful reward. Some of the dialogue and situations/resolutions you come across can be pretty tongue-in-cheek if not outright absurd and cheesy, and felt detractive towards the overall tone and feel of the game. Combat, while easy to learn and diverse in what movesets you can punish your enemies with, ultimately boils down only attacking, grabbing or counters, and doesn't encourage making use of the many skills you can learn except for the sake of doing something flashy. NPCs will sometimes get stuck on terrain or on corners, making some missions impossible to complete without a restart.But the two biggest offenders in this game for me, are the vehicle camera controls, and the option to purchase a number of game breaking features from the start through DLC content. The vehicle camera controls can be frustrating at best and damning at worst. It tends to lock itself in whatever position you move it to relative to your vehicle, and doesn't transition back to the forward position when you begin driving unless you move it back yourself, making multi-point turns and complex driving maneuvers aggrivating.The DLC content almost broke the game for me at the start. I'll admit I grabbed the whole shabang without reading about it all when it was on sale, and I wish I had. After the first couple missions, I suddenly found myself awash in an inordinate amount of Cop and Triad XP, Face XP, money, vehicles and items.. enough so that what was supposed to be earned throughout the course of the game was instantly given to me at the start, making personal progression almost non-existant. If that's your sort of thing, then by all means. Otherwise be wary of what DLC you purchase.Despite the cons and my own complaints about the game however, I'm left feeling quite positive about the overall experience. It's no GTA for sure, but I do think it's worth a look and a playthrough.8/10

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Well I bought it while it was on sale and never played it until two weeks ago. It instantly got me. The story is so captivating that I didn't even collect all shrines and statues just because I wanted to continue the storyline, which doesn't happen that often when I play games like this. It is this new situation, not being a gangster like in GTA and all those titles but rather being an undercover cop, always fearing that your cover might be blown up. I will just make a list here to point out what points are outstanding and which are not that great.Pros:-Action Hijack. Holy. Really cool thing, it allows you to hijack someones car just by jumping off your vehicle onto theirs, like in action movies.-Pretty big city.-"Minigames" like picking locks, hacking codes, tracking handys and so on. Not really challenging but it is a nice gimmick to have in an action game.-The combat system. It's really easy but it still looks pretty cool when you're doing your combos to defeat those 20 triad members.-Not too much shooting. Weapons are pretty rare, you mainly use martial arts to fight foes.-Different culture. The setting is authentic, the voice acting well done, just the traffic sucks.-Very cool characters. Reminds me of Mafia & Mafia II.-The captivating story. Wei Shen (you) gets a bit attached during the story and you can understand him due to what you and the characters go through.-Nice graphics. Nothing outstanding but they fit well. Not comparable to Mafia II though.Cons:-The driving. Meh. Not really dynamic, but it doesn't affect the gameplay too much.-THE TRAFFIC. Who the heck drives on the left side. 10/10 would crash.-The physics. Some things just look really weird especially when you're driving through everything but you suddenly crash because you hit a sidewalk.-Not enough to do besides the story. You don't have that much sidequests but that's totally fine since the story is so good.Conclusion:If you like games like Mafia, Mafia II and GTA Vice City then you're gonna love this game (at least its story). It just feels like a good thriller.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is a realistic look at the undercover life in the Hong Kong Triads (organized crime) played as a third person open world game. I guess you can compare it to the Grand Theft Auto games or Saints Row games in terms of actual gameplay.  In Sleeping Dogs you’ll find yourself driving in cars for large portions of the game since the game world is actually very large. There’s a fast travel option that I didn’t even know existed until I replayed the game a couple of months ago. The combat in the game is very similar to the Batman Arkham games (strike & counter), but with no gadgets. There are also sections where you’ll use guns, but it’s about 90% hand to hand fighting.Where the game really shines is in story. You’re an undercover cop trying to worm your way into the Triad and slowly get pulled in more and more into the life. It’s how I imagine real undercover cops experience their jobs. Overall I give the game a thumbs up. It seems like every game I review gets a thumbs up, but that’s because if I don’t like a game, I stop playing. Steam offers a free HD textures DLC so everything looks good with the graphics turned way up.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Has the seedy Hong Kong underworld ever called to you? Probably not, but still if you want to imagine being a Triad whilst working for the law then this is the game for you This is a pretty awesome open world GTA style game. It is beautiful to look at and just great fun to walk around and explore. The missions are diverse and plentiful. The story is compelling and very well written. I really felt connected to the characters and invested in what happened to them. And the entire immense story was topped off by a pretty awesome finale.Pretty much every aspect of the gameplay is solid. The driving and combat are robust and feel great. Some of my favourite memories of this game were just driving around the city at full tilt with the cops chasing me shooting out tires and running people off the road. There are a lot of vehicles and each one drives very differently.The combat is great, so much variety and with many ways to beat the hell out of people you won’t get bored. Plus with the ability to learn more skills you will find the fighting even better the further you go. The game also feature contextual take downs, want to slam some guys face into a fan or a window? You can do that and it feels immensely satisfyingThere are also tons of side missions to do such as street racing, gambling and a fight club that you will be busy for hours before even delving into the story itself. Plus with all the available DLC and now the definitive edition you will be able to delve even deeper into what Hong Kong has to offerThis version is no longer available but if I would recommend the definitive edition as it contains even more stuff. If you play this game you will have a great time, it is far superior to its spiritual predecessors and a great intro to a new series. Have fun ^_^

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I felt compelled to write a review for Sleeping Dogs, as it is a game that gave me more bang for my buck than most ever have.  I'm a huge fan of open-world games with driving (GTA, Saints Row, Far Cry).  With that said, I 100%'d Sleeping Dogs at about 30 hours in, and my current playtime is now nearing the 118 mark.  I can count the number of games I've 100%'d on less than two hands.  So, I think the important question is, why do I still keep playing?  What caused me to learn this game inside and out, to the point where I know all the mechanics, glitches, and how to mess with every piece of AI?The answer lies in that to me, Sleeping Dogs is just pure fun.  The melee combat is something that almost no other game has done as well, and really the only one that comes to mind is the Arkham series.  Even with Arkham, I find the combat takes too long, whereas in Sleeping Dogs it gets things just right.  It's visceral while remaining simple.  Enemies react in momentary fear to bone-crushing martial arts moves, and the protagonist Wei Shen can masterfully counter and take out hordes of gangsters.  Wei also moves around Hong Kong with basic parkour moves, as he can survive falls of impressive heights and slide over all manner of objects smoothly, if timed right.The other aspect is driving.  Let me preface this section with two things: one, that I vastly prefer arcade style driving (if I want real driving, I'll go take my real car out), and two, the weapon-based DLC car singlehandedly has given me hours upon hours of extra time with the game.  I'll put this bluntly; if you want realistic driving, go play another game.  Ramming cars at high speeds, tearing through the Financial District with a nearly indestructible bus, and blowing out the tires that sends cars flying like a Hollywood movie... all of its is insanely fun.  Add in the DLC car that pretty much breaks the game, and it just gets hilarious how awesomely you can dominate Hong Kong.Sleeping Dogs is far from perfect, however.  Some of the things the game does are laughably bad, like how the police are handled.  I'm not going to mince words here, the police are just terrible.  They're so bad that they're funny, like with how awful horror movies work.  The biggest issue I have is that they literally pop into an area.  You could be in a desolate alley and shoot someone, or beat up a bunch of people in a quiet street with no police anywhere nearby.. and they will literally pop in like they used a portal gun or stepped through a dimensional rift.  If they weren't so easy to shake off and mess with, this would have ruined any sense of immersion the game had.While I thoroughly enjoyed the story with a satisfying ending, which took me about 15-20 hours with exploration and side missions, you could tell that in some sections, the developers did not have the time to implement other features they wanted.  It's pretty obvious that they wanted to include deeper connections to Hong Kong with Wei with how much exploration and collection there were, along with Wei's serial hit-it-and-quit-it attitude with women.  Wei's struggle with his identity and corruption, both in the Triads and the police force, was a compelling reason for me to finish the story, however.Finally, don't let the DLC scare you.  The DLC mostly adds things in to make the game a little more fun, and none of it is necessary whatsoever.  I know some people who wouldn't sneeze at Sleeping Dogs for the amount of DLC it has, but I doubt they ever actually took a look at what it does.  I really believe that Sleeping Dogs is a game that every fan of this genre should play.  Hong Kong's a relatively fresh setting from similar games, and Sleeping Dogs finds its identity in mechanics that are just fun.  Not crazy whacked up purple♥♥♥♥♥♥♥bat fun like Saints Row, and not maniacal, realistic Trevor fun as in GTA, but just super tight, simple, attractive combat with good pacing and a pretty beautiful world.

												I think Sleeping Dogs is a really fun game.  The story is fast-paced, intense, and intriguing.  The graphics are wonderful, the atmosphere wonderful with some humor thrown in.  The music that plays when you're driving around, for the most part, is great.  Beyond stealing cars and completing missions, the combat elements are excellently done--that goes for firearms and ESPECIALLY for melee combat.  Great DLC as well.  Different outfits aren't just for vanity, but add either a challenging element (like added heat from the police) or additional combat options based off of real martial arts schools.... from drunken master, to wing chun, tai chi chuan, mui tai, mma, etc....  There are some classy and fun automobiles and the races range from easy to very challenging difficulty.  The side activities can be as fun as the main story.  You can learn how to swear in Chinese as well.The only thing that could make this game better is actual nudity for all the hot chix you can date--and even Wei Chen... he's got a hot bod too.  Anyone make those mods yet?  If so, hit me up!  Ha.....

content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs, i.e. "True Crime Hong Kong", is a third-person GTA style free-roamer set in Hong Kong. You play an undercover cop infiltrating the triad known as Song On Yee, and you will swear blood oaths with various triad members, as you understand they are just people like you, yet you will need to bring them to justic at some point. As the story progresses, you will do whatever needs to be done to stay undercover, even if it means eliminating witnessses, kill a few innocents, all for the greater good, perhaps. As the dividing line between good and evil blur, you will find out perhaps not all is as simple as you thought things to be. The various areas of Hong Kong have been simplified but the flavor had been retained. It is big enough to hold races, and various races are already available in the game (with more available via DLC). There are dozens of different vehicles in various classes, plus motorcycles, and if you don't want to run around all day taxis are always avaialble. And there are always tons of things to do (until you manage to do all of them). There are food stands that gives you a boost in various areas, clothing stores to buy outfits (some gives you bonus), car shops to "buy" cars, as well as missions such as clean up a gang near a certain hotspot by beating them up, hack the camera nearby, then call in the cops when a mastermind come along. There are also special crime solving missions that have you chase down leads or car stealing missions where the "dealer" want a particular model of car "obtained". Add that to "collectibles" (found all around town, several different types), and over a dozen DLCs that adds more outfits, more missions, more weapons, and more vehicles, and you have a total experience. The game doesn't skimp on combat either. Most combat is melee involving various forms of kung fu, and you will either fight barehand or with weapon (from cleaver to knife, tire iron to lead pipe) There are a few improvised weapon as well (ever tried... fish?)  There are guns avaiable for certain missions, but they are NOT that popular. in HK. You will learn more moves as you go along. All in all, Sleeping Dogs is GTA in Hong Kong with a TON of options, and it will take you dozens of hours to complete, and you can even challenge other players on the Rockstar "social" web to establish records and such. And the makers are still pumping out the occasional DLC. Just buy them while they're on sale, and enjoy them.

												All I have to say isThis game has surprised me as I am not that much into the GTA/SR games. Ok they are fun for a while but the story does not engage (IMO). Sleeping Dogs has an interesting hand to hand style combat system that at first I did not like, but you learn and improve your skill as you go (which grew on me) and became fun. The story and feel of the game is what keeps me engaged, I want to see how it plays out being an undercover cop in the capacity of infiltrating the Triads. So I recommend this game, especially if you found the GTA/SR storylines not to your liking, perhaps you will be surprised as much as I was by Sleeping Dogs.Yes I do Recommend this game."Why don't you have a pork bun in your hand"

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												This game is awesome! I haven't been bored in this game all that time i spent there. Let's go to Pros 'n' Cons, shall we?Pros-Very detailed fights. You want to punch the hell outta enemies? Sure, you can fight with your bare hands or with various melees. You like gun blazin' more? Sure, grab  a gun from a cop car or buy the DLC that gives you an assault rifle in your apartment. You like to shoot people from a badass car with awesome guns on it? Buy Fury Wheels.-Characters. I really felt for each one of them, like they were alive. I'm not giving much description here, bevlcause I don't want to spoil anything-A crap load of clothes. Some of them give you money economy (Less money to pay) bonuses or fighting bonuses, some of them referred to Valve games. I don't really know, if you get them just for free, or you have to get the games that the clothes are referring to.A lot of cars. From typical cars to supercars, or a supercar with miniguns in Fury Wheels. Every car is unique - the look and the characteristics. -The unique moving car hijacking system. Yes, you heard that right - you can hijack any car, while it's on the move.-Characters upgrades - both as triads and the police.-Fight clubs. Easy money + kick♥♥♥♥♥anytime.-Cheap DLCsCons-Missions. While I liked the story, it is pretty short. There's not that much story missions tbh.Awesome game, 9/10 - go play it, no matter - cracked game or the license, just play it. It's worth it.I'm awaiting you in Valhalla!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												I think Sleeping Dogs is a really fun game.  The story is fast-paced, intense, and intriguing.  The graphics are wonderful, the atmosphere wonderful with some humor thrown in.  The music that plays when you're driving around, for the most part, is great.  Beyond stealing cars and completing missions, the combat elements are excellently done--that goes for firearms and ESPECIALLY for melee combat.  Great DLC as well.  Different outfits aren't just for vanity, but add either a challenging element (like added heat from the police) or additional combat options based off of real martial arts schools.... from drunken master, to wing chun, tai chi chuan, mui tai, mma, etc....  There are some classy and fun automobiles and the races range from easy to very challenging difficulty.  The side activities can be as fun as the main story.  You can learn how to swear in Chinese as well.The only thing that could make this game better is actual nudity for all the hot chix you can date--and even Wei Chen... he's got a hot bod too.  Anyone make those mods yet?  If so, hit me up!  Ha.....
