content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs, i.e. "True Crime Hong Kong", is a third-person GTA style free-roamer set in Hong Kong. You play an undercover cop infiltrating the triad known as Song On Yee, and you will swear blood oaths with various triad members, as you understand they are just people like you, yet you will need to bring them to justic at some point. As the story progresses, you will do whatever needs to be done to stay undercover, even if it means eliminating witnessses, kill a few innocents, all for the greater good, perhaps. As the dividing line between good and evil blur, you will find out perhaps not all is as simple as you thought things to be. The various areas of Hong Kong have been simplified but the flavor had been retained. It is big enough to hold races, and various races are already available in the game (with more available via DLC). There are dozens of different vehicles in various classes, plus motorcycles, and if you don't want to run around all day taxis are always avaialble. And there are always tons of things to do (until you manage to do all of them). There are food stands that gives you a boost in various areas, clothing stores to buy outfits (some gives you bonus), car shops to "buy" cars, as well as missions such as clean up a gang near a certain hotspot by beating them up, hack the camera nearby, then call in the cops when a mastermind come along. There are also special crime solving missions that have you chase down leads or car stealing missions where the "dealer" want a particular model of car "obtained". Add that to "collectibles" (found all around town, several different types), and over a dozen DLCs that adds more outfits, more missions, more weapons, and more vehicles, and you have a total experience. The game doesn't skimp on combat either. Most combat is melee involving various forms of kung fu, and you will either fight barehand or with weapon (from cleaver to knife, tire iron to lead pipe) There are a few improvised weapon as well (ever tried... fish?)  There are guns avaiable for certain missions, but they are NOT that popular. in HK. You will learn more moves as you go along. All in all, Sleeping Dogs is GTA in Hong Kong with a TON of options, and it will take you dozens of hours to complete, and you can even challenge other players on the Rockstar "social" web to establish records and such. And the makers are still pumping out the occasional DLC. Just buy them while they're on sale, and enjoy them.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												Having recently played through all the big open world games this has got to be my favourite, it really does draw you in. It does not loose focus like the saints row do(still great games though) and it has hands down the best city in an open world game, it is so alive especially at night. Does a great job of making you feel like you are in hong kong. The story gets better and better as it goes along, it may be padded with alot of side missions but they are fun and fit the story/your character well. The characters in the game are very believable and well written and the over all story/tone of the game is of an adult nature.I would easily rate it above watch dogs and saints row 4(two most recent open world games that take place in cities).This was the original launch version without any of the unbalanced dlc that came later.9/10

content:
Posted: February 5
												Its a shame this studio shut down. I previously tried this game a while back and just couldnt get into it.  I decided to give it another go and it pulled me in enough to solve it.  After getting the handle on the combat and arcade style driving, I started to enjoy this one.  The story was good, the graphics decent, and the gameplay was fun.  It would have been nice to see a part 2 of this series with some cleaned up graphics to carry on the story.  I found it was lacking some depth in extra missions, e.g. girlfriend missions made you feel like more was going to happen in them and they just sort of ended.  All in all, it was worth the play through and I am glad I didnt shelf this one.  If you can get it for cheap, it's worth a pick up as it is a few years old now.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs is a triple A storyline with hollywood level voice acting and action, but it's hampered by terrible controls and lousy gameplay. Almost every vehicle drives like a boat and the boats like a fat man on an oiled sled across an ice rink. And that's too bad since so much of the game revolves around driving. Wei Shen doesn't control much better on foot. Outside of the melee combat he controls like a boat as well, clumsily trying to navigate around the numerous obstacles and people in his way. Combined with a poor choice of key mapping, get ready for some very frustrating firefights and chase sequences where you may think you have it in the bag only to be stopped at the very end by an open car door and buggy quick action events.I really want to love this game, in fact, I find the story and atmosphere so engrossing that I'm forcing myself to get past the lousy gameplay for it. Sleeping Dogs would have been an amazing linear action game instead of this open world design which I honestly think was done just to pad out game length. But none of the side quests, collecting, upgrades, money mean anything. There simply isn't anything on which to spend all the money you receive. They tried for GTA and failed. I could best compare it to games like LA Noir.Sleeping Dogs could have been a memorable game, but the compelling story keeps getting interrupted by unnecessary junk and the poorly ported controls. It's worth the experience for the story alone, but I wouldn't pay more than a few bucks for the PC cash-in port.

Sleeping Dogs would have been an amazing linear action game instead of this open world design which I honestly think was done just to pad out game length. But none of the side quests, collecting, upgrades, money mean anything. There simply isn't anything on which to spend all the money you receive. They tried for GTA and failed. I could best compare it to games like LA Noir.Sleeping Dogs could have been a memorable game, but the compelling story keeps getting interrupted by unnecessary junk and the poorly ported controls. It's worth the experience for the story alone, but I wouldn't pay more than a few bucks for the PC cash-in port.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Is this game woth it?HECK YES! This game is fantastic and it should be in any sandbox gamer's collection.The story line is absolutely fantastic and although you don't make too many options yourself you become weishen and you get so torn up about who you feel more loyal to, the triads that you only just met but feel like family or the law and the consequences going rogue could have. The story line is one of the best i've seen, better than GTA.The world itself is completely immersive, i've only been to japan so I sort of know what an asian style would be like, but square enix really went the extra mile to make this the real hong kong. You know when you're going through GTA and you feel like you've seen the same shop fifty times before, that's because you have. In this besides the shops and businesses you go into almost every shop seems different, on top of that no area seems replicated, it feels like this is the true sandbox game because it is so bloody diverse, never played another game like it.What lacks in guns is made up in the fantastic combat system. Ever watched a bruce lee movie and been like, oh yeah I'll take up martial arts because it's so cool. This game produces the result you desire in such an easy but satisfactory manner. It's easy to learn, and easy to use and some of the attacks are just brutal. The fact of the matter is if you're quick you can take on a pack of 10+ people no problems, just like bruce lee and jackie chan.The cars, especially the sports cars are awesome to drive, also the street racing (also on bikes) is exilerating and awesome. When you start rolling in the cash you can have anything you want!There's just so much to do, ♥♥♥♥ (roosters) fighting, street racing, gambling, fight clubs, etc. And the huge array of side jobs for randoms that can pay well but also give you the satisfaction for helping people you don't know, pushing up your prestige. I mainly love the ones where you get out to help someone but it's a con and someone tackles you and steals your money. It's so satisfactory to beat the living shizzle out of them when you catch up to them, and maybe grab a few extra dollars of their own money.So yes, this game is worth it, GTA might be the fun shoot em up, but it's a mindless series (referring mainly to GTA 4). This game has the life and diversity of a true masterpiece and it has more ups than downs. It's also received very well by most critics.I also finished the story line however I keep coming back to play the sandbox of the game. The only other game that did that for me was GTA III. Vice, San Andreas and 4 didn't have that, so that's really saying something!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is a great game that is not without its flaws but has won a place in my heart nonetheless. Once you get past the stunning visuals, you are met with an immersive underworld set in Hong Kong where an undercover officer climbs the ranks of the triads while being forced to consider his own loyalties.Unlike other games in the genre, the combat is primarily focused on the melee aspect. Officer Shen is a very competent martial artist, and learns more moves and improves the ones he knows as the game progresses. The system feels fresh at the game's onset, but by the game's finish, it loses some of its charm. It is very visually pleasing, but from a gameplay point of view, it is very easy to master the moveset and dominate enemies under all circumstances. This does, however, propagate the sensation of being the invincible hero of the traditional asian fighting movies from which Sleeping Dogs no doubt has drawn significant amounts of inspiration.Story-wise, the atmoshpere is great. Being in Hong Kong, people speak both English and Chinese, and you often hear the two intertwined. One of the most unusal parts was, in fact, getting used to driving primarily on the left side of the road. You are met with a good deal of characters, some memorable even after one encounter, but many of them are unfortunately flat. This is due mostly to having too little exposure to each of them, the average being two missions for each character - one where you meet them, and one where you do them a favor of some sort. Most benefitted from interesting missions, but there were a few cases in which I felt I'd wasted my time. This deficit applies primarily to the side missions. It is worth noting that some of the side missions fall into extremes; some were very humorous and/or interesting, and some were excruciatingly boring.Racing constitutes a major side activity, and it is decently implemented for a game that focuses on other aspects. You can purchase cars and use them in races, many of which take you through challenging routes. I often felt myself remembering the feeling I had playing Need For Speed Underground while playing through the races in the game. (It's a good feeling)For the primary missions, the cast is built out of stereotypes, but they play their parts well and the story itself, while having some cliche elements, is pleasurable to go through and does have a few unexpected twists. Since you are a police officer in parallel to being a triad member, this opens up a series of circumstances that were especially pleasing to see playing out. The main character is also very likeable, being a smooth talker when the need arises. There are a few moments that are absolutely impossible, such as surviving a shotgun blast in close range or taking down dozens of triad cars on the street like it's nothing, but those can be forgiven since Sleeping Dogs is an action game.The most irksome parts were getting around and going after collectibles. Getting around was immersive at first - you got to see the nooks and crannies of Hong Kong, and there were plenty of very well-detailed areas to enjoy. However, as you progress later into the game, you find yourself constantly wanting to be on the other side of the map, and with often no taxis in sight, the drive that can take several minutes gets tiring. An especially brutal offender was the naval part: getting on or off boats was extremely tiresome, primarily because of invisible walls that made it very hard to transition between sea and land.The collectibles became annoying to deal with because many of them were placed in impossibly hard to reach positions that took ages to scout out for possible entry points. Also, you are heavily coerced into going after two of the three types of collectibles, as you need them to improve your fighting skills and health pool, both of which can pose a serious problem in the later parts of the game if ignored.Finally, I'd like to mention the game's soundtrack. As is usual with such games, there are a number of radio stations, each catering to a different taste. I found myself enjoying several stations personally, and the commentary and advertisements between tracks were well-done and immersive.This sums up how I feel about the game, having just finished it less than an hour ago. I mention the game's shortcomings a lot because those made the experience less enjoyable, but it was definitely a game I enjoyed overall and would recommend to others. It compensates well for what it lacks through solid mechanics, a virtual Hong Kong teeming with detail and a plot that manages to keep the player engaged from start to finish.

The story about loyalty and dutyThis game tells you about Wei "Kick-All-Asses" Shen. Fomer triad member wich was converted by the police and now working for them to destroy the Triad from the inside. Yes, this is about undecover cop with sense of duty AND loyalty to the Triad.I was expecting some storyline choices and "take a side" quest in the end, but that won't happen. This game doesn't give you any choices at all. You just follow the story line.All datings are absolutely boring, most of the side missions are the same and the world itself feel a bit dead and empty. Nothing crazy happens like in GTA or Just Cause.But, I liked it. A lot of Kung Fu moves, finishers, Triad charm and cliches f.e. massacre at wedding/funeral. The plot of the game looks more like movie and voice acting is great. Combat is the same as in Batman (it feels really good).Long story short, if you looking for open world game with good story and Hong Kong involved than this game is for you. Otherwise don't look at it.P.S. DLC's are great though.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												Sleeping Dogs experienced anything but a sleepy development cycle. Originally set to be a title in the True Crime franchise, the project was cancelled by publisher Activision when almost being ready, much to the disappointment of developers United Front Games. However, in stepped Square Enix and with their assistance and a small re-branding, the game was back on track. Despite these dramatic events, players will be happy to know that Sleeping Dogs is a fun and diverse open world experience with tons to do, an engaging and serious story, and a memorable and authentic setting. Small gameplay issues and potential lack of variety aside, this is an enjoyable and respectably lengthy outing that can hold its ground against the leaders of the genre. Read the full review[www.newgamenetwork.com]

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												At first glance, this may look like an Asian GTA Ripoff, but there's much more to it than that. It's an admirable open-world third-person action game, but it's a lot more fun than GTA IV (bar not having multiplayer). Sure, there's guns every once in a while, but you will be relying on your hands and feet more often, disarming enemies simply to get back to honorable fighting. It's somewhat similar to the recent Batman games in that regard.I would highly recommend this game if you need a refreshing breath from typical sandbox action games, optimized for PC to look pretty with a reasonably powered hardware setup (and you get a free HD texture pack option through Steam when you buy the game, if you feel the fidelity of the graphics aren't awe-inspiring enough already). Wouldn't recommend getting all of the DLC, though, there's only a select few that add to the game while not making the game too easy. I don't want to spoil anything about the story, but it's certainly kept my attention throughout.I give it 4.5 out of 5 apples.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												This game makes no attempt to hide its influences...  The open-world criminality of GTA.  Batman's 1-vs-many melee combat.  Mirror's Edge style free-running.  Acrobatic hijackings straight out of Just Cause 2.  Cover shooting, a la Gears of War.  Innumerable cop movies and Bruce Lee movies get huge nods.  And it works.Every idea Sleeping Dogs borrows is done less well than in the game or film that inspired it, but its success lies in the blend.  The fistfights are much better than in GTA, you go on kill-crazy rampages undreamed of in Batman, and one of the side missions is basically "Enter The Dragon", complete with cheesy '70s film grain effects.  What more could you want?

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs is probably going to be my favourite game this year. It’s hard to imagine why Activision wanted to scrap this game as it really excels well as a sandbox game and has refined how we see the genre altogether.The story is amazing and can hold its own compared to Mafia 2 / GTA4. The combat is great, as well as movement; it’s very responsive compared to GTA4. Car’s are slightly arcade-ish to handle - but considering you can hijack cars and do slow motion shoot-outs it works out pretty well.Overall Sleeping Dogs is a love letter to Hong Kong cinema; I’ve been mesmerized by its tiny immaculate detail which gives this game so much charisma and charm. Truly one the great gems of this generation.On a last note, the PC version is just amazing, advance PC options and day 1 HD textures really show that United Front is committed to the PC. Listening to Ninja Tune radio while driving a motorbike down a wet and rainy neon lit sky is just pure bliss.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs adds its name to the ever growing list of genuinely good open-world action adventure games. The melee combat focus threw me off at first, but after switching to a gaming controller, the gameplay felt significantly more intuitive over a mouse & keyboard. The intertwined story of undercover cop and bad♥♥♥♥♥Triad Sun On Yee Red Pole is impressively put together. Sleeping Dogs comes off every bit as an AAA title with superb graphics, voice acting, and gameplay. Plus the amazing assortment of radio stations and musical flavors is extraordinary.Even though most of the side missions felt underwhelming, repetitive, and in many cases downright boring, I found myself continuously getting distracted trying to complete them, or stopping to seek out that next health upgrade or lockbox. I realize now it was the reward element that made them so addicting--always granting some new unlock or item reward. The taxi service is a nice feature if you want to get somewhere fast, although the car handling feels very similar to GTA San Andreas which makes driving good fun. Also the DLC adds a good variety of worthwhile content as well.Two thumbs up.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												I want to love Sleeping Dogs more than you can imagine. It’s colorful, spectacularly detailed, controls perfectly, it’s well optimized, the story and missions are compelling and varied, everything about it is fantastic. Sadly I just don’t enjoy brawling. Yes, there is gunplay in Sleeping Dogs (and it’s just as well executed as the rest of the game) but it takes a very definitive back seat to the martial arts combat system.In all my years gaming the only brawling/martial arts combat game I have ever truly sunken into is the Batman franchise. The combat in Sleeping Dogs does not have quite the same fluidity as Batman but it is still very responsive and well done. To be honest, I don’t quite know why it is that Batman is fun to me but the combat in Sleeping Dogs isn’t; I don’t believe that minor difference in fluidity is the defining flaw. So it’s a brawler whose combat I dislike, no recommendation right? Wrong. Despite the backbone of the game being brawling, the game as a whole is an open world GTA style sandbox and there were so many hours of content that I absolutely loved.If you’re not a brawling fan, Sleeping Dogs may not be something you think you would enjoy, but there is a lot there that the trailers and screenshots leave out.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												I spent actual money to buy DLC for this game, that is how much I love it.The story takes place in Hong Kong and it's your undercover cop who infiltrates a triad well known to him, and the love for his friends and his duty will be in conflict throughout the game. What elevates this story from the rest is the excellent voice acting and compelling characters that are both believeable and relateable.The game is an open-world third-person action shooter. The combat is an improved version of the Batman: Arkham games formula, with the introduction of combos, melee weapons (like cleavers, batons and even fish!!), environmental executions and guns that, at first, feel kind of awkward, but I got used to them.There is a lot of side activities in the world to complete: doing favors to increase fame, take part in illegal races, wipe out hidden triad gangs and sing karaoke.The graphics are impressive, and the game really shines at night time. The city does feel alive, even though most of the pedestrians are walking or talking on a phone. The soundtrack is full of both chinese and english songs, with plenty of radio stations to choose from.However, this game is far from perfect: the biggest complaint I have is that, when you have beaten all the story missions and favours and races, there is nothing to do. Trying to get involved in car chases with the police doesn't help since you will have upgrades that reduce heat faster than ever.Overall, it's a fun game to spend time to, with a compelling story and many side activities, even though at the end there is nothing else to do.SCORE: 89/100

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												I really enjoyed Sleeping Dogs, I spent a good hundred hours or so on it on my xbox before purchasing it on steam.The BasicsSleeping Dogs is an open world, third person sandbox game, set in Hong Kong. I really liked the setting of the game, as it's something different than the ususal, small things like, driving on the left side of the road made the game a bit more interesting than it would've been, should they have left details like this out. The story revolves around Wei, an undercover cop sent to take down the mafia that operates in Hong Kong.The GameplaySleeping Dogs has amazing fighting mechanics, it mostly revolves around melee combat, and guns are only used when absolutely neccesary. Because of this, Sleeping Dogs stands out from it's rivals, the melee combat is fluent, fun and never gets old. The gun mechanics are good, but nothing special or exceptional, just plain old shooting. The Melle however has a LOT of combos, and that makes for good variation, you can also execute enemies using the enviroment, giving you bonus points while finishing off an enemy in style. Driving mechanics is the only thing I dislike about this game and while you get used to them after an hour or so, they still bug me. The cars handle extremely unrealistic and I would consider that this games major flaw.I do really like how well-optimised the game is for PC, it's an exceptional port with settings like 'world densitiy', which will determine how many pedestrians, cars etc there will be in the world.The GraphicsSleeping Dogs looks good, and the world feels alive and immersive, especially at night. The game's true beauty comes out when you're driving through the city at night, with all the neon lighting and advertising creating a beautiful lit up picture. So yes, this game looks good and I'm sure it'll age well.To Summarize+Great fighting mechanics, very refreshing melee combat.+Good gunplay, though nothing exceptional.+Amazing setting.+Attention to detail.+Graphics are really nice looking.+Great PC-port.-Driving mechanics leave something to be desired.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Sleeping dogs is an average open-world sandbox game, similar to the GTA series. However, gun fights are rare in sleeping dogs and combat comes mainly in the form is mainly fist-fights with weapons, multiple hit combos and quick-time event blocks, which I personally find more satisfying. However, the world isn't as big as modern GTA games and there isn't much to explore or do after the main missions.

Posted: July 6, 2014
												Decent game in the GTA genre, although the cars are nigh indestructible here (which admittedly can be a lot of fun). The story is a little disjointed in parts but overall very good. The game has more melee/kung fu fighting than gunfighting, although there is a fair share of the latter. You play an undercover cop infiltrating one of the strongest Triads in Hong Kong, and the story is about family, loyalty, betrayal, and where your own loyalties lie.I would rate this game a 6/10; there are a few things that keep it from really shining. As I mentioned above, the story seems disjointed in parts. You will meet a girl, call her once to hang out, and then she is never seen or heard from again. This happens on multiple occasions, with no explanation as to what happened to her. A few of the main storyline missions also thrust you into situations that don't make sense or haven't been properly explained, as well. It's not enough to ruin the game, and you figure out what's going on quickly enough, but it just feels unpolished, almost like there were supposed to be missions in between or a linking storyline to tie it together better, that got left out for some reason.My two biggest gripes about the game are that your character Wei Shen, is basically Superman, able to take on up to 12+ guys at once with his Kung Fu that would put Bruce Lee to shame. He is also able to absorb an apparently infinite amount of bullets, as long as you let him rest for a few seconds in between getting shot. The second big complaint is the wardrobe/clothing system in the game. Different outfits give different bonuses, like extra melee damage or increased xp gain. You can mix and match different things like shirts, pants, shoes, sunglasses, and other accessories to gain various set bonuses. The problem is that it is extremely tedious trying to put together a set with a good bonus that also looks halfway decent. I spent most of the game wearing a pair of sunglasses that made me look like I belonged on the set of Jersey Shore, which made cutscenes where I'm talking to the Triad leader about loyalty and other Deep Sh*t™ just laughable. It didn't ruin my enjoyment of the game, it just made certain parts seem pretty silly. Imagine taking down a group of 8 or 10 rival Triads while wearing a straw sombrero, purple shoes, a giant neon green watch, idiotic sunglasses (at night), beach shorts, and a puffy jacket.Overall, I would recommend this game if you like the GTA genre, but I got this game on sale ($4) and got about 24 hours of enjoyment out of it. A very good value if you ask me; YMMV.

Posted: April 27, 2014
												Very nice open world game and pretty polished. Some aspects do come off as gimmicky, like the face-meter. When you complete a couple of side-missions and you're wearing stuff that's giving you a bonus face percentage when completing these missions, your face-meter is already at max halfway through the game. Graphics are very nice, espcecially when it's raining (and it's raining a lot!) the roadreflections look really cool.Story is okay, but I tended to get out of the flow when doing all the other stuff that there's to do. Side-missions can get pretty repetitive or tedious even, but I still got the urge to do every one of them, because there actually is a lot of gameplay on offer. For instance hi-jacking moneytrucks was a really cool thing to do (actually hi-jacking any car was), where the races actually could be kind of frustrating and hacking camera's was just addicting (and there's a lot more to do!).  Combat in this game felt reminiscent of that in the Batman games although not done as well imo. This was mainly because of the not-too-good camera-work. Being able to make use of the environment while in combat made up for this. It's really satisfactory slamming some bad-guy's head into a car door while seeing the glass shatter all around.All in all if you like open-world games like GTA this is definitely for you. For 4 bucks or euro's you can't go wrong. It's sure to keep you interested for a couple of dozens of hours.

Posted: May 18, 2014
												So i'm sitting here with my plate of noodles, thinking what to say about Sleeping Dogs. Since it is one of those games that i'm two minds about. On one hand, it delivers a well crafted and realised Hong Kong cop-drama, but on the other hand, it feels like a very lackluster open-world game. A bit of history, this game started off as a continuation to the True Crime series, but for reasons i cannot remember at this point, the development stopped. And  i think the game was saved in part by that decision. True Crime was not considered to be the best of series and if Sleeping Dogs (At time of original development True Crime:Hong Kong) it would have just fallen into obscurity with the rest, only to be remembered by the fans of the series. But does Sleeping Dogs survive on its own Or does it deserve the long sleep ?STORY:The story follows Wei Shen, an undercover cop sent to covertly infiltrate one of Hong Kongs famous triad gangs. And since i try my best to avoid spoilers, i will only summarize. That the story is heavily influensed by many of the famous Hong Kong cop-movies. And it is interesting enough to warrant playing through more than once.GAMEPLAY:Unfortunately for the game, the open-world nature really does it no favours. On the other hand it offers a very lively representation of Hong Kong and on the other it feels useless. There really is not enough content to warrant an open world, no random flippentry to perform besides some of the social challenges things and annoying the police. And that is about it. One oddity, that i believe also alienated some of the playerbase. Is the scarce amount of firearms, the game is mostly centered around melee combat and the system they used is so similiar to the Arkham-series that it feels almost like it was ripped off. But what there is, is functional enough. There are enviromental attacks that are flashy but a tad lengthy and a few other minor issues with the combat system.The game has a great number of glitches and bugs, some are funny and some are absolutely infuriating. Most of theese bugs are centered around the freerunning system, i feel like it should have been polished a little more for the pc-version. Since  the game was designed for consoles, there are also some annoying problems with the camera. Overall, the porting could have been done much better.SOUND DESIGN:Like GTA, theres a decent amount of copyrighted music. Nothing to be annoyed about, but nothing to remember neither. The only funny thing is, that there is a karaoke-bar, with actual karaoke. A pattern minigame, but worth it to listen Weis voice actors vo over the song. Yes, they went there...CONCLUSION:Considering the problems that Sleeping Dogs, could i recoommend it ? Short answer, YES. Long answer, the game feels padded out lengthwise, several minor problems deteriorate the gameplay experince, optional activities feel like diversions, experience leveling is questionable and the rewards they give are minor to say the least. The story is the only thing that is supposed to carry the game, but does it ? Not really...I would give this game a C+. It feels a little low, but as i have tried to explain, the only thing worth something in this game is the story it tells and really nothing else. What there is on the activities side, is forgettable and getting a 100% feels like a wasted effort.

Posted: May 28, 2014
												I fell in love with this game the first time I played it. I'd been on the fence regarding buying it since I'd heard a few detractors saying it wasn't as good as GTA. I love the GTA series, but this tops them. Why? Because not only the story is good, but also the fighting mechanic - GTA was never good at fighting, it was all about driving and shooting. Sleeping Dogs brings in the Arkham series' style of freeflow fighting (though not as good as the Arkham games, it's not far off) as well as cool things like being able to jump from one car to another to hijack vehicles, take hostages, have bullet time vault shootings and much more.The game is 2 years old but still looks as good, if not better (at times), than Watch Dogs. It runs really well, too. I was able to run it at ultra settings the day it came out, even with the hi-res PC-only texture pack that was released. Nowadays, I can run it at 2880x1620 (and would expect to run it at 4k, if my monitor supported it).If you've been disappointed by Watch Dogs, then give this a try - I personally find it's more fun than Watch Dogs, allows you to interact with the other people in the environment more and has a great fighting system. It doesn't have all the hacking stuff, and is more action-orientated than stealth based, but that's not always a bad thing in the open world genre.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												When I started playing Sleeping Dogs, I haven't had much expectations. "Just another GTA-like, open world game". Well, I was wrong. The game has strong characters, good story (for an open world game, at least), really satisfying combat system: melee as well as shooting. Though the best thing about it was, in my opinion, the world. Honk Kong looks and feels alive. Unlike many other games in this genre, you can really feel as if you were in the city. Obviously, it is not perfect, but the feel of the city is really good.Game has it's problems, but I never econquered any game-breaking bugs. PC port is decent, but it has a hard time with using the cursor in game menus. Other than that, nothing of importance found.I recommend the game to anyone who wants to have a little fun. Especially if you're bored with games which take place in the US. This game offers something different, but in a way that guarantees that you won't get TOO much of the Honk Kong culture.

Posted: February 28, 2014
												So, I have just beaten Sleeping Dogs. I must say, this game is probably the best game to have come out in 2012. You play as Wei Shen, an undercover Hong Kong police officer who has the task of infiltrating the biggest triad in Hong Kong: Sun On Yee. The story is set up beautifully, almost like a chess board. You start out working with the other pawns in the triad and as the story evolves, you meet all the other pieces of the board. And like in the game of chess, pieces are moved and taken away as the game progresses. The charecters are also very black and white like chess pieces in which you know who your enemies are, and you know who your friends are. There's no reach-arounds or deception, which is a plus in this sort of game. Gameplay is very much like a stew. There are pieces of other games that are brewed together and made into something good and unique. You have the freerunning of Assassin's Creed, the combat is very much like the Batman series of games, the HUD layout is almost exactly like Grand Theft Auto IV's. The driving is actually kinda bad in the game because all the cars and motorcycles go incredibly fast for the tight confines of Hong Kong's streets. But when you ride shotgun in a car and do the shooting while an AI drives, it is amazing.The content in this game is nearly unending. You have a ton of side missions, street races, drug busts, dates, clothing and cars to buy, cop missions, and even more if you get some of the DLC. The main missions are quite well done, though there doesn't seem to be much creativity put into them. But that's okay, because the game is just so fun you don't really notice it until you look back on it. The charecters are very good in the game. With your own charecter, you get to see the battle he has with himself, the police, and the triads. You see him start to blur the lines and get his hands dirty while trying to keep on the straight and narrow. You get attached easily and heartbroken when bad things happen. I think the charecters are the best aspect they did of this game. I would say my final rating will have to be a 10/10. There is almost nothing wrong in this game. Highly recommended.

Posted: April 25, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs provides the player to be a part of undercover cop with strong and engrossing narrative set in open-world. Once again, it is always compared to GTA-like games, but Sleeping Dogs has proved itself to be high potential sandbox. The production is easily noticeable; plot, voice acting, and environment are simply amazing. The cities are highly detailed and full of NPCs walking around and perform their activities based on situation. If Kane and Lynch: Dog Days takes player to the darkest side of China, then Sleeping Dogs will bring player to richly-detailed and diverse environment in Hong Kong from the old slums and night market to the business districts.The gameplay is another strong point. The main missions are pretty diverse and well connect to the storyline. The game offers you many types of mini-game like plant a bug, picklock, cracking safe which give you feeling of being undercover cop. Martial arts is easy to learn and achieve as you proceed through the game, you will unlock more fighting style to beat different types of enemy; knock, stun, combo, and environment kills give a very satisfied outcome and well entertained. The gunplay has simple mechanics; fire behind cover or slide on object to activate slow-motion (like a John Woo’s films). Both running chase scenes and driving are well-made for badass feeling like shooting tires to take down enemy vehicles or hijack vehicle and continue your road carnage. Moreover, the ramming mechanics during driving is simply useful as you can use it to lose the cops or even boost your speed in race. Sleeping Dogs also rewards player in every mission and collectables which keep on player engagement and provide meaningful collectable. However, the side mission is quite less creative and combat is quite sluggish. Still, there is a lot of detail and things to do even you complete the game.Lastly, the radio music is memorable with old Chinese song and some are from famous singer. The mixture of voice between pure Cantonese and English dub create the feel of player’s presence and preserve what Hong Kong should be.Sleeping Dogs is unique and diverse as I said. The developers care in most details and know what keep on player engagement. It gives me very great experience to be part of Hong Kong and triad life. I never regret for every buck I spend on this game. Like it or not, you have to taste once.

												This is my favourite game of all time. The graphics are beautiful, not texture wise, but how densely populated the city is, it's gorgeous. The models of the main game characters are just wonderful. The combat feels nice and smooth, and it feels great to fight. Gunplay is fun, and there is not to much of it, which I really like. Posted: January 4, 2014
												Easily my favorite sandbox action game. If you don't know Mandarin and Cantonese, and have never been to Hong Kong you might miss out on just a little bit of the ironic humor and charm of the game. Moments of dialogue like, "Wei Shen (sic Xian), you are a dangerous man." Funny because the protagonist's name is a Mandarin homophone for "dangerous." There is even a radio station for canto-rap/hip-hop. But there is more than enough to enjoy if you are a fan of Hong Kong cinema, kung fu, and over-the-top sandbox action games. Over-the-top because there are some outrageous enviornmental kills, enemy vehicles explode when you shoot out their tires at high speeds, vaulting from cover gives you bullet time that will keep going as long as you can keep stringing together headshots. All of which add to the feeling that you are starring in the John Woo version Infernal Affairs. While it may be hard to believe that an undercover cop could avoid more serious consequences for causing so much mayhem, the story is still enjoyable and is great at delivering on the expectations it creates. The weakest part of the game for the PC version is the driving, turning up the motion blur helps but driving still has less feedback than it did on my console.

												I love this game a Hong Kong Based Open World adventure like GTA. But your a policeman undercover so a little less killing a lot of kung fu and training. A ton of other cool missions and a bunch of hidden lockboxes,statues and prayer zones the more you find the more your health score maxes out.This game reminds me of the original Shenmue series that was on Sega Dreamcast many years ago and the newer Yakuza franchise that was out on PS3. Posted: February 24, 2013
												This game has one of the best stories I have ever experienced. Wei Shen is a great character that I really connected to, and I really started to like Jackie Ma too, not to mention Winston, Peggy, and Uncle Po. You never really know what to expect next in the plot- one second you'll be attending a funeral, the next a rival gang brings the police to arrest you. The ending was also extremely heartbreaking. The slow motion shooting in cars is very cool, the"parkour" flawless, the driving fun. There are a plethora of missions and side missions, which you can replay, as well as unlockables spread throughout Hong Kong. Fast traveling is immersive (you have to hire a taxi) and food, drinks, and massages have different game-changing effects on you. The graphics are also very good. The neon lights in the commercial areas are beautiful, and areas such as the Night Market, Victoria Peak, and the ramps at the docks made me keep coming back. I wouldn't like to think about this game not coming out. It's one of my favorite games of all time.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												When it comes to fights in games (especially in a way of martial arts), I am always very excited. And this game has it both: Martial Arts and Weapons. Although there are some sequences in the story that you cant get through without weapons, a lot of missions , especially these at the start, will get you deeper in the system of martial arts in the game. You will hardly ever have a problem to fight your enemies in a melee fight as the combos have been developed very accurate and simple for you. You dont have to push 20 similar buttons on the keyboard to do the roundhouse kick, you simply klick on your mouse 5 times. In some cases the time you get for hitting a counter may be a bit slow, but in general the fighting system is very pleseant for me. With a lot more combos you can learn with ingame progress, the amount of them seems almost endless.The story of Sleeping dogs will let you take a closer look into the Hongkongs Underground Organization Sun-On Yee.  Including Undercover Cops , a shootout on a wedding , a funeral and many more things, the story is both touching and exciting. Even after finishing the storyline there are a lot more things you can do in Hongkong. Upgrading your wardrobe, filling your garage with more vehicles and collect pickups for new combos are just a few of them.As the graphics of the game didnt have any downs for me (Note: For me graphics are not that important), I can only recommend the game to you.Have Fun! :)

Posted: February 6, 2014
												A very enjoyable open world action game. One of my absolute favourite mechanics of the game is the easy interchangeability between keyboard+mouse and gamepad which is damn handy for a person who has not played shooters on console all that much. I used my X360 gamepad for the driving and martial arts parts of the game and switched to keyboard+mouse for the shooting parts. It is also surprising how easy one gets used to driving on the left (wrong side!) of the road.The story itself isn't spectacular, but is it entertaining and I'd personally say does an admirable job at telling an undercover police story. The voice acting is also very good and surprisingly there are a good number of famous people lending their voice.This game though has VERY many DLCs. Some of them though are free, but others are mainly cosmetic where they add some outfits or vehicles or weapons. There are also others like the Police Protection Pack which just added a single mission and that was it, although later made the stuff in that mission available in the rest of the game. You also have two content DLC which add a few hours of gameplay with missions tied to Halloween (Nightmare at North Point) and Chinese New Year (Year of the Snake). There is also the SWAT pack, where you do random police missions disguised as a SWAT member. These DLC are entirely optional so might be worth picking up at a discount.

Posted: December 27, 2014
												A very good game.The star of the game is obviously Hong-Kong itself. I have no idea if it bears any ressemblance to the real city, but Hong-Kong in Sleeping Dogs is a town bustling with life, with shops everywhere and citizens going about their business. It feels like an actual place where people live, rather than a succession of hotspots for a player to experience like you find in other sandbox games. For someone not native to an Asian culture, it's also a very attractive jump into a different culture.As for the gameplay, it's solid. The car handling is great, and it's a real pleasure to drive around the city, just for fun. The melee fight, though somewhat limited, is still satisfying, especially after you get a few upgrades that allow you to fight like you want. As for the gunfight, it's extremely fun, especially the action scenes when you're gunning down enemies while in a car. It feels like an HK-action film.However, the game is not perfect. The story is servicable, but not much more. It's somewhat disjointed here and there, and not believable at all. There are also a few things that lack polish, like the Car Valet system which fail you regularly for unknown reasons, or the taxi system, which use the same button as the car thief, making for some awkward mistakes. Theses are small things, but they do add up, and that's something you wouldn't find in Saint Rows III or GTA IV (even though i dislike that game). Finally, the game is too easy, with no way to customize the difficulty, which is somewhat sad for people looking for a challenge.On the whole, the game provides a very nice experience, especially if you enjoy the Asian setting. But in the heavy weight category of open-city sandboxes, its few misteps make it falls down a notch compared to games like Arkham City (which has a much better melee combat), or Saint Rows III (which has more variety and polish). Still if you like the open-world genre, you will not regret buying Sleeping Dogs.

												a pretty decent sand box game. im not a fan of the hardcore parkour things they tried pulling off, like freerunnings cool but its literally just press space to do x when it comes to running.this games also notorious for QTE in the middle of fights or just in general its ♥♥♥♥ing disgraceful. sometimes the game doesnt even respond mainly because its not that great of a pc port. you might have to reassign keys to get past certain QTEs mainly because the game doesnt responddrivings a mixed bag. again, this is a pretty okay pc port, so there's obviously some kinks. it's super hard to pull off sharp turns and in general its annoying to do what you want to. however, there is a system implemented to make driving easier. it allows you to shift lanes on the fly. its hell to get used to, but it can help you out in the long run. ontop of that, you can switch cars... from your own car. theres racing but surprisingly, its even worse than GTAIV's street races.gunplay is... generic. i dont like how the guns are in this game, every gun in this game feels loose and sloppy. the bullets really dont go where you want them to. there's also a way to slow down time, but thats only if you execute a hardcore parkour ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t maneuver. in the end, the gun play will make you wish that you're playing max payne or something. in short it's crude, unrefined and uninspiredthe martial arts aspect of the game is cool, but really it's just clicking the mouse button X amount of times and holding it to perform some move. theres a lot of ways to finish off your opponents with "environment kills". it can get a bit sloppy especially with the amount of enemies they throw at you in some parts, other than that it's probably the biggest mechanic they focused on.given that your character is essentially an azn batman, he also can hack into anything and pick locks. lockpicking is probably the most braindead puzzle in the entire game, as it only serves to waste your time. locating calls is interesting but its just a memory game. planting bugs is just... why? its literally just holding down onto an arrow key and moving your mouse around in a box until you find the right place. hacking into computers/cameras is essentially just a really simple numbers game. other than that, they're really basic mini-games.the best aspect of this game is how it brings together all of these generic and mediocre mechanics together with it's storymode. its story telling is really what keeps the game playable, at least for me. get the game when its on a sale, it's defnitely worth a purchase but not for the 25 dollar asking price.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												I know, it looks like i've only played this game for seven hours, but a few days after I bought it, it went free on xbox (my luck), and I thought I might as well play it there for the achievments (steam achievments are useless). I first thought this game would be mediocre, as I haven't heard anything about it. Luckily, I gave it a shot for $5 on steam, and it turned out to be the best game of 2012 imo. This game is like GTA expect better. Now, before the fanboys come charging in, let me explain. Its melee is far better than GTA, its story is one of the best stories in a game in recent memory, and was good enough to make me actually want to beat it. The driving is at least better than gtaIV (gtaV may be better than SD, never played it), and the gunpay was about the same as gta. I will say the open world is a bit lacking though, and there aren't enough side missions. The setting was better too, it was a nice change from the typical LA or NYC.  Now, back to the story. It is good all around, but the last 3 hours or so really blew me away.  The character development was so good that *spoilers* I was cheering and clapping at the end when I finally got to grind up (I mean grind up, I threw him in an ice grinder) the main enemy, and then, five minutes later, I was cheering again when *more spoilers* I jailed the ***hole police chief for life. It was very touching and overall a great end to a great game. Please support this game, the publisher think it was a commercial failure even though it sold over 2 million copies. This is one of the best games i've played in a long time, and I can't stress it enough.

Posted: January 27, 2014
												If you are a fan of Jackie Chan's a 'New Police Story' or any of the old fashioned Chinese police movies for that matter; this is definitely the game for you. It captures the vibrancy and hustle of Hong Kong with beautiful graphics and clever AI that makes the city feel real, gritty and busy; something I have rarely seen a game accomplish so well. The driving is well balanced as are the fighting and shooting mechanics; none of which ever felt repetitive or overpowered during my 42 hour play-through. The main Character Shen had an interesting story to tell and I feel Square Enix did well in development as I found him an engaging protagonist that walked the frequent line of oblivion.In short, I highly recommend picking up this game if you want to play something a little different to the norm. It is fun, immersive and captures the heart of China even if the ending is a shameless setup for the next game.8/10

Posted: December 7, 2015
												A GTA lookalike open world sandbox playing in Hong Kong with extremely nice and fluid visuals and the best in class combat system.Golden bits:First and foremost the combat system. This is absolutely the best in the game and the best combat I ever had the chance of playing in a game that is not purely a combat game. Or maybe even including those. Combat is super fluid and adapts wonderfully to the situation while not featuring ridiculously complicated controller button combos.The abundance of good looking chicks. I mean this game features an extremely high percentage of 10/10 females wandering the streets of this city.  Mrs. Chu without a doubt. One cannot not like her to the point handling of the butcher knife. Your apartment in Central. Great shed - too bad the toilet seems to be always full of some yellow substance.Stinky bits:FOW inside apartments. While the FOW is OK during the action sequences in the city it gets terribly narrow inside apartments. Instant vomit.Racing sequences. There are 18 of these and strictly not fun. I am not saying they are difficult they are just the worst executed bits of an otherwise great game. Vehicle damage modelling. Sucks. Cars take a stupidly large amount of punishment before they explode.The 2 DLCs with achievements. They are extremely dragged out and boring. They also take away some of the skills you already got in the main game which is mad. I suggest playing the DLCs before finishing the main game in case you would wanna go for a 100% completion - otherwise they would feel very much like a bad afterthought.Stat award achievements. It is not nice having got to grind these after finishing the game. Not nice at all.All in all it is still very much Recommended. (8/10)

Posted: October 1, 2014
												An under-rated, open world, third person action game.  I was particularly impressed with the melee system; I'm not a fan of fighting games (can't remember all the combos) but found this to be both approachable and enjoyable.  Hong Kong has a fantastic vibe that gives it presence all it's own.  Driving has a wonderful feel of speed while still being controllable.  If you enjoy the GTA or Saints' Row series be sure to give this a shot.Note: The bulk of my SD play was on the X360 version; I enjoyed it so much I purchased the PC version.  PC features a hi-res texture pack and is (in my opinion) the definitive version best of the original versions.  See below.Note: The original version of SD is no longer available. The replacement is the Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition. It includes all the DLC, upgraded graphics, upgraded crowds and roads, etc. The game now takes advantage of current hardware to add more people to crowds, more cars to the roads, etc. 50% off for owners of the current version.

Posted: February 1, 2016
												Pretty good game, with some interesting locations and combat.Postitives:- A fun blend of hand-to-hand combat and firefights, with some cool car chases.- The player character is highly mobile, making it easy and fun to get around the city, both on foot and while driving.- An "ok" story, with quite a lot of side activities and some funny moments- Experience points, upgrades and bad cop/good cop elements brings some more meat to the gameNegatives:- The pacing can be a bit weird, especially the last parts of the game, which are very rushed and don't seem to be planned out very much. "♥♥♥♥♥♥- we're out of time! Just cobble some guns and stuff together!"- The hand-to-hand combat, while fun, can be a bit repetitious, without you really needing to use most of the combos that you learn during the game.- The game could have been so much more. Many of the elements in the game are not very deep, and sometimes the game seems a bit "cut". I'm guessing the designers had something more planned, but time or costs got in their way.All in all, a pretty good game.

Posted: May 15, 2014
												Gameplay: 10/10Graphics: 10/10Voice Acting: 10/10Campaign: 10/10Read on for my opinion on Sleeping DogsSleeping Dogs was a game I wasn't sure about at first. It looked too linear, not enough weapons or vehicles, possibly a garbage campaign. But I bought this game when it was on sale to try it anyways. Needless to say im blown away. This Game has an immense focus on fighting and hand to hand combat whichy is suprising given the GTA style free roaming. Another great thing is the wide diversity of vehicles at your expense to use. With multiple races and side missions to play in game, having different vehicles to test out and play around with sure is a blast. Manuvering the city is also a fun little challenge due to the crowded streets of Honk Kong, it makes it sometimes hard to get away fromm the cops as easily as you'd like. Another thing is the campagin. I figured it would be like GTA, or Saints row, where you're part of a gang and you go do illegal things over and over. But nope, your character is Wei Shen, and undercover cop! Thats something I really loved about this game. The Campaign was so fresh and different. And massive credit to the voice actors of the game! The interactions between Wei shen and the Honk Kong PD as well as fellow Gangs was superb! You will definetly get your moneys worth out of this game AND the DLC. If you havn't picked up Sleeping Dogs already, do your game library a solid and add it to your collection!

Posted: July 1, 2014
												Grand Theft Auto: China. That's almost a dead accurate representation of what this game is. Although you play a cop and not just some vigilante going home or starting out a crime bid. Other than that it's pretty much Grand Theft Auto.You run can around the City scape looking for Cars, Money Boxes, Red Envolopes, Statues, and occationally Call up some chicks so you can have dates with them. The Main Weapon of this game is your Fists, there is no weapon cycling, you either have a weapon or you don't and chances are you will not have a weapon on you when an enemy pulls one out so you have to rely on your own disarming abilities to get the upper hand and thankfully the game gives you power ups to improve your abilities in hand to hand combat making fighting much easier and fun. Also the Fighting mechanics are pretty much ripped straight off of The Arkham Games, so if you're pretty keen on that you're pretty much set with this game. Overall Sleeping Dogs is a great experience. I really like the atmosphere of this game and it gets really easy to get lost in this game just by driving around or walking around and just taking in the whole Chiniese experience.This is worth a buy.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												I kept coming back to play this almost every night after work until I finished off the main story - and I'm a habitutal non-completer of games, specifically open world sandbox or role playing. And I got sick of GTA titles around the Vice City era, so if that's not a good enough recommendation, here's a little more info on why this should be in your library:1. Sleeping Dogs keeps the pacing fresh in the main storyline missions by offering either the Cop or Triad, so you're not always just shooting uzis out car windows at speedbikes, or planting bugs. And even if you decide to stick with one of the other for a bit, the mission variance is creative and allows for some memorable moments created by the sheer amount of awesome (or completely wrong) things that can happen.  The fact you are a cop changes how you act as well, which I also appreciated in contrast to other games which give you no moral standard to follow.2. The hand-to-hand fighting system is excellent, and the time spent breaking arms and slamming heads into cars out weighs the gun play time by about 80/20. This makes the armed combat feel more dangerous and gritty, since you are opting for outright murder instead of going fist to fist with thugs. When I did go around eliminating street gangs with a pistol, and they were only armed with fists and knives, I felt both powerful and also a tad evil as they ran away from me... which most other games water down by having that be the only option for most encounters.3. Driving is exhilerating. The cars all sound nice and beefy, and weaving in and out of traffic is a blast.Cons:-A few pretty bad collision bugs where you'll stick to a car and fly around the city a bit (hilarious, albeit)-The super easy Karaoke minigames are mandatory to progress some missions, and take forever. Funny for maybe 5 seconds.-Powerups via street vendors were a good idea, but not enough variance or real benefit to warrant stopping for them.-All the towns look kind of same-y - could have used a rural area to drive around in.-The parkour bits were frustrating, no matter how good you were, you couldn't catch the dude until they wanted you to, or got into a car and ran them over (if that mission allowed it).-No car customization/painting :(

Posted: November 10, 2014
												As a fan of Hong Kong cinema, the way Sleeping Dogs depicts its story had me attached to the plot, characters and setting from start to finish. Every character has personality, and while there isn’t a stand out individual, each one feels developed enough for you to care about their associations with Wei and it helps that the voice acting is fantastic. The game’s length is about 15-hours with side missions extending to double that. The first three hours of Sleeping Dogs demonstrate a lot of the improvements to the GTA gameplay with the traversal free running and hand-to-hand combat. Hand-to-hand combat is heavily inspired by the Batman: Arkham series of video games, with Wei being able to punch, grapple and counter to victory. Grappling is a rather good move in Sleeping Dogs. Not only is it used to throw people over edges or pound them to the ground, but it allows Wei to interact with environmental objects as a way to deal extreme damage. Story missions are mainly great. Side missions are a different story. Most are fillers where you are chasing people, racing cars, beating people up, singing Karaoke, hacking, nothing all that exciting compared to the main plot. The cars handle well with their super arcade-like feel, and the gun combat is mostly solid, with Wei able to pull off bullet time when jumping over cover, helping with aiming headshots.Having seen all the versions on display, there is no denying that the PC version of Sleeping Dogs is well above the graphics of the console version. I had all settings set to the highest (PC Specs: i5, GeForce 660ti, 8GB RAM) and the framerate kept above 60 throughout the whole game. It’s the world that makes Sleeping Dogs’ graphics stand out, with the city looking stunning with the downloaded high resolution pack, showcasing the neon lights blasting their rays across the road and glowing up the night of Hong Kong.

Posted: February 28, 2014
												So, I have just beaten Sleeping Dogs. I must say, this game is probably the best game to have come out in 2012. You play as Wei Shen, an undercover Hong Kong police officer who has the task of infiltrating the biggest triad in Hong Kong: Sun On Yee. The story is set up beautifully, almost like a chess board. You start out working with the other pawns in the triad and as the story evolves, you meet all the other pieces of the board. And like in the game of chess, pieces are moved and taken away as the game progresses. The charecters are also very black and white like chess pieces in which you know who your enemies are, and you know who your friends are. There's no reach-arounds or deception, which is a plus in this sort of game. Gameplay is very much like a stew. There are pieces of other games that are brewed together and made into something good and unique. You have the freerunning of Assassin's Creed, the combat is very much like the Batman series of games, the HUD layout is almost exactly like Grand Theft Auto IV's. The driving is actually kinda bad in the game because all the cars and motorcycles go incredibly fast for the tight confines of Hong Kong's streets. But when you ride shotgun in a car and do the shooting while an AI drives, it is amazing.The content in this game is nearly unending. You have a ton of side missions, street races, drug busts, dates, clothing and cars to buy, cop missions, and even more if you get some of the DLC. The main missions are quite well done, though there doesn't seem to be much creativity put into them. But that's okay, because the game is just so fun you don't really notice it until you look back on it. The charecters are very good in the game. With your own charecter, you get to see the battle he has with himself, the police, and the triads. You see him start to blur the lines and get his hands dirty while trying to keep on the straight and narrow. You get attached easily and heartbroken when bad things happen. I think the charecters are the best aspect they did of this game. I would say my final rating will have to be a 10/10. There is almost nothing wrong in this game. Highly recommended.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												A friend got me this game saying it was rather decent. The sale was on and well i decided to say yes, from what i had seen, the game didn't look to bad, looked fun but also looked a little boring, which left me a little unwanting to play it. The steam sale was on when my friend got it me, so i had all of the DLC along with the game, which being honest, is a lot, from two extra DLC missions which add on, to ones which add to your triad and police level, to cars and clothes. There's plenty given from this to help gain your interest within the game. So, from that being said, lets start from the beginning. From my own slight worries and fears for the game, the opening looked promising, controls are standard and decent but felt a little clunky at first, i played more and got past the opening. The story showed it's inital idea and the concept was rather interesting but was... slow to really push this idea until much later on in the game.Once the story had been laid out and i had done the starting missions i found myself sitting there for 15 minuets as it showed me all of the DLC, what it had given me, and all the bonuses.. Which is great and all.. But it meant that my Triad and police levels shot to level 8, same with face meter, meaning by a quater way in i was max leveled on triad and police. It meant i could do more fun earlier on, but made the game a little "to" easy as it clearly laid out missions with mind off you gradually gaining upgrades, but, it was still fun to be kicking the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of enemies from the start and feeling like a Kung Fu master.After a few hours into the game the story had been slow. Wasn't gaining my interest and the side missions were fun up to a certain amount of time, even with all the extra content given out to me. So, i ended up leaving this on the side, in my libary for a time. I eventually came back after a few weeks and decided to have another go, i had an issue with the game crashing, easily fixed by validating the files but still was a pain. I opened my save and didn't remember anything, nothing suck in or stuck with me for the weeks, but, determined from reviews and some walkthroughs i started another new game and worked my way up to the place i was. But this time, i found myself more involved into the story when i started to understand the situation the player is in, what you're doing, and why the story is so evidently slow from the go. I managed to start to work my way through and found myself becoming more and more engrossed into the storyline, but not just that, i found myself starting to have conflict between being a traid and being an undercover police officer, something, that isn't easy to do, question a player: Are you a traid? Or are you still an officer? Especially when you can just run down people without stress, kill police officers, break speeding limits and more. Depending on this it kinda made me think well where do i go. I moved into the police cases aspect to the game then. The cases are a welcome additon, technically, a side mission spanning through the game the police cases are truly interesting and allow for you to keep to your roots as an officer while being drawn more and more into the crazy, murdering world of the traids. The missions slowly unlock as you play through the main missions, all cases being diverse into what you look into and some even being rather shocking from the final result. But in the end, you still feel like you've made an achievement into solving them and trying to stick to being a cop. Especially when you go from missions stealing/Killing and all this, to doing something for the better.From being more into the game now i took a look at the aspects of gameplay. Fighting was solid, guns felt powerful and fun to use and even driving on a keyboard and mouse was very enjoyable and responsive. Fighting is similar to that of Batman: Arkham series where you hit people with combos and then counter attacks as they start to come in landing on you. Despite feeling like a kung-fu god, going more and more in lead me to being killed and defeated easily by larger eneimes and more in groups. So i explored, found health shrines to take more hits, and went and found the statues to learn more moves as well, it made it interesting but, the statues are all generally in the way in missions, making searching for them kinda irrelivent, it's almost like they put them in the way in missions so you pick them up anyway and learn the moves, not like you have to go looking to truly gain an upper hand, just a way of slowly keeping your fighting up to par with the rest. Despite that, it was still very, very fun and the fighting never really got repetative when you're breaking someones leg and then flying kicking someone else in the head.So i had gotten later in. SPOILER  To the point where Wei had become a red pole, moving up the ranks, working for uncle Poe and managing to learn more about the higher ranks of the triads  And i found myself being more and more drawn in, especially to the traid side, beggining more to forget about my police side and loose myself in order to gain more into the traids. It was around here i found that sleeping dogs wasn't afraid to deal with much more horrid situations. The game had been very tame, not a lot of blood, some decent fighting but nothing counting as shocking.Until... The wedding...  Boy, did the game soon show me is was taking it more seriously, and was not afraid to show much more graphical violence, showing me the world of which i was trying to get into. It showed the horror of what can happen inside of this world and the danger i was in.  Especially when you see Wei in a blood stained suit, trying to comfort a dying Winston  It showed me it was prepared to shock me and show me more of the horrors of the world, making it show, sleeping dogs was able to remain serious and deal with these situations in a decent way. Past that the game toned down a little but the story, REALLY, picked up for me. It moved up more and more, making it even more interesting and getting me even more into it, so much so, i found myself playing it late at night as the battle between being with the triads and being a police officer forever was nagging there, and was clearly showing for Wei as well. Much later in and near the end a lot happened, a lot had to be taken in, the game had built up this tension that just.... fell short. The ending felt like all this tension and hard work into getting me to think of either being a triad or police just wasn't brought to a full conclusion. For those who have finished.  The ending felt like you either kill big Smile Lee as either an officer of the law, or as revenge for him killing your triad friends . For those who haven't, the ending only makes you feel like you've done it for one side or the other... and nothing else than that, which was a damn shame to all that hard work going into it. Regardless, it was still fun and enjoyable. Before the ending there is also another bloody scene, which i warn, those who cannot stand blood or worse, look away when it happens, and trust me, you know when it will. Overall sleeping dogs truly got me into it, got me to battle how i felt with being an undercover cop and got me to see the grousome side of everything which happened and could happen in such a game. I look forward to the DLC and would recommend this to anyone. It is slow to get into, but damn fun and interesting once you do get into it. I would say buy with all the DLC as well, as it's more worth it that way, but either way, sleeping dogs is a damn good game and i would rate it 9/10 from everything i've played. Just make sure that during some scenes you're prepared, as much as the game seems a little goofy, it handles some truly horrifying moments seriously and well.

Posted: January 17, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is a masterpiece of open world game play, bringing many different game mechanics flawlessly into one.Character development is amazing and very likable, with many twists and turns right throughout the main storyline. The voice acting is arguably the best I've seen in games of recent, you get attached to the dialogue and the mood of some scenes is somewhat of a movie rather than a game. Combat is top notch with the kung fu fights, which you can progress even further with Wei Shen unlocking new melee skills. Gun play is also very good, not being too overly emphasised as much as melee, which is better in some way, as the melee is one of the games selling points. Being open world you are given the freedom of Hong Kong. There is always something to do while you explore the streets, from random evens which can pop up at any corner which challenge you in different scenarios to finding many hidden lock boxes scattered around. This makes the game refreshing and can give you some surprises. With a myriad of game mechanics and a story that really grips you, this rightfully gets a 9/10.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												The very first game I bought on Steam during a sale (I just dropped by randomly and decided it's too good to pass up, lol!), and I gotta say it's quite good - definitely a must-have if you like third person shooter / sandbox games.Sleeping Dogs is quite similar in GTA with its freeroam and side tasks aside from the Main Story. The biggest difference however, you don't get to use firearms too often - instead, Martial Arts plays a major in this game. Wei Shen, your character, is so skillful that he can stand up against 10+ enemies with just his fist, and he is able to intercept any attacks as long as you time your QTE just right - nothing more satisfying than beating up tons of big guys and walk away unscathed! The game centers around Triad activities, so you still get to shoot bad guys every once in a while, especially during later missions.One good thing about Sleeping Dogs, it's very easy to play. You get all kind of help text and instructions, and the Tutorial missions are easy to follow up. Even if you are new to TPS / Sandbox, you can master the control in no more than a few hours. The map is quite big with collectibles and side stuff you can complete during freeroam / after finishing the story, and bonuses are nice too (both for easing gameplay and/or improving Shen's abilities). Even at Medium setting (I have x86 system so it don't have 4 GB RAMs), the graphics still look good and smooth - most of the time I have stable 45 FPS, which is lowered down to 30 when too much stuff show up. This is where Sleeping Dogs is WAY better than Saint Row The Third.However, there are still a few problems here and there - first, partial custom control is annoying. I mainly play on Arrow section, but for Sleeping Dogs I am forced to use WSAD because arrow keys and enter/backspace can't be reassigned - the devs are too lazy to make graphics for all keyboard layout so they just go cheap and force you to use their setting - not cool. Another thing, Sleeping Dogs is scripted to force you to play missions in a linear way - you can't bring weapons in because the story says so, and you can't keep weapons after the mission because the story says so. This makes me regret ever purchasing all those DLCs, only to find their perks CANNOT be used in the main story mission to make it more fun. Last but not least, some interaction are so fussy at time - walking up to a food vendor and press button only to find Wei does nothing yet they still talk like the deal is done, very funny.But overall, Sleeping Dogs is a good game - Activision really did a stupid move by throwing it away, otherwise I believe it'd did its original job; rebooting True Crime series. That, for us, is also a good thing because now Sleeping Dogs has become its own series, with Triad War sequence announced already. I'll definitely give it a try once it hits Steam, assuming my PC can still handle it.
