Posted: December 29, 2014
												It doesn't offer a great deal that can't be found in other open-world games, but the flipside is that it's also almost entirely free of the guff that drags many of its competitors down. Sleeping Dogs is a lean, refined GTA clone with an emphasis on putting as much of the game at your fingertips as early and often as possible.Gameplay boils down to melee, gunplay and driving sections. Melee fights are the most prevalent part of the game and anyone who's played the Arkham games will feel right at home with the counter-driven one-button fighting here. Melee weapons and environmental kills are offered for some variety but don't add much complexity or depth. Shootouts can be conducted as either an exercise in cover-based pop-and-shoot mechanics (if you're boring), or a more arcadey system where stylish kills can be chained together to rack up continuous bullet time. It's very reminiscent of John Woo's Stranglehold and handily my favourite part of the game, although it errs on the side of being a bit too easy. Driving is fairly standard; cars handle well with the right amount of weight and chases are enlivened somewhat by the presence of that same chained bullet-time mechanic as well as the ability to freely hop from one car to another a la Just Cause.The game's simulated Hong Kong is wonderfully detailed and always lovely to look at, but you'll find that it's not hiding a great deal of interesting content to be discovered. Aside from stores dotted around the place, you'll only ever really find yourself heading from map marker to map marker for story missions or sidequests. The obvious debt the game owes to classic Hong Kong action/martial arts cinema aesthetically will probably make it more interesting to genre fans (like myself).

												"Like Grand Theft Auto but...."Actually this game has the GTA feel but in a way makes itself unique from other sandbox titles. Posted: July 21, 2014
												First off I want to say that I was a bit skeptical of this game. I'm usually a bit picky when it comes to open world games. I have been disappointed in the past with games that claim to be open world but are actually just bigger world games with a relatively linear path. With that said, this game IS open world similar to GTA but not as robust or in depth as GTA gets with the side missions weapons, cars, missions, etc but it does get pretty linear at times. Don't let that scare you away though. This game is incredibly fun and has a lot of great elements to it. The Asian atmosphere it brings is  awesome. I don't think it really captures the true Asian organized crime background that much but it does a good job in its own way. If you're a fan of Bruce Lee/Jackie Chan/Jet Li martial arts movies you will like this game. They stuck a lot of cliche situations in this game that resemble many of those movies. I don't want to get too in depth and spoil anything but there are some outright mimics of the movies and their plots in certain parts of the game.General game play is fun and satisfying. The graphics are pretty decent once you get the high res xpac. Driving is OK at best.  I use a controller with this game as it feels more comfortable to me when anything driving is involved. I would say that it has its good and bad moments. The drifting mechanic in the game feels a bit weak and makes me want more out of the vehicles. The environments are nice and laid out. I do think that it becomes bland after a while with the same cars, same scenery etc. The towns all look the same for the most part. I dislike the fact that when you put on an outfit you don't get to use its perks in the various missions during the game. One thing I don't like and this is no fault of the game at all it's the nature of being set in the asian country is getting used to driving on the left side of the road. Being a veteran of all the past GTA games and well, living in the US it makes for some difficult reactions. I find myself driving on the right side of the road frequently zoning out on the highways then running head on while trying to avoid traffic. This brings me to my next issue.When you run into ANYTHING it takes away from the police points during your missions. Sometimes this is incredibly difficult and takes away from the game a bit. It could be anything from running into a sidewalk fence to running over a pedestrian. I understand the bigger stuff but even so much as a knick on the fence will cause a negative point towards your police faction score. Anyway, the game is well worth the 6 bucks I spent for the game + all DLC. I really really enjoy it and feel I can get a lot of replay value out of it. I would recommend it to anybody looking for a good solid game to play similar to GTA mixed with the foreign martial arts movies.

Posted: July 14, 2013
												Is this game on sale? Yeah? Then buy, especially if you like action-adventure games. This game is somewhat similar to a GTA game, so I'll compare it to that. I enjoyed playing through this game much more than any GTA's I've played through. The combat is better, driving feels solid, the story is very well done, and the shooting mechanics surpass that of GTA IV (which arguably has the best "shooting" in the series). The one thing Sleeping Dogs does lack, though, is variety in weapons (there are very few guns and melee weapons, solid combat aside), a somewhat generic open-world (while I don't think GTA is much more "alive," I think GTA games provide a better sandbox experience), and there's no multiplayer options for those interested in one (this didn't bother me about the game, but I know some people say "AW NO MULTIPLAYER I AIN'T BieING"). Overall, the base story mode (non-DLC) took me 16 hours and not once did I get bored during my playthrough, which is kinda rare for a game I knew very little about before purchasing. So, yeah. Buy it.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												Being a renegade kung-fu fighter, a rogue undercover cop avenging his dead sister, in a well depicted Hong-Kong, is a lot of fun in Sleeping Dogs. Cook a guy's face on hot plates, stab his heart with a swordfish; there are tons of way to kill a poor soul that are way more fun than using guns. The story is pretty good and pretty often, you feel like you're in a movie. When you're not killing triad members or out shopping for new clothes and bracelets, you can do pretty much everything you want: bet on♥♥♥♥♥♥fights, race cars and bikes in the docks, play mahjong...By the end of the game, Wei Shen will be your new definition of a real Badass with sick tats.Also you can sing Take On Me by a-ha, try finding that in a kungfu fighting game!

Posted: July 9, 2014
												The story was a amazing and kept me playing the game non-stop until the final climatic mission. All characters are very well made with great voice acting. When it comes to gameplay, I'm not sure about mouse and keyboard since I played purely by controller, but it was fun and the combat was very responsive. The melee combat system is very deep compared to most other games in the genre with its great combos and counter-attacks as well as skill trees but it also features cover-based shooting for all you GTA fans. Driving is alright, but the camera angles at times can be annoying. The game could use a multiplayer mode for racing and free-roam as well. Overall, a great game by any means. Buy it. 8/10

Posted: December 21, 2013
												Sleeper hit, great game, For an open world sandbox (gta style) game, this has suprisingly deep story that will grip you from beggining to end. Even though it's sandbox, and lets you go free, the game does a great job at directing you and making you ACTUALLY feel like a part of the world, unlike how GTA just makes you feel like a crime spree driven sociopath. Good gameplay, EXCELLENT martial-arts and combat system (that borders on brutal at times with its environmental fatalities), this game is a must play for anyone who likes a good sandbox game, or simply a good undercover cop story.

												Great game. Just finished the story. For sure, one of my favorite games of all time! So glad I purchased, and all of the DLCs are wonderful. Posted: May 8, 2014
												Engaging combat system and storyline. They kind of gloss over the character background by briefly mentioning it at various times throughout the game, however, it would have been nice if they went more in depth so I could visualize it a bit better; that would help make Wei's actions and motivations more emotionally charged and invest us in the storyline and the game more. It is interesting seeing a game with a "minority race" as the main culture and population being explored, as opposed to being the model minority or cheap humor. Keyboard and Mouse controls are pretty whacky and the mouse acceleration is whack; recommend you to play on a controller instead. There were a few characters who should have honestly had a bigger role in the game or should have appeared more. Kind of lacks replay value and incentive to do the additional achievements and missions; however, in terms of a game that is fun to play through for the initial story and gameplay, Sleeping Dogs is an excellent choice. Overall, the game has a strong story, diverse culture, and engaging combat system, but falls off a bit in terms of replay value and additional content after you beat the main story.

Posted: May 28, 2014
												I fell in love with this game the first time I played it. I'd been on the fence regarding buying it since I'd heard a few detractors saying it wasn't as good as GTA. I love the GTA series, but this tops them. Why? Because not only the story is good, but also the fighting mechanic - GTA was never good at fighting, it was all about driving and shooting. Sleeping Dogs brings in the Arkham series' style of freeflow fighting (though not as good as the Arkham games, it's not far off) as well as cool things like being able to jump from one car to another to hijack vehicles, take hostages, have bullet time vault shootings and much more.The game is 2 years old but still looks as good, if not better (at times), than Watch Dogs. It runs really well, too. I was able to run it at ultra settings the day it came out, even with the hi-res PC-only texture pack that was released. Nowadays, I can run it at 2880x1620 (and would expect to run it at 4k, if my monitor supported it).If you've been disappointed by Watch Dogs, then give this a try - I personally find it's more fun than Watch Dogs, allows you to interact with the other people in the environment more and has a great fighting system. It doesn't have all the hacking stuff, and is more action-orientated than stealth based, but that's not always a bad thing in the open world genre.

Posted: August 28, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is a great game, not perfect in anyway, but it's still a good experience.Graphics:There good, not the best but the game has a few years on it now. For AMD users like myself, this game is a pleasue, runs so well it's unbelieveable. I run this game 100fps+ maxed and it does look very nice. Graphics are good enough, not much pop-in which is fantastic and people faces look quite nice.Story:Story is alright, it's not the best or the worst. Looking past some of it's major flaws and loop wholes, it serves it's purpose. I wouldn't buy this game for it's story alone though, you need to enjoy the mechanics aswell. Being a double agent puts a nice spin on things, but it's nothing we haven't seen before. Lots of twists are predictable sadly, and slow turn of cop into bad guy is very generic.Mechanics: Hand to Hand combat is beautiful, it's so rare to find a game like this that focuses on close combat instead of guns. Really enjoyed it,  very smooth and the counter system is nice. Only problem is it's a little to easy, especially when you can kill everybody except bosses and grapplers by throwing them into a phonebooth.Overall:Good game, probably one of the best open world titles left that people haven't played. It's no GTA, but it's great to fill that gap while waiting for something else. Game is quite shoot, however, keep in mind I didn't do any sidemissions. I went straight through all the main missions.Nice game, would definitely recommend on sale.Rating: 7/10

Posted: December 7, 2013
												Holy Jesus this game was so much fun. I just finished the story, and it was fantastic. I would compare the feeling I'm having right now to a roller coaster. The game was non-stop fun througout the whole game, and now I have this sudden calmness. The story was THAT great, but there was one thing I loved about it. It never bored me. I could go one mission to the next without wanting to do something else. In fact, I found the story so interesting that I have almost every secondary mission to do now that the game is over. The combat in this game is spectacular is almost exactly like Batman. The combos and way you learn them are almost identical to the game Bully however, which I noticed immediately. The driving is good for an open-world game, and smashing through everything that gets in your way is a blast. This game has been on my backlog for a while now and I highly regret it. 												An under-rated, open world, third person action game.  I was particularly impressed with the melee system; I'm not a fan of fighting games (can't remember all the combos) but found this to be both approachable and enjoyable. If you enjoy the GTA or Saints' Row series be sure to give this a shot.Note: The bulk of my SD play was on the X360 version; I enjoyed it so much I purchased the PC version.  PC features a hi-res texture pack and is (in my opinion) the definitive version best of the original versions.  See below.Note: The original version of SD is no longer available. The replacement is the Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition. It includes all the DLC, upgraded graphics, upgraded crowds and roads, etc. The game now takes advantage of current hardware to add more people to crowds, more cars to the roads, etc. 50% off for owners of the current version.

												While Sleeping Dogs is a little rough around the edges (mainly flaky "social hub" service and bizarre controller quirks) the game is actually quite fun. I picked this gem up during a Steam sale and am glad that I did. I've got 10+ hours of play in and expect to continue playing it with or without the "Social Hub". Its gameplay is a lot like the GTA series but a larger emphasis on melee combat (like the Batman Arkham series). I wouldn't pay full price for Sleeping Dogs, because of the lack of game updates (the devs are in support mode now and obviously aren't too keen on looking into the issues) to fix bugs and certain game functionally, but you certainly can't go wrong paying < $10 for this game. Just my 2 cents.

Posted: September 2, 2014
												A great open-world game. The story of Wei Shen, trying to stay loyal to the police whilst also maintaining his cover amongst Triad members is very tense. It kept me ignoring side missions to see what happens next. And after you've beaten the main story, gone through every race and side mission and collected every item, there are loads of DLC packs that provide even more hours of enjoyable gameplay. Incredible game. 9.5/10

Posted: September 23, 2012
												Sleeping Dogs is an excellent game, a strong contender to make my top 5 of 2012. It has a powerful story with exciting twists and interesting characters, supported by Hollywood quality voice acting and music, and gorgeous graphics. The three core gameplay elements, melee, shooting and driving, while individually not as outstanding as other games that focus on one element, are all good enough to enjoy here. Add in a wide range of side missions and you have a varied experience that is never dull and easily lasts over 15 hours. This is also a good PC port, with plenty of customisation options, the controls work well with keyboard and mouse and there are hardly any bugs. My only complaint is that the undercover setting is kind of wasted. The player never gets to make a meaningful moral choice like "can I avoid committing this crime without blowing my cover?". Every mission and plot point is fully scripted, and some players may find themselves disagreeing with Wei's choices.

Posted: July 29, 2013
												Anyone who loves sandbox games, or the Grand Theft Auto series will absolutely love this game. If not, this will be one of those exceptions. You play as Wei Chen, a cop who tries to infultrate the most dangerous gangs in Hong Kong, all whilst trying to stay under cover. The story is set in a beautiful city environment loosely based around Hong Kong. The scenery is fantastic, and there are mods available in the steam workshop to make it even more visually stunning. In addition to that, the story is gripping and the combat system is superb. Within a couple of fights, you've got the hang of fighting for the rest of the game. It develops well, and more complex moves are added when you collect more of the missing statues. The only complaint that I have, is the fact that I completed the main story a little too quickly. A few more missions or added characters or scenes would have been brilliant. However, even after completing it, I still play the game as there are plenty of little odd jobs here and there to do.When this game is going cheap (maybe during the steam sales!) I would say:GRAB IT AS FAST AS YOU CAN. It'll be one of the best games you buy, I can tell you it certainly is one of mine.

Posted: May 28, 2014
												I fell in love with this game the first time I played it. I'd been on the fence regarding buying it since I'd heard a few detractors saying it wasn't as good as GTA. I love the GTA series, but this tops them. Why? Because not only the story is good, but also the fighting mechanic - GTA was never good at fighting, it was all about driving and shooting. Sleeping Dogs brings in the Arkham series' style of freeflow fighting (though not as good as the Arkham games, it's not far off) as well as cool things like being able to jump from one car to another to hijack vehicles, take hostages, have bullet time vault shootings and much more.The game is 2 years old but still looks as good, if not better (at times), than Watch Dogs. It runs really well, too. I was able to run it at ultra settings the day it came out, even with the hi-res PC-only texture pack that was released. Nowadays, I can run it at 2880x1620 (and would expect to run it at 4k, if my monitor supported it).If you've been disappointed by Watch Dogs, then give this a try - I personally find it's more fun than Watch Dogs, allows you to interact with the other people in the environment more and has a great fighting system. It doesn't have all the hacking stuff, and is more action-orientated than stealth based, but that's not always a bad thing in the open world genre.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												Dear Reader,Sleeping Dogs is a spectactular game. With a lovely story where everyone is happy and they gets what they want, it makes for a truely realistic experience of what it is like being a man living in Hong Kong. In Sleeping Dogs, there is no violence or drama, but it makes up for that with lots of heartfelt, family-friendly humor. I have personally put almost 24 hours worth of my time into this game, and I do intend to put more. So, if you do get bored with your mindless slaughter of innocent NPC's, purchase and enjoy Sleeping Dogs today.Love,Fossor_

Posted: June 23, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs is GTA 4 with parkour and good combat and bullet-time. That's it really. It's GTA 4 mashed up with Hong Kong cinema. It's pretty glorious. The combat in this game is really just a simplified Arkham Asylum, which is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing good for a GTA clone, considering how wrong they always get it. You've got pretty simple X, X, X, hold X combos, with different amount of X's pre-hold giving you different sweet combos. You've got a grapple that you can follow up with arm-breaking, tossing them off a ledge, or just, you know, bashin' their face in. You have all sorts of sweet kicks. It's pretty martial-artsy of course but it's less trying to look cool (although it does) and more about no nonsense killing dudes with your body. Also you can grab people and throw them in dumpsters or impale them on meat hooks or smash them into a box full of broken glass (yeah I don't know why there are boxes full of broken glass everywhere.) The driving feels good, but I can't remember how driving felt in GTA 4. It probably apes that as well so if you're one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who couldn't deal with that you'll probably hate it. But you can hang out of your car window and shoot out tires and♥♥♥♥♥♥and when you start shooting the game goes into slow motion so you can actually do it without crashing into a wall, which is cool. This is a pretty spergy thing, but I really like the freeway system in this game. It loops around the whole city with lots of nice on-ramps and exchanges everywhere and apparently I love that♥♥♥♥♥♥because I like just getting on the freeway and going fast. This game has ♥♥♥♥loads of bullet-time. You punch a guy with your gun out? Aim your gun after and you get some bullet-time. Vault over your cover? Aim your gun and guess what? ♥♥♥♥in' bullet-time. Headshot 3 guys before you land, it's awesome.Oh yeah, and you can jump out of your car and onto another car and steal it in motion. That♥♥♥♥♥♥owns, so do that a bunch.The story is ok, I guess. It's serviceable at least. You're an undercover cop in with the triads, and guess what, spoiler alert, you get too close to your gangster buddies and loyalties get conflicted. You're way too good at what you do and kill a billion people so you end up promoted to the top of the organization way too fast. You know, standard stuff. I am pretty curious how you end up getting off scot-free after how many people you've killed. The Hong Kong PD are pretty ♥♥♥♥ing corrupt, I guess. Well they are cops. ACABOh, and if you're a sperglord like me, it puts all the collectibles on the minimap. Thank ♥♥♥♥ing god. For some reason they unlock after you bone down on the various women you encounter throughout the story. I think Wei ♥♥♥♥s just about every woman he encounters. So I guess that's cool, or troubling, maybe. I can't decide. I guess his karaoke powers and street fighting skillz are just enough to overlook the ridiculous clothing he's (probably) wearing.Time to wait for the DLC to go on sale.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												It doesn't offer a great deal that can't be found in other open-world games, but the flipside is that it's also almost entirely free of the guff that drags many of its competitors down. Sleeping Dogs is a lean, refined GTA clone with an emphasis on putting as much of the game at your fingertips as early and often as possible.Gameplay boils down to melee, gunplay and driving sections. Melee fights are the most prevalent part of the game and anyone who's played the Arkham games will feel right at home with the counter-driven one-button fighting here. Melee weapons and environmental kills are offered for some variety but don't add much complexity or depth. Shootouts can be conducted as either an exercise in cover-based pop-and-shoot mechanics (if you're boring), or a more arcadey system where stylish kills can be chained together to rack up continuous bullet time. It's very reminiscent of John Woo's Stranglehold and handily my favourite part of the game, although it errs on the side of being a bit too easy. Driving is fairly standard; cars handle well with the right amount of weight and chases are enlivened somewhat by the presence of that same chained bullet-time mechanic as well as the ability to freely hop from one car to another a la Just Cause.The game's simulated Hong Kong is wonderfully detailed and always lovely to look at, but you'll find that it's not hiding a great deal of interesting content to be discovered. Aside from stores dotted around the place, you'll only ever really find yourself heading from map marker to map marker for story missions or sidequests. The obvious debt the game owes to classic Hong Kong action/martial arts cinema aesthetically will probably make it more interesting to genre fans (like myself).

Posted: January 24, 2014
												Buggy and serious design flaws aside, is Sleeping Dogs fun?  The short answer is yes.  The story is predictable but satisfying -- several characters that I expected to die, did -- with the exception of one.  The fact that the bugs result in ridiculous behaviour only makes the fact that the game plays itself straight all the more hilarious and adding to the entertainmnet value.Cover-combat is nicely broken up with movie-style stunts, favouring bold, aggressive play that is movie-like, entertaining and rewarding both visually and tactically but is otherwise pretty standard.  The Free-Running is perhaps too down-to-earth considering the rest of the game isn't and while a nice attempt is probably one of the weaker game elements.  The fighting has some serious design flaws that really keep it from being as good as it could be; enemy classes weaken what could have been entertaining free-flow combat by giving them uninterruptable attacks or grapple immunity which bogs down the combat flow in a forced way.  The driving seems fine, but the catch-up logic is irritating as it only applies to the computer-controlled cars making racing rely more on luck than it should.  Said driving is not keyboard friendly.Finally, the bugs.  Oh the bugs.  Bugs were the first things I encountered because during the initial chase, the person I was supposed to follow quit running halfway through and in order to continue I had to dash ahead while the game nagged me that I was leaving him behind before he promptly teleported ahead.  Sometimes key events won't fire if you are genre-savvy and plan ahead.  NPC's will get stuck frequently and occasionally have amusing pathfinding difficulties.  One time the security camera wouldn't let me exit.  And the fact that many critical actions are crippled after completing a mission will mean occasionally thugs will steal your car trying to escape you because you couldn't do anything useful until the summary finished summarizing and you dismissed it.Overall  the mechanics work with the general feel, and while fans of GTA or Saints Row will probably prefer those games to this one, it's still fun and its own unique quirks made me feel it was a enjoyable romp.

Posted: September 1, 2012
												A mixture of Max Payne and GTA; this game is a must play. The story resembles a classic "Kung-Fu Action Film" in which Wei Shen (the protagonist) plays as an undercover cop in Hong Kong, trying to bring down the overwelming Triad force that rules the city. It's chaotic, heartwarming, bloody, and beautiful at the same time. The game is packed with all sorts of missions and side missions, including melee fights, gun fights, training in the Dojo to learn new moves, racing, dating, drug busting, collecting sports cars, chicken fights, photography, car chases, karaoke, going to fight clubs, and more. I should also mention the combat and movement, which is superb. Kung-fu melee combat AND freeroaming with parkour? Phenomenal.All I can say is that if you're looking for a great freeroaming game with a compelling story, or a freeroam that's looking to spice things up a bit; this game is for you. This game does need some fairly decent hardware if you want it to run properly, and I highly recommend getting the HD Texturepack. I'm definitely looking forward to a sequel!Enjoy.

Posted: April 4, 2014
												Let's get the bad out of the way: The driving camera is brutal. It's too close, it doesn't centre/rotate properly when reversing or turning, and just... yeah, it stinks. Also, I'm not a fan of the soundtrack compared to other open-world games. Oh, and the story is not the most original if you watch a lot of HK (or crime) flicks. The game is buggy, too. Finally, the fighting isn't as tight as the Arkham games, and gunplay is only average. Now, for the good -- or should I say stellar. The story, albeit unoriginal, is brought to life by great voice-acting and momentum. Also, I would be remiss to say it's better than the majority of video games. Some movies, shows, and books, too.The fighting does feel cinematic, despite a few rough parts, and the street races get the blood pumping. The city is one of the best I've ever experienced, and the game just oozes atmosphere.It's a must-play game, that can dish out hard-hitting drama but also deliver some laughs, sweetness (or bittersweet feelings), and is loads of fun.I genuinely would have paid for Bethesda-style story DLC, but instead we only received costumes and a few small expansions. Square-Enix have pretty much said they were disappointed by sales (despite ignoring digital numbers) but pump out their derivative JRPG garbage year-in, year-out.Prove 'em wrong by giving this game a shot!

Posted: August 14, 2015
												Chinese GTA with a simply awesome combat style. The basic Kung-Fu fighting by mashing buttons on your controller or smacking enemies in garbage containers, it just doesn't get boring beating up the thugs on Hong Kongs streets. The shooting is a little difficult with a controller, but maybe I'm just not used to it. The Slo-Mo elements are really helpful in situations like car chases, to pop the tires of chasing vehicles followed by huge explosions. The story so far is your average undercover cop story you get in any action movie, but not bad at all. There are some nice open-world events and minigames like hacking into CCTV cameras or tracing cellphones. If you have played GTA V by now and start playing Sleeping Dogs afterwards like me, it may be a bit disappointing that there aren't many different character desings for passers or cars. But reminding that this game is already 3 years old, it still looks pretty good. In the end the game has the most important parts an open world game needs and some little extras.

Posted: September 30, 2014
												The main storyline follows an emerging gang war that threatens to overrun the city of Hong Kong. You then follow a series of fairly redundant missions before beginning to shake down local vendors for money and beating up enemy gangs to bolster Winston's ego. Occasionally meeting up with your police handler, to hear the same lecture about not getting too emotionally involved to the monsters you’re working for.I have to be blunt, aside from the really pretty graphics, the game takes a face dive into the floor for it's combat system being nearly non-existent. You can pretty much just sit there deflecting attacks till your enemy just spontaneously dies, since the actual combat is a bit meh by having it just be a combo of clicks. This wasn't suppose to be a point-and-click game, yet the combat system makes it feel like one. So with 80% of the game revolving around combat, it's a real let down there.Another complaint I have to make is basically how terrible the handling of any vehicle was. There is virtually no chance of speeding and driving properly what-so-ever, as someone who has grown up playing various race games, this is another disappointing factor of the game.The game’s second biggest issue is with its camera. It can often positions itself towards center even when you’re trying to maneuver whilst driving. This can significantly complicate navigating tight quarters or getting a look around your vehicle in open spaces. The camera can also be frustrating in some combat situations, though it doesn't happen quite as often or severely.I also have to point out that in a gang game, it is virtually impossible to actually acquire a weapon. For memory you get a gun once during the entire game for approximately 5 minutes and nothing more. Knives are also irritatingly rare with maybe only one person in a random gang you attack to have one which you can sometimes have the option of picking up.It redeems itself within it's story-line, but, character development, bar the ones in cut scenes seem so cut short and abnormal. You go from just meeting a person to seeming like you have been in a relationship for years. It just doesn't quite flow in my opinion.All that aside, I did enjoy the random health shrines, deterring from the usual 'Pick up a health pot to gain more max health', within combat you can't just go to the side and chew on regenerative dirt, it takes a bit more time to actually gain it back. Another really redeeming quality is the animations to fight scenes, they are quite realistic. Also, the sounds of punching and slashing (when you finally acquire a knife) are brilliant.Moving on.. People chattering away in the background, or random vendors trying to sell certain things to which you can also interact with a few odd ones here and there make it feel a lot more in-depth and was something I did enjoy. Also actually just having pedestrians is such a tiny detail that make a game feel so much more real. It pulls it off with flying colors. I also have to make a comment on the voice acting. It simply adds to this emphasis on realism. The game employs a unique mixture of Chinese and English that doesn't sound corny or ill-executed which can be pretty difficult to pull off.In all, pretty good game, just a few frustrating little downfalls.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												A friend got me this game saying it was rather decent. The sale was on and well i decided to say yes, from what i had seen, the game didn't look to bad, looked fun but also looked a little boring, which left me a little unwanting to play it. The steam sale was on when my friend got it me, so i had all of the DLC along with the game, which being honest, is a lot, from two extra DLC missions which add on, to ones which add to your triad and police level, to cars and clothes. There's plenty given from this to help gain your interest within the game. So, from that being said, lets start from the beginning. From my own slight worries and fears for the game, the opening looked promising, controls are standard and decent but felt a little clunky at first, i played more and got past the opening. The story showed it's inital idea and the concept was rather interesting but was... slow to really push this idea until much later on in the game.Once the story had been laid out and i had done the starting missions i found myself sitting there for 15 minuets as it showed me all of the DLC, what it had given me, and all the bonuses.. Which is great and all.. But it meant that my Triad and police levels shot to level 8, same with face meter, meaning by a quater way in i was max leveled on triad and police. It meant i could do more fun earlier on, but made the game a little "to" easy as it clearly laid out missions with mind off you gradually gaining upgrades, but, it was still fun to be kicking the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of enemies from the start and feeling like a Kung Fu master.After a few hours into the game the story had been slow. Wasn't gaining my interest and the side missions were fun up to a certain amount of time, even with all the extra content given out to me. So, i ended up leaving this on the side, in my libary for a time. I eventually came back after a few weeks and decided to have another go, i had an issue with the game crashing, easily fixed by validating the files but still was a pain. I opened my save and didn't remember anything, nothing suck in or stuck with me for the weeks, but, determined from reviews and some walkthroughs i started another new game and worked my way up to the place i was. But this time, i found myself more involved into the story when i started to understand the situation the player is in, what you're doing, and why the story is so evidently slow from the go. I managed to start to work my way through and found myself becoming more and more engrossed into the storyline, but not just that, i found myself starting to have conflict between being a traid and being an undercover police officer, something, that isn't easy to do, question a player: Are you a traid? Or are you still an officer? Especially when you can just run down people without stress, kill police officers, break speeding limits and more. Depending on this it kinda made me think well where do i go. I moved into the police cases aspect to the game then. The cases are a welcome additon, technically, a side mission spanning through the game the police cases are truly interesting and allow for you to keep to your roots as an officer while being drawn more and more into the crazy, murdering world of the traids. The missions slowly unlock as you play through the main missions, all cases being diverse into what you look into and some even being rather shocking from the final result. But in the end, you still feel like you've made an achievement into solving them and trying to stick to being a cop. Especially when you go from missions stealing/Killing and all this, to doing something for the better.From being more into the game now i took a look at the aspects of gameplay. Fighting was solid, guns felt powerful and fun to use and even driving on a keyboard and mouse was very enjoyable and responsive. Fighting is similar to that of Batman: Arkham series where you hit people with combos and then counter attacks as they start to come in landing on you. Despite feeling like a kung-fu god, going more and more in lead me to being killed and defeated easily by larger eneimes and more in groups. So i explored, found health shrines to take more hits, and went and found the statues to learn more moves as well, it made it interesting but, the statues are all generally in the way in missions, making searching for them kinda irrelivent, it's almost like they put them in the way in missions so you pick them up anyway and learn the moves, not like you have to go looking to truly gain an upper hand, just a way of slowly keeping your fighting up to par with the rest. Despite that, it was still very, very fun and the fighting never really got repetative when you're breaking someones leg and then flying kicking someone else in the head.So i had gotten later in. SPOILER  To the point where Wei had become a red pole, moving up the ranks, working for uncle Poe and managing to learn more about the higher ranks of the triads  And i found myself being more and more drawn in, especially to the traid side, beggining more to forget about my police side and loose myself in order to gain more into the traids. It was around here i found that sleeping dogs wasn't afraid to deal with much more horrid situations. The game had been very tame, not a lot of blood, some decent fighting but nothing counting as shocking.Until... The wedding...  Boy, did the game soon show me is was taking it more seriously, and was not afraid to show much more graphical violence, showing me the world of which i was trying to get into. It showed the horror of what can happen inside of this world and the danger i was in.  Especially when you see Wei in a blood stained suit, trying to comfort a dying Winston  It showed me it was prepared to shock me and show me more of the horrors of the world, making it show, sleeping dogs was able to remain serious and deal with these situations in a decent way. Past that the game toned down a little but the story, REALLY, picked up for me. It moved up more and more, making it even more interesting and getting me even more into it, so much so, i found myself playing it late at night as the battle between being with the triads and being a police officer forever was nagging there, and was clearly showing for Wei as well. Much later in and near the end a lot happened, a lot had to be taken in, the game had built up this tension that just.... fell short. The ending felt like all this tension and hard work into getting me to think of either being a triad or police just wasn't brought to a full conclusion. For those who have finished.  The ending felt like you either kill big Smile Lee as either an officer of the law, or as revenge for him killing your triad friends . For those who haven't, the ending only makes you feel like you've done it for one side or the other... and nothing else than that, which was a damn shame to all that hard work going into it. Regardless, it was still fun and enjoyable. Before the ending there is also another bloody scene, which i warn, those who cannot stand blood or worse, look away when it happens, and trust me, you know when it will. Overall sleeping dogs truly got me into it, got me to battle how i felt with being an undercover cop and got me to see the grousome side of everything which happened and could happen in such a game. I look forward to the DLC and would recommend this to anyone. It is slow to get into, but damn fun and interesting once you do get into it. I would say buy with all the DLC as well, as it's more worth it that way, but either way, sleeping dogs is a damn good game and i would rate it 9/10 from everything i've played. Just make sure that during some scenes you're prepared, as much as the game seems a little goofy, it handles some truly horrifying moments seriously and well.

Posted: January 17, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is a masterpiece of open world game play, bringing many different game mechanics flawlessly into one.Character development is amazing and very likable, with many twists and turns right throughout the main storyline. The voice acting is arguably the best I've seen in games of recent, you get attached to the dialogue and the mood of some scenes is somewhat of a movie rather than a game. Combat is top notch with the kung fu fights, which you can progress even further with Wei Shen unlocking new melee skills. Gun play is also very good, not being too overly emphasised as much as melee, which is better in some way, as the melee is one of the games selling points. Being open world you are given the freedom of Hong Kong. There is always something to do while you explore the streets, from random evens which can pop up at any corner which challenge you in different scenarios to finding many hidden lock boxes scattered around. This makes the game refreshing and can give you some surprises. With a myriad of game mechanics and a story that really grips you, this rightfully gets a 9/10.

Posted: July 9, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs was both a fun game, and a fulfilling open world experience. The story was interesting and had depth, gameplay never felt repetitive as the game progressed. Graphics were good minus a few texture glitches/lighting errors. Combat was complex and diverse while retaining simplicity. Player animations were great in number, and allowed for great mobility while parkouring around the map. The world was detailed and immersive. It's easy to get enveloped in the this digital replication of Hong Kong, as the details allowed it to feel very authentic. Voice acting was mostly in English with a little Chinese added, making it both intelligible and authentic.As for negatives, they are few, but they will annoy the sh!t out of you. Bugs were not uncommon, glitchy textures/animations, AI wasn't the best, and map pathing was awful at times. Customizability for vehicles left plenty to be desired. Despite any negatives, this was a good game and definitely recommended. 8/10

												I never thought I'd get into a game so much as I have with this.Gameplay comes across as a cross between Assassin's Creed, GTA and Batman combat-wise. Not so fluid movements, but satisfying results. you rely on your bullets in this game, when you find a gun, so use them wisely.Storyline, however, is fantastic. Even if you don't like the gameplay, I seriously reccomend playing it through for the story. The ways that the characters develop is just fascinating and you find yourself wanting to know more. The only thing I wish we could've seen more of is Wei Shen's history. Maybe a future DLC? Side missions are fun to play, but not necessary unless you want to upgrade your "face" which is where you can wear certain clothes and buy certain cars to give you certain perks in the game. Fun, but not necessary. I've only just started on the DLC's so not much to say on them so far.

Posted: November 16, 2014
												I was only 9 years old I loved pork buns so much, I ate all the meat and doughy goodness I pray to Pork Bun Man every night before bed, thanking him for the pork bun in my hand. "Man who never eat pork bun," I say, "is never a whole man." My dad hears me and admits I am a failure I know he was just jealous of my devotion for Pork Pun Man I remind him he will never be a whole man He slaps me and sends me to go to sleep I'm crying now, and my face hurts I lay in bed and it's really cold Suddenly, a warmth is moving towards me It's Him I am so happy He whispers into my ear "You look like you could use a pork bun." He grabs me with his powerful hands and puts me down onto my hands and knees I'm ready I spread my budget for Him He penetrates my wallet and my very soul It hurts so much but I do it for Him I can feel my HK dollars dissapearing as my mouth starts to water I push against his force I want to please Him He roars in a mighty roar as he fills my hands with his pork buns My dad walks in Pork Bun Man looks him straight in the eyes and says, "Why don't you have a pork bun in your hand?" He leaves through my window Pork Bun Man is love. Pork Bun Man is life.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												Loved this game. It seems that it is relatively underated, but it is definitely a must-play in my opinion. Pros-Gorgeous visuals-Fully realized world-Very fun combat-Great voice acting-Compelling storyCons-Vehicle handling could use some work-Vehicle models are not as visually attractive, though they are still decent-Some inconsistencies exist: our protagonist is a "good" cop, but there are plenty of oppurtunities that make him a bad cop. Also, The story leads you to feel like you are turning in to a gangster, and leaving behind your cop mindset, yet this is not correct, you are a cop through-and-through. -The girlfriend part of the game is stupid and pointless. They aren't necessary, and they feel out of place. The protagonist is supposedly good and perhaps even a practioner of chivalry, yet you have the option to be a "player" and date multiple girls. I did not participate in this portion of the game, as it's out-of-place and out-of-character.This game is totally worth playing. It's not perfect by any means, and I wouldn't even compare it to GTA; it is a different playstyle, whereas GTA is a free-for-all satirical look at society, Sleeping Dogs is a cinematic take on Chinese gang-cop mentality, and it will really make you feel like you're in the mix of it.

Posted: January 27, 2014
												If you are a fan of Jackie Chan's a 'New Police Story' or any of the old fashioned Chinese police movies for that matter; this is definitely the game for you. It captures the vibrancy and hustle of Hong Kong with beautiful graphics and clever AI that makes the city feel real, gritty and busy; something I have rarely seen a game accomplish so well. The driving is well balanced as are the fighting and shooting mechanics; none of which ever felt repetitive or overpowered during my 42 hour play-through. The main Character Shen had an interesting story to tell and I feel Square Enix did well in development as I found him an engaging protagonist that walked the frequent line of oblivion.In short, I highly recommend picking up this game if you want to play something a little different to the norm. It is fun, immersive and captures the heart of China even if the ending is a shameless setup for the next game.8/10

Posted: August 15, 2015
												This is a 3rd person GTA style game with martial arts combat thrown into the mix. The story takes place in Hong Kong and has a strong Asian theme throughout the game, triad gangs with their codes and beliefs, art style, cars, martial arts and lots of food.You play as a undercover police officer, and a former triad member returning back from USA to Hong Kong, China. Game story evolves mostly around police, you and triads, their constant battle for power. There are lots of side activities, in form of racing, helping people with problems, busting drug deals, stealing vehicles, assassination's, random dating, etc.There are a lot of collectibles in game, some give you cash, some unlock clothes, melee moves and vehicles, others boost your health. Game plays like any GTA style game, but with some added elements. You can steal and drive cars, bikes, boats (no aircraft), you can shoot firearms, use melee weapons.A lot of killing in the game is done through martial arts melee combat. You unlock moves, perks, abilities by spending points acquired by doing missions and collecting certain collectibles. I really enjoyed the story, it has many twists and unexpected moments.Game looks and plays well, there are some low resolution textures here and there, even with high texture DLC pack. Character animations, control was good and easy to use. I really liked voice acting, it didn't have that cheap feel you get in other games where Asian characters are voiced with fake accents. There are some elements of gore in game, that may be unpleasant and not advised for those of under age.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												Buggy and serious design flaws aside, is Sleeping Dogs fun?  The short answer is yes.  The story is predictable but satisfying -- several characters that I expected to die, did -- with the exception of one.  The fact that the bugs result in ridiculous behaviour only makes the fact that the game plays itself straight all the more hilarious and adding to the entertainmnet value.Cover-combat is nicely broken up with movie-style stunts, favouring bold, aggressive play that is movie-like, entertaining and rewarding both visually and tactically but is otherwise pretty standard.  The Free-Running is perhaps too down-to-earth considering the rest of the game isn't and while a nice attempt is probably one of the weaker game elements.  The fighting has some serious design flaws that really keep it from being as good as it could be; enemy classes weaken what could have been entertaining free-flow combat by giving them uninterruptable attacks or grapple immunity which bogs down the combat flow in a forced way.  The driving seems fine, but the catch-up logic is irritating as it only applies to the computer-controlled cars making racing rely more on luck than it should.  Said driving is not keyboard friendly.Finally, the bugs.  Oh the bugs.  Bugs were the first things I encountered because during the initial chase, the person I was supposed to follow quit running halfway through and in order to continue I had to dash ahead while the game nagged me that I was leaving him behind before he promptly teleported ahead.  Sometimes key events won't fire if you are genre-savvy and plan ahead.  NPC's will get stuck frequently and occasionally have amusing pathfinding difficulties.  One time the security camera wouldn't let me exit.  And the fact that many critical actions are crippled after completing a mission will mean occasionally thugs will steal your car trying to escape you because you couldn't do anything useful until the summary finished summarizing and you dismissed it.Overall  the mechanics work with the general feel, and while fans of GTA or Saints Row will probably prefer those games to this one, it's still fun and its own unique quirks made me feel it was a enjoyable romp.

Posted: March 10, 2013
												It's hard to believe this started out as a True Crime title. It's a great undercover cop action game set in Hong Kong. The driving is arcade-y, the fighting is styled after the Batman: Arkham games except with more kung fu, and the shooting is at least as competent as any other open world game. If you liked Saints Row the Third but want something a little more grounded in reality, Sleeping Dogs is a good fit.

Posted: March 16
												This is one of the better "free roam the city in a car and kill some dudes now and then" games I've played. There's a newer, crappier version of it out now that you're expected to purchase instead that "improves" the graphics and makes the game a sloppy buggy mess.This original release is smooth, pretty, and I experienced no issues in my time with it. XBOX controller support is perfect so no worries there. The hand to hand combat is copied and pasted from the Batman Arkham series and is fun and fulfilling. Occasionally you'll get a gun with limited ammo, the story established reasoning behind this is even for cops firearms are very limited in Hong Kong. They appear often enough to keep you satiated anyway.The story is deep and interesting, and makes you care about the player character and his companions. I won't get too into it cuz go play the game but you're an undercover cop infiltrating the gangs that have taken over your home town.I'd play this over GTA V any day.

												A GTA lookalike open world sandbox playing in Hong Kong with extremely nice and fluid visuals and the best in class combat system.Golden bits:First and foremost the combat system. This is absolutely the best in the game and the best combat I ever had the chance of playing in a game that is not purely a combat game. Or maybe even including those. Combat is super fluid and adapts wonderfully to the situation while not featuring ridiculously complicated controller button combos.The abundance of good looking chicks. I mean this game features an extremely high percentage of 10/10 females wandering the streets of this city.  Mrs. Chu without a doubt. One cannot not like her to the point handling of the butcher knife. Your apartment in Central. Great shed - too bad the toilet seems to be always full of some yellow substance.Stinky bits:FOW inside apartments. While the FOW is OK during the action sequences in the city it gets terribly narrow inside apartments. Instant vomit.Racing sequences. There are 18 of these and strictly not fun. I am not saying they are difficult they are just the worst executed bits of an otherwise great game. Vehicle damage modelling. Sucks. Cars take a stupidly large amount of punishment before they explode.The 2 DLCs with achievements. They are extremely dragged out and boring. They also take away some of the skills you already got in the main game which is mad. I suggest playing the DLCs before finishing the main game in case you would wanna go for a 100% completion - otherwise they would feel very much like a bad afterthought.Stat award achievements. It is not nice having got to grind these after finishing the game. Not nice at all.All in all it is still very much Recommended. (8/10)

Posted: August 5, 2014
												Made by: United Front Games and Square EnixGenre: Third-person shooter, open world, RPGish, action-adventure, combat.Themes: Undercover drama and the fight betwen good and evill.Story: You are Wei Shen: a undercover cop. Your goal is to take out the Hong Kong triad family called "The Sun On Yee". In the beginning of the game, Wei gets caught during a drug deal that back fired. Wei gets sent to jail, in jail he finds a childhood friend named Jackie, who works for the Son On Yee. Thanks to Jackie you're now part of Winston's group. Winston is a Son On Yee "red pole" (local leader) and a leader of the Water Street Gang. From that point on you must make your way up to the top of the triad family to take it down.Gameplay: The game has an interesting focus on melee combat instead of the usual focus on gunplay. You will find yourself using your fist's more so than guns, because guns are relatively hard to get by in the streets of Hong Kong. The combat of this game is not hard only because your combos consist of spamming one button and then the occasional hold of sed button to perform a special effect like: stun, knock down or just a heavy hit. The gunplay (when you find a gun) is fun.The game has a well implemented cover mechanic. When youre behind cover you can blind fire or vault over your cover to slow down time and enter bullet time for a short period of time. Bullet time in this game is nothing like the bullet time in Max Payne, every time you get a kill it extends the time you spend in bullet time. You can literally clean up a area in Hong Kong by just shoting the living hell out of every one while in bullet time!!!(WARNING: You still need to reload, bullet time or no bullet time clips still exist.) There are two tipes of guns in this game: pistols and two handed guns. The difrence is that you can carry around a pistol, but you cant carry around any thing thats not a pistol, (Smg's, shotguns, rifles etc.) you will be forced to drop those guns when entering vehicles.The game also has some RPG elements: every time you finish a mission you get "Cop points" and "Triad points", you can use sed points to upgrade Wei's damage and resistibility to bullets, and melee damage using the triad and cop skill trees. You get cop points for doing the mission as flawless as you can. You lose cop points for doing illegal stuff like property damage, murdering innocent people etc. You get triad points for killing triads, using combos, environmental kills, or just shanking them with a knife. :p(NOTE: Only after finishing a mission you will get sed points, killing innocent civilians is still ok as long as you kill them not during a mission.)The driving is fun, it has that arcade feel of driving. While driving you can use the ram button (Yes a ram button. Problem?) to fight off enemies while driving, you can also enter bullet time if you have a pistol in your holster.The game has parkour. Though it's used for some chaise scenes and sometimes its needed to get a collectible, and that's it, you don't really use it all that much....Problems: The game ads a lot of mechanics but it doesn't try to experiment or give those mechanics a better use. The parkour is used sometimes, stealth is there when the story needs stealth and the game has boats that are only used to get to the poker mini-game!!!!Final thoughts: If you like GTA style games, but you want less gunplay, this game is right up your alley. The game is fun and filled with collectibles that reward you for collecting them, like giving you money or health upgrades. You will enjoy every minute spent in Hong Kong.

Posted: August 15, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is a gem by Square Enix.  It has all of the elements needed for a great action/drama game with fighting, driving/racing and FPS elements. Be sure to use the high-resloution DLC (free on Steam).  For me, it was better to use a controller for the driving and fighting aspects alone.  This game also supports wide-screen resolutions.  I am very glad to have experienced this title and applaud Square Enix on thier continued line of quality games.

"Man who never eat pork bun," I say, "is never a whole man." My dad hears me and admits I am a failure I know he was just jealous of my devotion for Pork Pun Man I remind him he will never be a whole man He slaps me and sends me to go to sleep I'm crying now, and my face hurts I lay in bed and it's really cold Suddenly, a warmth is moving towards me It's Him I am so happy He whispers into my ear "You look like you could use a pork bun." He grabs me with his powerful hands and puts me down onto my hands and knees I'm ready I spread my budget for Him He penetrates my wallet and my very soul It hurts so much but I do it for Him I can feel my HK dollars dissapearing as my mouth starts to water I push against his force I want to please Him He roars in a mighty roar as he fills my hands with his pork buns My dad walks in Pork Bun Man looks him straight in the eyes and says, "Why don't you have a pork bun in your hand?" He leaves through my window Pork Bun Man is love. Pork Bun Man is life.

Posted: June 23, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs is GTA 4 with parkour and good combat and bullet-time. That's it really. It's GTA 4 mashed up with Hong Kong cinema. It's pretty glorious. The combat in this game is really just a simplified Arkham Asylum, which is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing good for a GTA clone, considering how wrong they always get it. You've got pretty simple X, X, X, hold X combos, with different amount of X's pre-hold giving you different sweet combos. You've got a grapple that you can follow up with arm-breaking, tossing them off a ledge, or just, you know, bashin' their face in. You have all sorts of sweet kicks. It's pretty martial-artsy of course but it's less trying to look cool (although it does) and more about no nonsense killing dudes with your body. Also you can grab people and throw them in dumpsters or impale them on meat hooks or smash them into a box full of broken glass (yeah I don't know why there are boxes full of broken glass everywhere.) The driving feels good, but I can't remember how driving felt in GTA 4. It probably apes that as well so if you're one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who couldn't deal with that you'll probably hate it. But you can hang out of your car window and shoot out tires and♥♥♥♥♥♥and when you start shooting the game goes into slow motion so you can actually do it without crashing into a wall, which is cool. This is a pretty spergy thing, but I really like the freeway system in this game. It loops around the whole city with lots of nice on-ramps and exchanges everywhere and apparently I love that♥♥♥♥♥♥because I like just getting on the freeway and going fast. This game has ♥♥♥♥loads of bullet-time. You punch a guy with your gun out? Aim your gun after and you get some bullet-time. Vault over your cover? Aim your gun and guess what? ♥♥♥♥in' bullet-time. Headshot 3 guys before you land, it's awesome.Oh yeah, and you can jump out of your car and onto another car and steal it in motion. That♥♥♥♥♥♥owns, so do that a bunch.The story is ok, I guess. It's serviceable at least. You're an undercover cop in with the triads, and guess what, spoiler alert, you get too close to your gangster buddies and loyalties get conflicted. You're way too good at what you do and kill a billion people so you end up promoted to the top of the organization way too fast. You know, standard stuff. I am pretty curious how you end up getting off scot-free after how many people you've killed. The Hong Kong PD are pretty ♥♥♥♥ing corrupt, I guess. Well they are cops. ACABOh, and if you're a sperglord like me, it puts all the collectibles on the minimap. Thank ♥♥♥♥ing god. For some reason they unlock after you bone down on the various women you encounter throughout the story. I think Wei ♥♥♥♥s just about every woman he encounters. So I guess that's cool, or troubling, maybe. I can't decide. I guess his karaoke powers and street fighting skillz are just enough to overlook the ridiculous clothing he's (probably) wearing.Time to wait for the DLC to go on sale.

Posted: December 6, 2013
												An enjoyable take on the GTA formula, don't expect anything new but what is done is done fairly well. A collection of GTA type mission structures and driving mixed in with the melee systems of Batman, Remember Me and inFAMOUS, you won't find a lot of gunplay but the martial arts style does work and carries the game fairly well, although at some points I found it got bit tedious. The story won't win any awards and relies on a lot of tropes but it's paced well enough to keep you going.Sleeping Dogs is an enjoyable enough game, it's biggest problem being that it doesnt really offer anything innovative, relying on its setting more than anything to be its point of difference. With GTA V it looks somewhat dated but it's still worth checking out if you're into the genre, just don't expect any revelations.

Posted: January 23, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs captures the atmosphere of Hong Kong and throws you into the life of Wei Shen, undercover cop-extraordinaire. Through the 30 story missions, you grow fond of the characters and the visceral life of the triads. The fight mechanics are wonderful once you get a hang of it (play defensively) though the collectibles are very much a grind. Cantonese speakers will find this to be a diamond in the rough with its not-so-subtle use of profanity and cultural mannerisms. On the surface, however, those who are unfamiliar with Hong Kong might perceive this as an exaggerated dose of stereotypes. This is definitely an under-appreciated game that is worth a look!

												Great artwork, well written story, diverse music selection, fantastic sand boxed freedom of enviorment, high replay potential, and more kung fu than you can shake a tire iron at.Worth the money even at retail, and a real bargin if you can get it for less. If you like GTA, fighting games, racing games, detective stories and RPG I suggest you give this game a shot.Great care was given to the behavior of ambient residents of Hong Kong. I was impressed to see dock workers working, traffic adjusted by working hours,  and people cleaning floors at the club in the off hours. Everywhere you look, people are doing their own thing and the variety of  behaviors is not to underestimated in the games value of setting you firmly in a living cinematic experience. The amount of 3d modeled objects is overwhelming. I wish I could play it in 3D which is also avaiable.I am not a franchise fan easily, but in this case I hope for more  from this development team.

Great shed - too bad the toilet seems to be always full of some yellow substance.Stinky bits:FOW inside apartments. While the FOW is OK during the action sequences in the city it gets terribly narrow inside apartments. Instant vomit.Racing sequences. There are 18 of these and strictly not fun. I am not saying they are difficult they are just the worst executed bits of an otherwise great game. Vehicle damage modelling. Sucks. Cars take a stupidly large amount of punishment before they explode.The 2 DLCs with achievements. They are extremely dragged out and boring. They also take away some of the skills you already got in the main game which is mad. I suggest playing the DLCs before finishing the main game in case you would wanna go for a 100% completion - otherwise they would feel very much like a bad afterthought.Stat award achievements. It is not nice having got to grind these after finishing the game. Not nice at all.All in all it is still very much Recommended. (8/10)

Posted: March 16
												This is one of the better "free roam the city in a car and kill some dudes now and then" games I've played. There's a newer, crappier version of it out now that you're expected to purchase instead that "improves" the graphics and makes the game a sloppy buggy mess.This original release is smooth, pretty, and I experienced no issues in my time with it. XBOX controller support is perfect so no worries there. The hand to hand combat is copied and pasted from the Batman Arkham series and is fun and fulfilling. Occasionally you'll get a gun with limited ammo, the story established reasoning behind this is even for cops firearms are very limited in Hong Kong. They appear often enough to keep you satiated anyway.The story is deep and interesting, and makes you care about the player character and his companions. I won't get too into it cuz go play the game but you're an undercover cop infiltrating the gangs that have taken over your home town.I'd play this over GTA V any day.

Posted: March 21, 2013
												I had heard quite a bit of pleasantly-surprised hype about this game. Apparently everyone expected something that sucked, due to the game's storied past - it was originally a True Crime game? So when it went on sale I decided to pick it up for myself. You've probably played this game in one form or another, it's a GTA-alike sandbox game, only this time, it's heavily Chinese-influenced, set in Hong Kong. The setting is probably the best part of this game, it's both well-fleshed out and novel, and the game seems to sport more of a "living" environment than the sometimes sterile underpopulated cities of other GTAlikes. That said there are only a few mission types, and they tend to repeat themselves over and over. The game starts with a parkour chase-scene, and you do chase-scene after chase-scene, after chase-scene. You'll hate them by the end of the game. What is interesting is the game's combat- there are few guns, at least initially, and you dispatch most enemies with a well fleshed out kung-fu system. The story missions carry the plot, though without much pacing. It's a rags-to-riches criminal tale with a twist, you're an uncover cop, trying to move up in the mob. Things kind of meander along until it just suddenly ends- they could have easily cut the story in half. There's a ton of padding in the form of side missions, but those are nearly always more repetitive than refreshing. I'd place the game higher than the GTA-series, but it's not nearly as good as Saints Row. Pleased I picked it up on sale, if you're interested, you should too.

Posted: March 22
												I've yet to finish this game and I still love it and would recommend it. At first, I thought it was just going to be a basic "do bunch of criminal activities while secretly a cop", but I was so wrong. There is a legitimate story here, and the intensity with which it builds surprised me greatly. In fact, after a major event close to halfway through (not going to spoil it, but you'll know it when you see it), I actually nearly shed tears. For the game to make me that invested in the characters and what happens to them is proof of how great it is. Wei Shen is a badass, but the game clearly pushes his character HARD, and it's amazing to see the difference in him as the story progresses and he's drawn further and further into not only the goings on within the Triads, but his mission as a cop as well.I personally love that there's a HUGE RPG aspect to this as well. You have three different experience sections. Cop Experience which increases as you do cases for the police and drug busts, but also completing missions without any damage to people or property, Triad Experience which is given for kicking♥♥♥♥♥and being as violent as you can possibly be, and Face Experience which is gained through favors for various people around Hong Kong. I don't think there's any reward/penalty to working one over the other and leveling each allows you to pick new perks. Overall, it felt like the rewards for progression were quite valuable.There's a lot to say, but obviously I'm not going to write a novel about it :P In short, you can level up, you can buy new clothes that also give passive bonuses for wearing sets (or just look whatever part you want), you can spiff up your apartments if you just need to blow some cash, there's stuff to collect to gain more money, increase your HP, or learn new moves as part of a side quest....basically it's filled to the brim with anything an RPG fan would want.So yes....give a shot. It's an impressive game and one I've let go for too long.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												I love the combat system in the game, it really captures being a streat thug. Most people bring up GTA when personally I found this game more comparable to games like Assasins Creed and Arkham City with the heavy focus on melee. It has a unique story that actually fits the world, and feels real. You are a undercover cop with close connections with the Triads, some maybe... too close. But it doesn't do that BS "choose a side, one or the other." instead you watch Wei struggle with both, and it's a better game/story because of it. Definitely worth a play-through, although a lot of the DLC you can live without.

Posted: August 9, 2013
												First of all let me say one thing, this is the most similar thing to what I wanted GTA IV to be. That said, I can only complement this game, it is really well optimized and I cannot say enough how I enjoyed my time with this title despite not completing every single race and challenge. The gameplay of Sleeping Dogs focus on melee combat with a huge variety of combos along with the driving. The melee combat  reminded me of Assassins Creed but only better, you can learn new moves by completing challenges and/or missions and these will help you on later main story missions. The driving is probably the best I've seen on an open world game like this, it might not have planes and choppers but the car driving is REALLY enjoyable, I didn't liked riding bikes though. The soundtrack really fits the theme of the game that is set in Hong Kong and the landscape ranges from mundane places to skyscrappers fully covered with advertisement and neon lights. The game also features a multiple set of houses that you gain as you progress through the main story and near those places you find a parking lot which will grant you access to all your vehicles that you've bought. Let's just say it has basicly all the elements of games like Saints Row and GTA clothing, food, cars etc. Now the story is quite good in my honest opinion and it features an undercover cop (the player) that returned to Hong Kong after living on the USA for years and he infiltrates the Triads not only in order to cripple one of the main gangs but also because he's on a personal crusade to deal with issues from the past. Other than that, you'll have to find it by yourself by playing the game, I cannot recommend it enough. Buy it, play it, enjoy it.

Posted: September 1, 2012
												A mixture of Max Payne and GTA; this game is a must play. The story resembles a classic "Kung-Fu Action Film" in which Wei Shen (the protagonist) plays as an undercover cop in Hong Kong, trying to bring down the overwelming Triad force that rules the city. It's chaotic, heartwarming, bloody, and beautiful at the same time. The game is packed with all sorts of missions and side missions, including melee fights, gun fights, training in the Dojo to learn new moves, racing, dating, drug busting, collecting sports cars, chicken fights, photography, car chases, karaoke, going to fight clubs, and more. I should also mention the combat and movement, which is superb. Kung-fu melee combat AND freeroaming with parkour? Phenomenal.All I can say is that if you're looking for a great freeroaming game with a compelling story, or a freeroam that's looking to spice things up a bit; this game is for you. This game does need some fairly decent hardware if you want it to run properly, and I highly recommend getting the HD Texturepack. I'm definitely looking forward to a sequel!Enjoy.

Posted: April 7, 2013
												Fluid combat, upgrades, customization, a wide variety of available side missions and a well written story makes Sleeping Dogs one of the best open world games I've ever played. If you like these kinds of games, I suggest you pick this one up whenever you can.You take the role of an undercover cop with a history of violence who is given the task of destroying the Triad from the inside-out. However as the story progresses things go from just business to personal matters. The story is really down-to-earth, and the characters are relatable enough to get the full enjoyment out of the missions.Even after finishing the game there is plenty of things left to do. Buy new clothes, max your upgrades, participate in street races, or even go sing karaoke. Hong Kong is your playground.The melee combat is what really sold me on this game. The ability to string together my own combos, learn new moves, and even use the environment was a refreshing change from the usual run-and-gun gameplay open world games seem to lean towards.A fantastic game all around. I'll definitely start a second playthough.

Posted: February 18, 2015
												A lengthy and engaging undercover cop story merged with a metric ton of variety-filled missions and smooth martial arts combat. Unlike most open-world games, the missions don't devolve into repetitive slogs through waves of enemies. Karaoke, street-racing, gang wars, dates, and stealth missions are balanced perfectly for a carefully concocted recipe of Hong Kong brawling, gun-fighting goodness.FYI, I played this game for many more than 6 hours. I'm not always online when I play games (see my Tomb Raider Legend review too, where it says I've only played it for 0 hours, but when in reality I've played it for more than 10 hours). I would put my estimate for Sleeping Dogs at around 20 hours.

												Sleeping Dogs is everything I wanted from a GTA set in Hong Kong. If you wanted Infernal Affairs and a healthy sprinking of action from every Jackie Chan movie ever, this game is perfect!The storyline is well written and impressively acted. You play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop, who needs to choose between loyalty to his new criminal brethren or to his duty as a police officer, people on both sides get suspicious, tense moments of untrustworthy accusations, etc. Kind of cliche, to be honest. If you've seen Infernal Affairs, or one of the many Hong Kong police dramas (or the US version The Departed) you have a general sense of what the story is about. Unfortunately the ending is a bit lackluster and you don't really get to make too many choices in the game. Nevertheless, it was interesting enough to keep me engaged for the 20 hour or so through the main storyline.The more melee focused combat is something more akin to the Arkham series and is fun to enough to keep your interested through the entire game. There is some good ol' cover based shooting/ sweet slow motion but I felt like that was definitely the weakest part of the combat. You can do a bunch of badass♥♥♥♥♥♥like jack a car by jump from a moving car to another moving car so it's usually pretty fun to get into fights.Sleeping Dogs unfortunately falls into the familiar trap of "Go here, beat up that guy", or "Go here and steal this car." that plague so many open world games. Still, the game is so cheap during sales these days, and the combat is so fun you'll find yourself walking around the streets just cruisin' for a bruisin'.I'd highly recommend this is if you're into GTA or Action films in general, it's a lot of fun for the price and the DLCs can be some goofy fun.

The combat very closely resembles that of Batman: Arkham City however doesn't feel as smooth, regardless anyone who enjoyed that series will probably enjoy this.

												This totally surprised me. Honk Kong is great place for sandbox game, and map is quite damn large. Game is mostly based on melee combat, but you'll also have weapons later in game. Melee system is great, it has lots of different moves to learn. Game has lots of vehicles, motorcycles and cars. You can steal any car from street as you should, or you can pay taxidriver to take you where you want if you're too lazy to drive yourself, and then rob his car. Most cars are fast, and pretty easy to control. You can buy yourself cars, which will be added to garage.Storyline is about undercover cop, if someone did not know that, it is interesting, but nothing spectacular. Sound acting is in  English, and some Chinese phrases are part of it.Game has about 20 hours of gameplay, which also includes some of collectibles.I was interested in this game, and decided to buy it when it was on sale. I do not regret buying it, it is great game, one of my favorites in 2012.
