												This sandbox game does so many things right. The combat (mostly unarmed brawling) is lifted directly from Batman: Arkham Asylum, the story is engaging, the controls are tight (gamepad recommended), the city (Hong Kong) is exotic and interesting, the RPG elements reward completionists like myself, and most importantly, checkpoints are frequent so you rarely have to redo an entire mission from scratch unless you want to.The only thing I feel is missing is more/deeper character customization, but that's par for the course with every non-RPG sandbox game outside of the Saint's Row.

Posted: October 30, 2013
												Well worth the current $5 dollar price tag! Sleeping Dogs is unfortunately an underrated gem of a game. Originally under fruition as True Crime Hong Kong, Sleeping Dogs came to be when Square Enix revived this IP. The player takes charge of the main character named Wei Shen. Wei acts as an undercover police offficer who becomes deeply involved with the Triad underground. As the story progresses the player begins to learn about Wei's background and how he got into this predicament. Full of action, adventure, and emotions, Sleeping Dogs is in my opinion a solid 8.5 out of 10. With amazing voice acting, a riveting story, interesting characters, and an open world that feels alive, Sleeping Dogs is sure to entertain any free roam/single player advocates!

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Sleeping Dogs is a fantastic Open-world sandbox Game with a great Story and an awesome atmosphere. Single Objects in the world may not look like they are from Crysis, but all together just looks so great. The PC Port is good, plenty Settings and Adjustments to be made. It even supports 3D and you can scale the HUD size, which is something not a lot of games support.The Story, as mentioned above is really good, you can sometimes expect what will happen which is not that good, but all in all is pretty good and not too serious. You play as undercover Cop, trying to lock down the Leader of the Triads. There are plenty of missions to do in the Huge Map, like racing, doing Favors for people and figthing. The ending is reasonable satisfying, but after I finished the main story (approx. 20 Hours with some side-missions), there is no incentive to do the remaining side-missions.Sidenote: You need a pretty beefy System to run this game at higher than low details. On my 500 euro PC with an i3 and a Radeon HD 7750 it runs at ~50 FPS, 1080p and min details.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												Absolutely great and overlooked game! The matial arts combat is very remincent of the Batman Arham games and is polished. The gun play is alright and it's relative rarity compared to the hand to hand combat keeps it fresh. It has great visuals, the city seems alive and colorful, and the driving is silky smooth. Finally, the story mode is engaging and well voice acted. Similar to other 'open world' games, there are  a variety of side missions and minigames--such as kareokee. Would definately recommend, especially given a discounted price.

Posted: November 27, 2013
												A spiritual successor to the 'True Crimes' series, Sleeping Dogs is a rebirth of what the True Crimes game SHOULD have been like. An open world game of this genre that takes place outside of the United States (or an implied) is a fresh and nice change of scenery. Sleeping Dogs takes place in Hong Kong, the home base of the Chinese Triads. You play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop that walks a very thin line between loyalites. Sleeping Dogs takes on the Hong Kong cop genre and does a fantastic job of telling you a story backed with fun gameplay.The visuals of the game is solid and it is to be expected out of any game with Square Enix label on it. Especially in cutscenes, everything is crisp. Which is important for a story driven game such as this one. In game graphics shows the enviroment very well. When it rains, the clothing on Wei does get wet and it shows. Little details, like blood and bruises after getting into a brawl shows up on Wei's face and on his clothing as well.  Damage to cars is admittedly, pretty standard in these games. Paint will be scratched up if you brush up too closely to another car and bullet holes will show up if shot at. Visuals are at its finest at the most important aspects of the game, while some little details could have used a little more work.Gameplay might be a little different from what people expect from an open world game of this type of genre. While you can go on shooting rampages and crime spree when you are free roaming, it isn't anything like the calibur of GTA. You don't start out with a gun or have any places to buy weapons, melee combat is the name of the game in Sleeping Dogs. You'll be punching, kicking and slamming your enemies down on the ground alot. The melee combat is fairly firmilar to the Arkham games, but isn't as stylish. They mix it up a bit by throwing different types of enemies, like certain enemies cannot be grabbed and certain enemies dish out more damage than others. Enemies could have used more work and variations. You can upgrade your melee skins by collecting Jade Statues, which unlocks new melee combo strings or get triad upgrades which you get buffs and more combo strings. Combat is passable in this game and you shouldn't be detered by the fact it isn't just like the Arkham games.Sleeping Dogs is a very story driven game. You play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop on a mission to infiltrate the ranks of the Triad. Wei throughout the game is faced with conflicting loyalities, he has a personal vendetta to settle with one of the members and has to deal with his growing attachment towards the triads. The story and setting really does feel like a hong kong cop drama. Overall, Sleeping Dogs is a solid buy. It has enough side missions to extend gameplay. Some of the best side missions are the street races. It is a nice change of pace from triple A titles. Its definitely a cult hit. Definitely worth putting in your library of games. Sleeping Dogs is an experience that won't disappoint you.Sleeping Dogs has quite a few DLCs with it, here is a list of DLCs that is worth getting. 1. Year of the Snake. A post game DLC that gives Wei a police mission to stop something big going down in the Chinese New Years.2. Nightmare on North Point. A stand alone DLC that has Wei fighting Chinese vampires and a vengeful spirit of a dead and forgotten triad leader.3. Zodiac Tournament. A DLC that is intergrated with the main game. A throwback to the 70s with corny Kung Fu action that pits Wei with some of the worlds finest martial artist and a corny plot. (Story has nothing to do with the main story)4. Street Racer Pack. Adds 3 more challenging races to the game. (Not worth getting at full price, wait for a sale on this one)The rest of the DLC are almost all cosmetic, unless you really want more outfits and access to certain guns for Wei, its better to buy them when there is a sale. Not worth getting at full price.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												Expected a 'cheap thrill gta-clone. Was pleasantly suprised. Sleeping Dogs offers an interesting storyline that explores the moral gaps between the archetypical 'good' and 'bad'. The inevitable climax was satisfying in its execution (pun intended) but left me with a terrible aftertaste from what happened. Ultimately, the pacing was good and the delivery often excellent, although characters didn't always get the chance to fully develop beyond what was required in order to act as a development 'tool' for the protagonist.In regards to gameplay, i was very satisfied. Sleeping Dogs borrows many elements from other franchises. Free-running through the city had an AC-touch to it. Shootouts were heavily inspired by Max Payne and driving reminded me of NFS. Most of the gameplay revolving action (shooting, driving) felt fluent and leaned heavily towards an arcade style. Meaning fast and destructive action had precedence over 'realism'. This can sway some people away from the game, but in my opinion it is a proper design choice - it stands in nice contrast with the ever-looming shadow that is the GTA franchise.Overall, this game is quite good. The world is fleshed out with a lot of content; missions, jobs, favors, events, minigames; a lot of things are present to ensure that there is enough to do besides playing out the storyline which, because it's an open world crime game, felt relatively short clocking in at ~15 hours.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												This game has some really strong points. The combat is fresh, interesting and progressive. If you ever want to feel like a badass, this is the game. I was pleasantly surprised how little it relies on gun use, but for those who really enjoy FPS games this isn't for you, as the gun options are little in selection. The focus is in the melee combat, and the attention it gives is great. It's not very hard to get into, but still very satisfying to play. The next big aspect of this game I loved is the environment, and installing the free High-res graphics DLC doesn't change it as much as I expected, but still makes it pop. You may not enjoy it nearly as much as I did without running it on high graphics, but it's still very attractive (I've always liked the slums of hong kong scene, not sure why but it's really cool)  The driving was a little bit odd, but once you purchase a high-end vehicle it only adds to the badass-itude. The story was a little generic, just with Asian flair, but not necessarily disappointing. I'd very much recommend the game, I grabbed it on sale but $20 for it still worth a grab.

Posted: October 30, 2013
												Well worth the current $5 dollar price tag! Sleeping Dogs is unfortunately an underrated gem of a game. Originally under fruition as True Crime Hong Kong, Sleeping Dogs came to be when Square Enix revived this IP. The player takes charge of the main character named Wei Shen. Wei acts as an undercover police offficer who becomes deeply involved with the Triad underground. As the story progresses the player begins to learn about Wei's background and how he got into this predicament. Full of action, adventure, and emotions, Sleeping Dogs is in my opinion a solid 8.5 out of 10. With amazing voice acting, a riveting story, interesting characters, and an open world that feels alive, Sleeping Dogs is sure to entertain any free roam/single player advocates!

Posted: January 4, 2014
												Sleeping Dogs is a game NOT To be missed if you are a fan of third person sandbox games like Saints Row Or GTA, Sleeping Dogs has an amusing attention to detail, Gorgeous Graphics, Awesomely optimized, and it stands as a perfect Middle between Saints Row`s Goofiness And GTA`s Realism, making it feel fun, With An arcadey feel while mantaining a serious tone In a Down to Earth Universe.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												8.5/10Excellent game. If you're looking for a fresh new experience in gaming, definitely pick this game up. The open-world is extremely polished and detailed, giving a truly immersive experience. The volumetric lighting, food vendors, soda machines, rusty air conditioners, high density vehicles and NPCs, real-time weather change, and local radio are all present as if you were actually in Hong Kong. The story is strongly focused and engaging as you control an undercover cop to reveal the dark world of the Triads. The gameplay is solid. The shooting mechanics are fluid and action-packed. The guns are big and satisfying to use. As for the driving component, you'll feel like a true asian ricer blazing through the night life. When you have to fight, the combos are easy to memorize and satisfying to execute. Unlike the original True Crime, there's actually strategy involved than just mindless button mashing.However, the game is intended to be played linearly (which I prefer actually) and not like a sandbox. So, the replay value is limited if you're concerned.

Posted: September 9, 2012
												It's like playing through a movie, staring a modern Bruce Lee. Despite the stiff faced animations and some of the cliche plot elements, Sleeping Dogs is a wonderful game to play. I love open world games, especially ones set in a city, being set in Hong Kong was just the iceing on the cake. The gangster themes in this make some of the concepts in the GTA series look tame...beating a cheating girlfriend to a pulp, throwing her in the trunk of your stolen car, and then pushing her face into a table saw? That's just f**ked for the lack of better words. But that's the kind of stuff you'll have to get used to in the underground world of Hong Kong, it's dark, brutal, draws you in.

Posted: January 2
												--TL:DR--Sleeping Dogs is what would happen if the gameplay from GTA 4 and the setting+story from Rush Hour 2 combined and made a baby game that later got married in life to the combat system from Arkham Asylum. It's good.--The Good--Combat: This combat system feels like you are Bruce Lee (RIP) and the entire gang population of Hong Kong decided all at once to test your skills in honorable combat. The dishonorable ones are those with firearms, instead of finding your own, teach them a lesson in the way of the dragon. Also, there are multi-target counters, and yes they are awesome. The depth of the combat system is a great core foundation, there are grapples, environmental attacks, melee weapons, ranged weapons, combos, heavy/light attacks (with variants of each level of combo). Overall a great combat system.Story: Undercover cop dives into the criminal underworld of Hong Kong to usurp the leadership and bring down the crime families from the inside. A premise that has been done before in film, and it is nice to see a quality interpretation of this type of story done in a video game. The pacing is structured between gang missions and police missions, giving you the story at a pace that you decide. It also allows for both sides of the story be told seperately and interestingly they occasionally interset. Overall good story.Characters: From the main protagonist and his own personal demons as he infiltrates his childhood friends gang turf, to the leaders of each respective gang and the respect they garner. I found each character to be well crafted as well as acted. There are some bad characters however, most notably the "tourist" from america who occasionally pops up looking for martial arts training. She is well acted but the character just feels forced.--The Bad--Gunplay: Complaining about bad gunplay in a kungfu game is like complaining you had a fly in your soup that you got for free with a really good sandwich. The sandwich being the best part of the meal and the soup (being secondary to the main dish) was a little bit disapointing that you found a fly in it. Gunplay in Sleeping Dogs is just bad, no lie. There are situations where you wish you could shoot the main character into melee range so the beat downs can continue. I personally am not a fan, as the firearms don't have a quality sound nor do they feel good. It works but its not the focus of the combat.--The Meh--Sidemissions: Not much of note here. They are typical open world fair, defeat the bad guys on the corner, street race, collect treasure, ect. There are a few stand outs like kareoke, as well as the training you can do after collecting a statue for your masters dojo (something about beating up kung fu students in those missions is great)

Posted: September 30, 2014
												Didn't know what to expect going in to this one but it had been on the "need to play" list for a while and I'm glad I finally got around to it.  The gameplay in Sleeping Dogs is top notch.  Everything felt fluid and not a beat was skipped between fighting, cutscenes, gunplay, driving, etc.  The gameplay sort ofdraws comparsions to GTA, Assassin's Creed, Jade Empire and Max Payne, borrowing elements from them all. The mission/quest system works great with the world map and they are done well.  Even the side missions are done well, from racing to beating up crooks I found myself doing side missions, which is odd for me.  It has a super cool story and it was presented well with great graphics.  Overall it was a great game and worth playing for anyone wanting a story driven, open world, action game.

When you have to fight, the combos are easy to memorize and satisfying to execute. Unlike the original True Crime, there's actually strategy involved than just mindless button mashing.However, the game is intended to be played linearly (which I prefer actually) and not like a sandbox. So, the replay value is limited if you're concerned.

Posted: January 21, 2014
												Loads of fun and violence! It reminded me of Yakuza (Playstation exclusive) but sandboxed and with more friendly and showy combat system. There are some environmental "finishers" which add a taste to the fights. Good, engaging story. The game is action packed for those who don't want/need to do the "side quests" otherwise it can be repetitive. Especially weak are the favors.DLCsThe Year of the Snake - kind of sucks, short and dull. Two not-so-good cutscenes - totaly not worth it.Nightmare in North Point - the story is not so bad, zombies are good, but it's short.Zodiac Tournament - very cool addon, tough fights, nice story but again short.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												Probably one of the most fun single player games I've ever played. There are a lot of fun missions and sub-missions to do, and while you're not doing missions it's fun just to play around in the world. content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Growing up in the 80's and being an Asian, one could not help but to dream about playing a triad gangster. This is Hong Kong. Knockoff capital and triad homeground.The game puts you in the shoes of Wei Shen, a Asian American undercover cop assigned to inflitrate a triad gang, the Sun On Yee.One of the things that will get you on the get go is how the game world is alive with the environs of Hong Kong, complete with street peddlers, suits and the seedy underbelly of the city all for you to explore. The sights and sounds immersion was enough to get you into playing the role of Wei Shen, a cop with a deeper agenda on why he wants to destroy the Sun On Yee. Rating:-Graphics - 8/10 - the best parts of the game happens at night/rain cycleSounds - 8/10 - listening to rap music on HK radio stations while jacking a car? Check.Game Immersion - 7/10 - random padestrians hurling abuse at you if you decide to bang into cars while driving.Combat Mechanics - 6/10 - melee combat is awesome but gunplay lacks realism e.g. no recoilFun Factor - 9/10 - used a fish to beat up a thug in a night club. Fish survived.Overall : 7.5/10 - would be higher if the devs decided to actually not have to re-release the game with tweaks long after people have finished it (am looking at you SD:Definitive Edition)tl;dr - if you haven't gotten it yet, buy it. if you have and already completed it, consider getting the DLCs. One of it pays tribute to the Hong Kong kung-fu filems ala Bruce Lee style.

Posted: September 14, 2015
												This review is for the original version + all the DLC. There will not be any spoilers. Tl;dr at the bottom.So after completing Sleeping Dogs on the Xbox 360 I decided to pick it up for the PC. When I heard the review about the definitive edition I decided it would be best to trade for the complete collection instead, and I have no regrets. The game runs smooth on my pc, probably 50-60 frames when it's raining with the high resolution texture pack. Speaking of graphics the game's visuals are greatly improved making it a pleasure to look at. Just seeing the glowing neon signs popping out everwhere gives this game a certain charm only Deus Ex: Human Revolution (One of my favorite games despite me not even getting to the first boss.) could give me. It's basically eye candy for you neon fans out there. Sleeping Dogs is more of a game that you drive around and look at, but that doesn't mean that the gameplay isn't great. Taking its fighting from the Batman series may be boring in most cases, but in Sleeping Dogs the combat animations make fighting a lot more interesting than other Batman combat clones. For the DLC, I've been enjoying the cop missions as well as the story. Speaking of the story I think it's well executed for its theme, but I won't go into detail since it's best just to play it for yourself. The DLC is looking good so far, but for new players I wouldn't pick up the Gold + Silver pack because it raises you to almost the end-game stats. I would only recommend getting those two packs if you're done/almost done with the game. There is a lot of DLC, too. 24 packs to be exact, but I've enjoyed all of it so far. The outfits are designed very well and the new cars are interesting to look at and fun to drive. I haven't played the DLC missions yet though, but I'm guessing that they're going to be fun based on everything I've seen so far.tl;dr With the striking new visuals (for an xbox 360 user), great performance, and fun Batman combat I'd recommend anyone that played the 360 version or haven't even played the game yet to get your hands on the original + DLC. You won't be dissapointed and it's far from just another Grand Theft Auto clone.

Posted: December 2, 2016
												I haven't finished a Grand Theft Auto game - yet I own 4 of them and have played each. Sleeping Dogs on the other hand has gripped me from the start. It's an open world game centered around a rather boilerplate crime thriller narrative that's elevated due to the impressive voice talent behind it, including Emma Stone, Lucy Lu, Tom Wilkinson (Batman Begins, RocknRolla, Shakespere In Love etc. - if you love movies you know), & legend James Hong (Bladerunner, Big Trouble in Little China) among others. Set in Hong Kong the game offers a nice level of visual enticement and variety for a game set in the present. As with any open world game there is the main narrative or side objectives to explore as well as the city itself, all of which keep you engaged as you sift through its different layers. The soundtrack (via radio stations) is also particularly outstanding, offering a catalog of tunes from Warp Records and Ninja Tune among others (for those in the know). Sleeping Dogs isn't exceptional or unique in its offering, but it is exceptionally competent and a worthwhile adventure.

Posted: April 7, 2013
												Fluid combat, upgrades, customization, a wide variety of available side missions and a well written story makes Sleeping Dogs one of the best open world games I've ever played. If you like these kinds of games, I suggest you pick this one up whenever you can.You take the role of an undercover cop with a history of violence who is given the task of destroying the Triad from the inside-out. However as the story progresses things go from just business to personal matters. The story is really down-to-earth, and the characters are relatable enough to get the full enjoyment out of the missions.Even after finishing the game there is plenty of things left to do. Buy new clothes, max your upgrades, participate in street races, or even go sing karaoke. Hong Kong is your playground.The melee combat is what really sold me on this game. The ability to string together my own combos, learn new moves, and even use the environment was a refreshing change from the usual run-and-gun gameplay open world games seem to lean towards.A fantastic game all around. I'll definitely start a second playthough.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												Incredible game.It more or less combines two of my favourite open-world crime franchises;The sprawling, detailed close-to-life locations GTA and the bone-smashing melee combat of Yakuza.Would have loved a sequel to this one, but alas it seems not to be on the cards.

Posted: April 6, 2015
												Sleeping Dogs has never been a game at the top of my must play list, to me it was just another GTA clone. But with the latest Humble Bumble package that it was included with, I thought why not give it a go.I’m glad I did too, as its not at all what I expected. Yes its an open world sandbox game, but that’s pretty much where the similarity’s end. In Sleeping Dogs you wont find yourself taking on hundreds of police witha machine gun and RPG, you wont be stealing cars constantly ether. Sleeping Dogs is very much a re-imagining of the genre.Sleeping Dogs puts you in the role of an undercover cop trying to rather successfully infiltrate the triads, the twist being your never completely sure that he hasn’t turned. The character grew up inthe neighborhood and many of your missions involve people he grew up with. It adds an interesting layer to the story, your not just finding out about other characters but also yourself. The Hong Kong that Sleeping Dogs puts you in is not the biggest map out there but its densely populated and really gives the impression of a living breathing city. A lot of work has gone into it and itreally shows, the best example being the night market that you spend much of the start of the game in. People browse the stalls, have conversations, interact with each other and you. At times its easy to forget your missionand get drawn into it all.The missions are good, they make you feel like your watching a gangster film. That’s probably because you’ll spot many elements taken from such films. But I’m not complaining about that, there wellput together and flow. The side missions tend to vary from the average too, instead of for instance taxi missions or pimp missions like the other big titles you will be doing favors for people. These favors couldbe doing free running or stopping a thief and even singing karaoke. But there are racing missions and fight clubs like most sandbox’s. Sleeping Dogs offers the player an upgrade system that’s quite unique too, there are three areas to upgrade. The first is Triad, the experience for this skill are earned through doing triad missionsand criminal acts. The second is Police where the reverse is true, this makes the player walk a tightrope of sorts trying to stay clean while being a criminal. The last skill is Face, this is increased by improving peoplesview of you through favors and such. Its also worth noting though not a skill per-say you can also improve your fighting skills through finding lost Jade statues for the local gym owner.And talking of the fighting, Sleeping Dogs does a great job with this, I’ve hear some compare it to the Arkham games but I disagree. The combat is far more methodical and slower paced. If you go in throwing punches willy nilly the game will punish you, you’ll find yourself waiting for counters and then throwing a few attacks in and back to waiting again. This might sound boring, but when playing its very inviting and seems to fit the whole style of the game well.This game try’s hard to be different from the rest, it succeeds well too. You can steal a car, but you can’t keep it. Your garage is for purchased cars only. You can use guns, but only carry handgun concealed and most of the time you will be using hand to hand combat. The game feels fresh and new, but its not perfect by any means.My one biggest gripe with this title is the driving, now its not terrible by any means but feels stiff and not natural. Its certainly better than some games I’ve played, but its not really fun its functional.The controls could be laid out better and the ability to jump from car to car seems out of place. But its not a huge issue and shouldn’t put you off playing it. The other issue is the camera, the camera seems to go crazy when reversing a car. It puts it self in some of the least helpfull possisions. But thankfully you probably wont be reversing too much so it shouldn’t give you too much trouble.See full review here http://cyberusuk.com/2015/02/25/sleeping-dogs-review-should-you-let-it-lie/

Posted: February 12, 2014
												What can i say,i thought this was just going to be another generic grand theft auto / saints row style open world car stealing and gangland killing game, but this has a lot more depth to it.as an undercover cop, you're simultaneously performing legit missions to raise your police officer ranking and skills, and at the same time undertaking shadier and shadier missions for the gangs to raise your rep and gain deeper access to the criminal world.the driving mechanics are solid, with a range of vehicles and motor bikes to pick up.highlight for me is the melee fighting mechanic though, it's great how you can actually perform differenet moves, interrupts, locks, throws, and use the environment to take down enemies.surprising one! highly recommended.

Posted: July 29, 2013
												Anyone who loves sandbox games, or the Grand Theft Auto series will absolutely love this game. If not, this will be one of those exceptions. You play as Wei Chen, a cop who tries to infultrate the most dangerous gangs in Hong Kong, all whilst trying to stay under cover. The story is set in a beautiful city environment loosely based around Hong Kong. The scenery is fantastic, and there are mods available in the steam workshop to make it even more visually stunning. In addition to that, the story is gripping and the combat system is superb. Within a couple of fights, you've got the hang of fighting for the rest of the game. It develops well, and more complex moves are added when you collect more of the missing statues. The only complaint that I have, is the fact that I completed the main story a little too quickly. A few more missions or added characters or scenes would have been brilliant. However, even after completing it, I still play the game as there are plenty of little odd jobs here and there to do.When this game is going cheap (maybe during the steam sales!) I would say:GRAB IT AS FAST AS YOU CAN. It'll be one of the best games you buy, I can tell you it certainly is one of mine.

Posted: August 23, 2012
												First of all, THANK YOU SQUARE ENIX. Sleeping Dogs is without a doubt one of the most entertaining games I have played this year. Gameplay is flawless. Feels somewhat awkward at first but it's something the player adapts to overtime. Not surprised to see vehicles control the same way as they did in past True Crime games. Music is fantastic. Great assortment of radio channels. Fighting is a major step-up from past TC games despite the inability to learn different martial art styles. Plenty of skills to learn. Love every moment of it. Same applies to gun fights. Story is action packed and very immersive. Definitely lives up to past True Crime games. Campaign alone is roughly 10-15 hrs, but you can easily squeeze out over 50hrs with collectables, side missions, fight club, racing, chicken fights (soooo good), hacking cameras, dating, and loads more. Overall a brilliant title packed full of great content. Sleeping Dogs 2. Make it happen Square Enix, since Activision can't be bothered.

Posted: April 6, 2015
												Sleeping Dogs has never been a game at the top of my must play list, to me it was just another GTA clone. But with the latest Humble Bumble package that it was included with, I thought why not give it a go.I’m glad I did too, as its not at all what I expected. Yes its an open world sandbox game, but that’s pretty much where the similarity’s end. In Sleeping Dogs you wont find yourself taking on hundreds of police witha machine gun and RPG, you wont be stealing cars constantly ether. Sleeping Dogs is very much a re-imagining of the genre.Sleeping Dogs puts you in the role of an undercover cop trying to rather successfully infiltrate the triads, the twist being your never completely sure that he hasn’t turned. The character grew up inthe neighborhood and many of your missions involve people he grew up with. It adds an interesting layer to the story, your not just finding out about other characters but also yourself. The Hong Kong that Sleeping Dogs puts you in is not the biggest map out there but its densely populated and really gives the impression of a living breathing city. A lot of work has gone into it and itreally shows, the best example being the night market that you spend much of the start of the game in. People browse the stalls, have conversations, interact with each other and you. At times its easy to forget your missionand get drawn into it all.The missions are good, they make you feel like your watching a gangster film. That’s probably because you’ll spot many elements taken from such films. But I’m not complaining about that, there wellput together and flow. The side missions tend to vary from the average too, instead of for instance taxi missions or pimp missions like the other big titles you will be doing favors for people. These favors couldbe doing free running or stopping a thief and even singing karaoke. But there are racing missions and fight clubs like most sandbox’s. Sleeping Dogs offers the player an upgrade system that’s quite unique too, there are three areas to upgrade. The first is Triad, the experience for this skill are earned through doing triad missionsand criminal acts. The second is Police where the reverse is true, this makes the player walk a tightrope of sorts trying to stay clean while being a criminal. The last skill is Face, this is increased by improving peoplesview of you through favors and such. Its also worth noting though not a skill per-say you can also improve your fighting skills through finding lost Jade statues for the local gym owner.And talking of the fighting, Sleeping Dogs does a great job with this, I’ve hear some compare it to the Arkham games but I disagree. The combat is far more methodical and slower paced. If you go in throwing punches willy nilly the game will punish you, you’ll find yourself waiting for counters and then throwing a few attacks in and back to waiting again. This might sound boring, but when playing its very inviting and seems to fit the whole style of the game well.This game try’s hard to be different from the rest, it succeeds well too. You can steal a car, but you can’t keep it. Your garage is for purchased cars only. You can use guns, but only carry handgun concealed and most of the time you will be using hand to hand combat. The game feels fresh and new, but its not perfect by any means.My one biggest gripe with this title is the driving, now its not terrible by any means but feels stiff and not natural. Its certainly better than some games I’ve played, but its not really fun its functional.The controls could be laid out better and the ability to jump from car to car seems out of place. But its not a huge issue and shouldn’t put you off playing it. The other issue is the camera, the camera seems to go crazy when reversing a car. It puts it self in some of the least helpfull possisions. But thankfully you probably wont be reversing too much so it shouldn’t give you too much trouble.See full review here http://cyberusuk.com/2015/02/25/sleeping-dogs-review-should-you-let-it-lie/

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												The best game of 2012Sleeping dogs came in as a dark horse. Unlike many other games that were released in this period, this game did not get much pre-release press attention or hype. But when the game was released, it out performed the others.For last couple of years, almost all games followed the regular formula for maximum sales. There was nothing new or innovative. All of them featured awesome trailers and demos which makes you wanna play the game; but when you get the game, you realize that the game does not live up to your expectations.Sleeping dogs tried something different, something new. It tells the story of an undercover cop. Unlike many other games in this genre, it is not a run and shoot game. Its an open-world game and focuses mostly on hand-to-hand combat instead of gun-fights. The missions and story are pretty good; although I felt that the main story is a bit too short. The game's combat system deserves all the praises. Its a mix of melee combat in Batman and Assassins Creed Revelations. It features a decent free-running mechanism as well (not as splendid as in Assassins Creed).Side missions include Spying, hacking, looting, racing (typical GTA eh?). The vehicle mechanics in this game is done by programmers who previously worked in the legendary Need For Speed games. Apart from some occasional glitches, the game's engine is pretty neat. It has a decently realistic renderer(don't expect CryEngine here). However for PC gamers, to experience Hong-Kong (did I say the game is set in Hong-Kong?) in its full glory, you MUST download the High resolution Texture pack from steam - its FREE.So Sleeping Dogs = GTA + Saints Row (open world) with Batman (fighting) and Splinter Cell (hacking and things like that) and Assassins Creed (free-running)Should you play this game? Absolutely YES

content:
Posted: November 23, 2012
												This is easily one of the best open world games I have ever played combining the mechanics of various great games into one. The game takes place in Hong Kong and the main character is an undercover cop who works his way up in the gangs. The game has a lot of hand to hand combat reminding me a lot of Batman Arkham Asylum with a very smooth feeling in it. There is also some gunplay which while feeling pretty good, does not work well on mouse and keyboard due to the way the controls are done. You have to hold the shift key in order to zoom in and that just feels terrible. The right mouse button is already taken up by interact and counter so this leaves the shift key or you need to work something else out. Since there is also a lot of driving in this game, I would recommend you just use an Xbox 360 controller to play this game. The graphics and sound in this game are really nice. The game does not support XP due to use of DX11 features and the game looks really nice with them enabled. The game will last about 8+ hours for the main story but 100% completion will take a lot longer. I preferred this game over Grand Theft Auto IV and I recommend it to anyone looking for a good sandbox action game. 90/100

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												I'm struggling to put my finger on exactly why I like Sleeping Dogs so much. It's your favourite GTA game, only pared down, de-fluffed and condensed. Combat is about diving into groups of enemies and turning into a melee-powered arm-breaking knee-snapping force of nature - guns are used to escalate situations, not resolve them. You're a cop! - and so your actions are judged appropriately while playing a mission. Likewise, you're infiltrating the Triads - so you're scored for being ruthless.There's not an awful lot to do outside of the main storyline, but who cares? Cruising around fictional Hong Kong is enjoyable in itself, and by the time you've finished the story you've pretty much seen all there is to see in the game anyway.No cruft, no gimmicks, no eye-rolling social commentary: just an enjoyable crime story set in Hong Kong, with an open-world game as the way it's told. ...and pork bun. Lots of pork bun.

												hello guys, my name is dako. i want to like to compare this game with GTA but on the other hand yu cant compare this with gta. because it is a diffrerent game. surely, it includes the concept of an open world environment game. but, it seems like square enix didnt put much effort in this game like rockstar in GTA. i had a lot of fun playin the story. the city of hong kong is very atmospheric and good. the graphic of the modells and city are although very nice. the story itself is a little bit easy to predict. nothing special. undercover cop tries to arrest the head of the triads and get a lot of trouble in the end. The Missions are ok and nice to play. Sometimes a little bit weird because of nonsense but ok. the control is very uncomfortable because they emulated the console control to a keyboard- mouse control. you have to work urself through this mess. overall you will have fun. if u like to play at least 12 hours of good missions in an visually nice city u cant do anything wrong. if u like to hunt additionally some achievments and reach a playtime of 20 hrs u cant do anything wrong. i purchased this game for 7,5€, no reason to pay more. pros: - nice graphics- nice atmosphere- nice  combat system- a lot of different ways to play this game - somtimes funny / good humor cons:- a little bit tooooo  easy- sidequests are sometimes boring- its not possible to buy weapons- some bugs / glitchesis good in its own way but no comparison with GTA 4.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												4.7/5 Absolutely Recommended.AestheticsGraphics: There are many graphics settings which is good for those without super good computers.Sound: The sound quality is fine, voice acting is good.Gameplay Plot: The game is set in Hong Kong, a unique setting unlike most cliche open-world games.You are an undercover cop and you get the best of both worlds being a triad member you work your way up the hierarchy of the triad gang and get better skills for both sides. Combat: Versatile and extremely enjoyable. You can do kung fu moves, smash people's heads in, grab them and throw them off of a building roof, and many more things. Driving: Pretty average for your open-world action game.Length: The game is a bit short. It took me about 25 hours to beat it. It will take you about 20-30 hours to beat the game depending on how many events you do and how often you do the main story missions.Open-world Events: The events in this game are quite different from any other games. You can fight in a fight club, do races around the city, bet in cockfights, bust drug deals around the city, do various favors for characters around the city to increase your Face level, and more. Not to mention the lockboxes and health shrines placed all around the city. Lockboxes are pretty much chests filled with money and sometimes rare clothing. Health shrines increase your maximum health after you find a certain amount in each city.Immersion: The game is extremely immersive. The developers did a very good job of capturing the essence of Hong Kong, or at least our perception of it with the sounds of lots of yelling, street vendors, night markets, and generally the Cantonese language. The radio plays good songs that you would expect to hear in a car.CustomizationHere are the individual things to customize about your character:HatTorsoPantsShoesWatchBraceletSome item sets give your character added perks such as dealing more melee damage or being more sneaky around cops.You can also unlock preset outfits by playing the game.ConclusionYou can't go wrong if you buy this game. If you are into free-roam action games with a good plot, I definitely recommend that you buy this game, I can guarantee you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game could be summed up in "GTA with Triads". And that's a great thing.First because Hong Kong and the Chinese gangster scene isn't a properly explored field in gaming as a whole. So you have a rich universe, deep characters and an immersive, breathing city, all wrapped up in gorgeous art direction and graphics and nice gameplay.I won't write about the plot, because in my opinion, the impact and involvement is always stronger when you arrive unbiased. But I can say the story develops as a good Chinese cop movie, with nods to 70's grindhouse flicks and even B-movies here and there.You have a huge city to explore, on foot or using one out of a crapload of vehicles at your disposal (one way or another). You have tons of stuff to do other than the story missions (favors, jobs, collectibles, events, fight clubs, street races, collectibles, challenges among your friends via Social Hub... did I say collectibles?). A very nice experience for the regular OCD gamer.The game focuses on fighting instead of gun firing, and I also liked this a lot. Dozens of bone-breaking, spine-chilling ultraviolent moves to beat the heck out of bad guys. Then you jump in a car and engage into an action movie chase, driving with one hand and shooting enemies' tires with the other. Explosions and slow motions abound. Situations like this are common.One thing that caught my attention is the missions never get repetitive. Or at least they don't look as much. Even if you're using the same mechanics, you're always doing different stuff. There's the obligatory fetch quests. You scare people who don't pay your boss. You take your girlfriend for a stroll. You hijack armored trucks. You hack cameras, pick locks, plant bugs. You break into a guy's house to mess with his Feng Shui. There's even a mission where you must sing horribly in karaoke, on purpose, to help a guy convince his girlfriend to leave the place. How 'bout that?The voice acting is very good, and the vehicles you take give access to several radios of different styles of music, from 80s pop to hard rock, cheesy Asian tunes and even classical. Nothing compares to find yourself running away from the police while listening to Debussy's Clair de Lune.I played this via Big Picture with a 360 controller and the experience was pretty tight. I had no technical problems.Had good laughs with this game. And "Holeee sheet" moments, and edge-of-seat moments, and "In yo face punk!" moments. So I highly recommed this game and the extra DLC chapters (Zodiac Tournament, Year of the Snake, Nightmare), which are also tons of fun.
